Chapter 6 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— General powers of city, §§ 1.12, 1.13. 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 14. 
State Law reference— Constitutional grant of home rule powers, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II; statutory grant of home rule powers, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-1 et seq.; Georgia Alcoholic Beverage Code, O.C.G.A. § 3-1-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 6-1. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 17-7-01 , adopted Aug. 1, 2017, repealed § 6-1, which pertained to power to temporarily close business and derived from Code 1987, § 33-109. 
Sec. 6-2. - Posting of license; posting of advertisements. 
The city shall provide for all retail licensees a decalcomania to post on the premises of their places of business. Additionally, licensees shall not post more than two authorized signs in keeping with the city's sign ordinance at their places of business; nor shall they display signs advertising brand, product or price either outside or inside in such a manner as to be visible from the outside. 
(Code 1987, § 33-110; Ord. No. 14-02-02, 3-4-14 ) 
Sec. 6-3. - Sale on election days. 
As authorized by O.C.G.A. § 3-3-20, licensees at all locations where alcoholic beverages are sold may open their places of business for such sales on all election days. 
(Code 1987, § 33-104) 
Sec. 6-4. - Hours of sale. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale any alcoholic beverage for consumption by the drink on the premises, in or upon any licensed premises, except between the hours of 7:30 a.m. and 1:00 a.m., on all days except for Sunday. Alcohol beverages may be consumed on the premises between the hours of 7:30 a.m. on Saturdays until 1:00 a.m. on Sundays. Notwithstanding the above, if December 31 st (New Year's Eve) falls on a Monday through Saturday, the hours for consumption are extended until 1:55 a.m. for December 31 st only. The hours for the Sunday sale of distilled spirits, wine and malt beverages for consumption on the premises shall be in accordance with section 6-5 below. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale package alcoholic beverages at wholesale or retail, in or upon any licensed premises except between the hours of 7:30 a.m. and 11:45 p.m. on all days, except for Sunday. The hours for the Sunday sale of package alcoholic beverages at wholesale or retail, not for consumption on premises, shall be in accordance with section 6-5 below. 
(c)  All licensees under this chapter which serve alcoholic beverages for consumption by the drink on the premises shall be closed at 1:30 a.m., and not open for business earlier than 6:00 a.m. following. 
(d)  No licensee under this chapter shall permit a place of business to sell alcoholic beverages on any other day or times during or upon which the sale of alcoholic beverages is prohibited by law. 
(Ord. No. 94-06-02, 7-19-94; Ord. No. 94-06-01, 7-19-94; Ord. No. 11-11-01, 12-6-11; Ord. No. 17-1-01 , 1-17-17) 
Note— See the editor's note to § 6-52. 
State Law reference— Sunday sales, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-20; § 3-3-7. 
Sec. 6-5. - Same—Sunday sales. 
(a)  The sale of distilled spirits, wine and malt alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises shall be permitted with food service at tables and booths in dining facilities at specially licensed establishments between the hours of 12:30 p.m. and 12:00 midnight on Sundays. 
(b)  The additional annual fee for such special license shall be in the amount of $600.00 and be payable in the same manner as regular licenses permitting the sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises on the other six days of the week; and such special license shall be issuable only in conjunction with such regular licenses and for establishments whereat both food and alcoholic beverages are sold; and be subject to all other conditions and requirements for application, consideration, approval and operations as such regular licenses. 
(c)  The applicant for such special license shall submit such documentation as may be required by the city manager to satisfy the city that the statutory mandate respecting food sales has obtained at the establishment for the preceding 12 months collectively or, in the alternative, such applicant may elect to submit within 20 days following the conclusion of each calendar quarter after issuance of such special license, a certificate from a certified public accountant that said statutory mandate was obtained within the preceding calendar quarter; the failure to submit as aforesaid being grounds sufficient for refusal or revocation, as applicable. 
(d)  The Sunday sale of package alcoholic beverages at wholesale or retail, not for consumption on premises, shall be from 12:30 p.m. to 11:30 p.m. 
(Ord. No. 94-06-01, 7-19-94; Ord. No. 11-11-01, 12-6-11) 
State Law reference— Sunday sales, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-20, § 3-3-7. 
Sec. 6-6. - No alcoholic beverage possession or consumption on certain premises. 
No alcoholic beverage, (to include, without limitation, malt beverages, distilled spirits, liquors, and wines), may be possessed or consumed, (or permitted to be possessed or consumed), upon the premises of any business, within the city, which provides food service, or live or recorded entertainment, or facilities for dancing, unless such business shall have a valid city license for the sale of such possessed or consumed beverage, and such possessed or consumed beverage is purchased upon such premises in conformity with the city license. The provisions of this section shall apply jointly and severally to any such person(s) possessing or consuming such beverage in violation hereof, and any business license holder, their managers, their agents, or employees permitting such possession or consumption in violation of this section. There is specifically and expressly excluded from the operation of this section, private gatherings upon business premises where food service or live or recorded entertainment are not usually provided by such business. 
(Ord. No. 99-05-02, 7-15-99; Ord. No. 05-01-02, 1-18-05) 
Sec. 6-7. - Removal of partially consumed and sealed bottle of wine from restaurant by patron. 
Notwithstanding any other contrary provision of law, any restaurant which is licensed by the City of Helen to sell alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises may permit a patron to remove one unsealed bottle of wine per patron for consumption off premises, if the patron has purchased a meal and consumed a portion of the bottle of wine which has been purchased on the premises with such meal on the restaurant's premises. A partially consumed bottle of wine that is to be removed from the premises must be securely resealed by the licensee or its employees before removal from the premises. The partially consumed bottle of wine shall be placed in a bag or other container that is secured in such a manner that it is visibly apparent if the container has been subsequently opened or tampered with, and a dated receipt for the bottle of wine and meal shall be provided by the licensee and attached to the container. If transported in a motor vehicle, the container with the resealed bottle of wine shall be placed in a locked glove compartment, a locked trunk, or the area behind the last upright seat of a motor vehicle that is not equipped with a trunk. 
State Law reference— Removal of wine from restaurant by patron, O.C.G.A. § 3-6-4. 
(Ord. No. 09-12-02, 1-5-10) 
Sec. 6-8. - Permit of beer and wine sales at city special events. 
Special outdoor areas where beer and/or wine may be dispensed and consumed shall be permitted only within the delineated boundaries of a special city event subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  The dispensing or consumption of beer and/or wine in designated outdoor areas shall be permitted only at special city events, when, by the adoption of a resolution of the city commission, an event is designated by the city commission, and solely within the commission's discretion, as a "special city event" for the purpose of fostering the city's economic development and/or tourism and to recognize events of historical significance. The city special event designation is intended for, and shall be issued only for a city special event. The designation is not for intended for events held by individuals or private businesses. 
(2)  In the event that an event is characterized as a special city event by the city commission, designated outdoor cafe areas may be outlined or designated where beer and/or wine may be served and consumed within the delineated boundaries of the event. 
(3)  Whenever any event will include the dispensing and consumption of beer and/or wine, any vendor of beer and/or wine who seeks a permit to sell within the delineated boundaries of the special city event will, at least 45 days prior to the event, meet with the Helen City Manager and chief of police; in order to review the plans, conditions and restrictions pertaining to the event. Prior to the issuance of an alcohol service permit for the event, the vendor shall sign a statement of understanding of and agreement to the terms and conditions imposed on the event. Such statement shall become a part of the conditions of the alcohol service permit for the event. 
(4)  The dispensing of beer and/or wine at any special outdoor cafe area shall be restricted to vendors possessing a valid city alcoholic beverage license for the sale of beer and wine on premises. The name of such licensee(s) and the current license number, as such appear on the license, shall be required as a part of the application for a special event vending permit. 
(5)  Every area where beer and/or wine is consumed shall be conspicuously posted at all times at each point of entrance/exit with signs stating the following: "The possession of alcoholic beverages beyond this point is prohibited." The letters of such signs shall not be less than three inches in height and one-half inch in width and shall be in black letters on a contrasting light background. 
(6)  It shall be unlawful for patrons of any area(s) of a special event in which beer and/or wine is permitted to bring into or take outside the designated area(s) any alcoholic beverage or to furnish any alcoholic beverage to any person outside the designated area where beer and/or wine is permitted. 
(7)  The application to dispense beer and/or wine at a special city event at which beer and/or wine is permitted shall include, in addition to the map identifying the outermost boundaries of the event, a map no smaller than 8½ by 11 inches in size, clearly identifying the area(s), including all public streets and sidewalks within and adjacent to the area(s), where the consumption of beer and/or wine is proposed; and the area from which the vendor proposes to conduct beer and/or wine sales. 
(8)  The fee for a permit to dispense and/or consume beer and/or wine at a city special event shall be set by the city commission no less that 45 days prior to the event and shall be made payable to City of Helen. 
(9)  Notwithstanding the provisions of this section, any person dispensing and/or consuming beer and/or wine in accordance with this section shall comply with all other laws and ordinances pertaining to the sale, possession and consumption of alcoholic beverages. 
(Ord. No. 13-05-01, 5-21-13; Ord. No. 14-08-01, 8-19-14 ) 
Secs. 6-9—6-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LICENSES GENERALLY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Authority relative to licenses, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-2. 

Sec. 6-26. - Expiration, renewal, payment of fee. 
(a)  All licenses to manufacture and distribute alcoholic beverages shall expire at midnight on December 31 of the year in which issued. 
(b)  All applications for the renewal of licenses to manufacture or distribute alcoholic beverages shall be submitted to the city on or before December 1 of the year in which the license was issued, and the reapplication must be approved or disapproved within 30 days of December 1 of that year. 
(c)  The license fee shall be due and payable upon submission of the application to the city. Payment may be made only by certified check. If the commission fails to approve the application, the license fee shall be refunded. 
(Code 1987, § 33-105) 
Sec. 6-27. - Fines and/or suspension and/or revocation. 
All alcoholic beverage licenses issued pursuant to this chapter are the mere grant of privilege to carry on a business, and such licenses are subject to being revoked and annulled by the city. Each license issued hereunder is subject to the laws of State of Georgia and the ordinances of the city. 
(a)  The following shall be grounds for fines and/or suspension and/or revocation of a license to manufacture and distribute alcoholic beverages. 
(1)  The violation by the license holder or an employee of any state or federal law or regulation, or any ordinance of this city other than traffic violations. 
(2)  The failure of the license holder or an employee to report promptly to the police department any violation of the law or a municipal ordinance, breach of the peace, disturbance or altercation resulting in violence occurring inside the premises. 
(3)  Any conduct on the part of the license holder or an employee contrary to the public welfare, safety, health or morals. 
(4)  Operating or conducting the business in a manner contrary to the public welfare, safety, health or morals, or in such manner as to constitute a nuisance. 
(5)  The violation of any state or municipal law or regulation pertaining to alcoholic beverages. 
(6)  The failure of a license holder or an employee to properly check identification to ensure that an underage person is not sold, served, or does not have in his possession alcoholic beverages while in a licensed establishment. The term "identification," in this section, means any document issued by a governmental agency containing a description of the person, such person's photograph and giving such person's date of birth and shall include, without being limited to, a passport, military ID card, driver's license or ID card issued by a governmental entity. 
(7)  A license holder or an employee knowingly selling or furnishing alcoholic beverages to any person who is visibly and noticeably intoxicated. 
(8)  The furnishing of fraudulent or untruthful information in the application for a license and/or the failure to pay all fees, taxes, or other charges imposed under the provisions of this chapter, and required in conjunction with the sale of alcoholic beverages. 
(b)  The minimum penalties for any violation of section 6-27 by a license holder or its employee shall be as follows: 
(1)  For a first offense in a one-year period, a minimum fine of $300.00. 
(2)  For a second offense within a one year period, a minimum fine of $600.00 
(3)  For a third offense within a one year, a minimum fine of $1000.00. For a third offense within a one-year period, a license holder's license shall also be suspended for a minimum of three business days. 
(4)  The above are the minimum penalties to be imposed in the event of a violation. The city manager or his designee may impose increased monetary fines, suspend, or revoke the alcoholic beverage license of the license holder in accordance with this code section. Factors to be considered by the city manager in the imposition of disciplinary action to be taken against a license holder shall include: 
a.  The disciplinary history of the licensee. 
b.  Likelihood of deterring future wrongdoing. 
c.  Impact of the offense on the community. 
d.  Any mitigating circumstances or corrective steps being taken by licensee. 
e.  Any aggravating circumstances or failure by the licensee to take remedial or corrective steps. 
(c)  If the city manager or his designee makes a finding a violation has occurred under this code section, the city manager shall be authorized to suspend or revoke an alcoholic beverage license and/or to impose monetary penalties upon the licensee under the conditions set forth in this section. However, no revocation, suspension or any other penalty shall be imposed without first providing a licensee the notice, hearing and appeal rights as more specifically provided in section 6-29, or unless an emergency situation is presented, such that immediate suspension or revocation of the license is determined appropriate as provided in subsection (d) below. 
(d)  If the city manager or the chief of police of the city makes the determination that an emergency situation is presented where there is a danger to human life, imminent criminal activity or other imminent danger to the peace, prosperity and welfare of the citizens of Helen, the city manager or the chief of police may immediately suspend or revoke a license by the delivery of a written order thereof to the license holder's premises, so long as a hearing thereon as specified in section 6-29(c) below is held within five business days of the emergency situation. 
(Ord. No. 17-7-01 , 8-1-17) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 17-7-01 , adopted Aug. 1, 2017, repealed the former § 6-27 and enacted a new § 6-27 as set out herein. The former § 6-27 pertained to revocation and derived from Code 1987, § 33-106. 
Sec. 6-28. - Imposition of fine. 
Grounds for the suspension and/or revocation of a license under this article also constitute grounds for the imposition of a fine against a licensee. A fine may be imposed by the commission concurrent with or in lieu of suspension, but not revocation, of a license. No fine shall exceed $1,000.00; but each violation, even if arising out of the same transaction, may incur a fine. 
(Code 1987, § 33-107; Ord. No. 11-3-03, 4-5-11; Ord. No. 17-7-01 , 8-1-17) 
Sec. 6-29. - Notice and hearing process; appeal. 
(a)  Prior to imposing any sanction authorized by section 6-27 of this chapter, the city manager shall provide a written order to the licensee specifying the licensee's alleged violations of this chapter and the penalty to be imposed. Written notice of such order shall be delivered to the premises of the license holder by an officer of the Helen City Police Department. Delivery of the written notice to those premises shall be considered legal service of process. 
(b)  The written order issued by the city manager in accordance with the procedures outlined above shall be stayed for a period of ten days after the service of the order. During this ten-day period, the licensee shall have the right to file a written hearing request with the city commission, stating the grounds for appeal of the city manager's order. If the licensee files a timely request for hearing, the city manager's order shall be stayed until the licensee's hearing is held or the request is withdrawn. If the licensee does not file a timely request, the city manager's order shall become final, and the sanctions imposed against the license in said order shall begin on the 10 th day after service of the order, and any fines imposed shall be due and payable immediately. 
(c)  If timely written hearing request is filed, a hearing shall be held before the Helen City Commission to determine if the violations have occurred. The date of the hearing shall be not less than five nor more than 30 days after the date of the filing of the written request for hearing. All testimony shall be sworn. The city manager or his designee will bear the burden of proof by preponderance of the evidence that the violation(s) have occurred. Following the hearing, the city commission may sustain, overrule or modify the order of the city manager. If the city commission does not find by a preponderance of the evidence that the violation as cited occurred, the city commission will overrule the order. Otherwise, if the city commission finds by preponderance of the evidence that the violation(s) occurred, the city commission will sustain or modify the city manager's order, based upon the evidence presented in the hearing. 
(d)  The findings of the city commission hearing shall be final unless appealed within 30 days of the date of said findings by certiorari to the superior court of White County. 
(Ord. No. 17-7-01 , 8-1-17) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 17-7-01 , adopted Aug. 1, 2017, repealed the former § 6-29 and enacted a new § 6-29 as set out herein. The former § 6-29 pertained to commission hearing and derived from Ord. No. 89-3, § 33-108, adopted June 20, 1989. 
Sec. 6-30. - Employee licensing. 
The following provisions apply to all establishments holding a license under this chapter: 
(1)  This section has been enacted for the purposes, among others, of promoting the health and general welfare of the community; to establish reasonable and ascertainable standards for the regulation and identification of employees of licensees under this chapter that are likely to serve alcohol or interact in a substantial way with those patrons purchasing or consuming alcohol from these licensees; and to ensure that such employees, having access to and control of alcoholic beverages and their distribution, are identifiable in the event of any reports of incidents occurring at establishments licensed to sell alcoholic beverages. 
(2)  Any person obtaining his or her initial serving license permit within the city shall be required to watch a mandatory training video on the responsible service of alcohol at Helen City Hall. The training video will be available for viewing twice weekly at city hall and only at those times designated by the city administrative staff. The serving license permit will not be issued without completing the training. 
(3)  This section does not apply to employees whose duties are limited solely to those of a bus person, cook or dishwasher; or to a restaurant host or hostess whose job consists solely of greeting and seating customers, and who does not serve, sell or take orders for alcoholic beverages. 
(4)  No licensee under this chapter shall allow any employee required to hold a serving license on the licensed premises unless the licensee has on file, on the premises, the current, valid license permit of such employee in accordance with this chapter. The employee's photo identification serving license must clearly be displayed and visible on their person at all times when the employee is working. 
(5)  If any permit holder leaves the employ of a licensed establishment, the licensee and permit holder shall immediately notify the city of this change in employment, in writing, and upon obtaining further employment in the city for a position as stated above, the permit holder shall notify the city of his or her new place of employment, in writing, within 72 hours. 
(6)  All serving license permits issued hereunder remain the property of the city, and shall be produced for inspection upon the demand of the police department. 
(7)  Violations of this section may be cited and punished in accordance with section 1-7 of this Code, and may also serve as grounds for suspension and/or revocation of licensees in accordance with section 6-27 of this Code. 
(8)  The fee for this permit is to be set by the city manager. 
(9)  This Municipal Code section specifically incorporates the provisions of Official Code of Georgia § 3-3-24. Persons under 18 years of age not to be allowed or required to serve, sell, or take orders for alcoholic beverages; exceptions 
a.  No person shall allow or require a person in his employment under 18 years of age to dispense, serve, sell, or take orders for any alcoholic beverages. 
b.  This code section (O.C.G.A. § 3-3-24) shall not prohibit persons under 18 years of age who are employed in supermarkets, convenience stores, breweries, or drugstores from selling or handling alcoholic beverages which are sold for consumption off the premises. 
(Ord. No. 11-04-01, 5-17-11; Ord. No. 11-08-01, 8-16-11; Ord. No. 13-07-01, 7-16-13; Ord. No. 17-7-01 , 8-1-17) 
Sec. 6-31. - Consumption sales only, full service grocery store exception. 
Except as otherwise provided herein (specifically, sections 6-71 and 6-73 of this Code), persons holding a license to sell alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises shall also not hold a license for the sale of alcoholic beverages by the package, with the exception that a full service grocery store, as defined herein, may hold both types of licenses. A full service grocery store is defined as a retail market which meets all of the following criteria: 
(a)  A retail market that maintains at all times that it is open an inventory of saleable food products, including meat, dairy, vegetables, fruits, dry goods, and beverages; 
(b)  Has an interior floor space and storage area of at least 8,000 square feet and devotes at least 50 percent of such interior floor space for the display of food for sale products; 
(c)  Includes a full service kitchen that sells and serves prepared foods; 
(d)  Has a designated location for beer and wine pouring for on premises consumption; and 
(e)  Does not sell or offer distilled spirits or vehicular fuel. 
(Ord. No. 17-04-01 , 4-18-17; Ord. No. 17-7-01 , 8-1-17) 
Secs. 6-32—6-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - MALT BEVERAGES[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Malt beverages, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 6-51. - Excise tax. 
(a)  Rate of levy. There is hereby set and levied on the sale of malt beverages within the city the following excise tax: 
(1)  Where malt beverages, commonly known as tap or draft beer, are sold in or from a barrel or bulk container, a tax of $6.00 on each container sold containing not more than 15½ gallons and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of 15½ gallons. 
(2)  Where malt beverages are sold in bottles, cans, or other containers, except barrel or bulk containers, a tax of $0.05 per 12 ounces and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of 12 ounces. 
(b)  Against whom levied. The malt beverage excise tax is levied against and shall be paid by each licensed wholesale dealer in malt beverages in the city. 
(c)  Due date, required report. The malt beverage excise tax shall be paid on or before the tenth day of the month following the calendar month in which the beverages are sold or disposed of, and payment shall be accompanied by a report itemizing the exact quantities of malt beverages sold for the preceding calendar month by size and type of container. Any tax remaining unpaid at the expiration of 15 days from the due date shall be delinquent. 
(d)  Enforcement. The tax levied by this section may be enforced by execution in the same manner as other taxes of the city, and in addition, any failure of payment of such tax shall be grounds for revocation or refusal of the business license of the delinquent taxpayer. The city manager or designee shall administer and enforce the provisions of this section for the collection of the tax herein imposed, and in so doing shall have the power to: 
(1)  Examine, or authorize the examination of, books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment, and other facilities of any person subject to the tax, in order to verify the accuracy of any report made, or if no report is made, to ascertain and determine the amount required to be paid; 
(2)  Require the filing of reports by any person having possession or custody of information relating to the tax herein levied; and 
(3)  Allow a credit on any amount due and payable from persons who paid the tax herein levied but who were erroneously or illegally subjected thereto. 
(e)  Deficiency. 
(1)  Determination of deficiency. If the city has cause to believe that the report of the tax or the amount of the tax required to be paid to the city by any person is not proper, it may compute and determine the amount required to be paid upon the basis of any information that is within or may come into its possession. One or more deficiency determinations may be made of the amount due for one or more monthly period. 
(2)  Interest on deficiency. The amount of the deficiency shall bear interest at an annual rate equal to the bank prime loan rate as posted by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System in statistical release H. 15 or any publication that may supersede it, plus 3%, to accrue monthly. Such annual interest rate shall be determined for each calendar year based on the first weekly posting of statistical release H. 15 on or after January 1 of each calendar year. Interest shall begin to accrue on the due date for which the amount or any portion thereof should have been returned, and shall continue until the date of payment. 
(3)  Notice of determination and service. The city shall give to the person written notice of the determination. The notice may be serviced personally or by mail; if by mail, such service shall be addressed to the person at his address as it appears in the records of the city. Service by mail is complete when mailed with a certificate of service stamped thereon and a copy retained in city files or when delivered by certified mail with a receipt signed by the addressee. 
(4)  Time within which notice of deficiency determination to be mailed. Except in the case of failure to make a return, every notice of a deficiency determination shall be mailed 
within three years after the 20th day of the month following the calendar month for which the amount is proposed to be determined, or within three years after the return is filed, whichever period should last expire. 
(Code 1987, § 4-102; Ord. No. 16-8-01 ; 9-6-16) 
Cross reference— Taxation, ch. 62. 
State Law reference— Malt beverage excise tax, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-80 et seq.; Rate of interest on past due taxes, O.C.G.A., § 48-2-40. 
Sec. 6-52. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 94-06-02, adopted July 19, 1994, deleted former § 6-52, relative to hours of sale for malt beverages, and enacted new provisions regarding the hours of sale for alcoholic beverages which have been included herein at the discretion of the editor as § 6-4. The provisions of former § 6-52 derived from Code 1987, § 33-101(7). 
Sec. 6-53. - Sanitary condition of premises. 
All premises used for the sale or manufacture of malt beverages shall be kept in a safe and sanitary condition as required by the ordinances of this city and the laws of this state. 
(Code 1987, § 33-101(6)) 
Secs. 6-54—6-65. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSING OF BREWERS AND DEALERS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— General authority relative to licenses, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-20; local licensing of malt beverages, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-40 et seq. 

Sec. 6-66. - License required. 
Each brewer, wholesale dealer and retail dealer of malt beverages, not exempted by state law from municipal licensing requirements, who does business within this municipality shall be required to obtain a license from the city clerk in the manner specified in this division. 
(Code 1987, § 33-101(1)) 
State Law reference— Local license required, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-40. 
Sec. 6-67. - Fee established. 
The annual business license fee for each place of business engaged in malt beverage brewing, distribution and selling of malt beverages at wholesale or retail or for consumption on premises, whose place of business is located within the city shall be $1,000.00. 
(Code 1987, § 33-101(2); Ord. No. 99-10-01, 10-19-99; Ord. No. 01-05-01, 6-5-01) 
State Law reference— License fee authorized, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-42. 
Sec. 6-68. - Publication of notice of application for license; background investigation. 
No application for a license for the sale or manufacture of malt beverages within this city shall be acted upon by the city commission until after notice has been run two times in the county legal organ. Such notice shall contain the name of the applicant and the location of the proposed business and shall be run at the applicant's expense. Additionally, a background investigation of the applicant shall be conducted and a public hearing held on the application prior to commission action. A fee of $100.00 shall be charged the applicant to defray the city's expense in conducting the background investigation. 
(Code 1987, § 33-101(3); Ord. No. 98-06-04, 6-25-98) 
Sec. 6-69. - Factors for commission consideration. 
The full commission in passing upon an initial application for a malt beverage license shall be guided by the following factors as to whether to grant or deny the application: 
(1)  The proximity of other establishments selling malt or alcoholic beverages to the proposed location. 
(2)  The character of the neighborhood immediately adjacent to the proposed location. 
(3)  The proximity of churches, schools and playgrounds to the proposed location. 
(4)  Whether the proposed location has adequate offstreet parking facilities or other parking available for its patrons. 
(5)  Whether the location would tend to increase and promote traffic congestion and resulting hazards therefrom. 
(6)  The feelings and attitudes of the citizens residing in the area adjacent to the proposed location. 
(7)  The information set forth in the application. 
(8)  Whether any malt or alcoholic beverage license previously issued for such location was ever revoked for cause by the city commission. 
(9)  Whether the applicant has ever sold malt or alcoholic beverages illegally in the city. 
(Code 1987, § 33-101(4)) 
Sec. 6-70. - Change of location. 
A license issued under the provisions of this division shall permit the sale or manufacture of malt beverages only on the premises described in the application. 
(Code 1987, § 33-101(5)) 
Sec. 6-71. - Sale of growlers and/or wine package. 
(a)  Growlers means a bottle or can not to exceed two liters and not less than 12 ounces that is filled with beer from a keg by a duly authorized licensee or employee of said licensee, with said licensee holding a package beer license issued by the city. 
(b)  Package beer/wine license. License holders who hold a license to conduct retail sale of beer beverages and/or wine in its original package. 
(c)  Growlers and/or wine may also be sold by the package from premises licensed for consumption on the premises, provided that the package wine and/or beer licenses are also obtained. Growlers and/or wine package sales are the only type of package sales permitted from premises which are also licensed for consumption on the premises. 
(d)  The sale of growlers, as defined above, is authorized for those licensees holding a package beer license, but is not authorized under any circumstances for those licensees also holding a package distilled spirits license; or for those licensees who offer for sale vehicular fuel. The filling of growlers by means of a tapped keg shall not constitute the breaking of package as contemplated by O.C.G.A., § 3-3-26. Growlers may only be filled from kegs procured by the licensee from a duly licensed wholesaler. Growlers may be filled and made available for retail sale only if securely sealed. In order to be securely sealed, the growler must be sealed with a tamper proof cap or seal. 
(Ord. No. 17-7-01 , 8-1-17) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 17-7-01 , adopted Aug. 1, 2017, repealed the former § 6-29 and enacted a new § 6-29 as set out herein. The former § 6-29 pertained to sale of growlers and derived from Ord. No. 14-02-01, adopted Feb. 18, 2014 and Ord. No. 17-04-01 , adopted April 18, 2017. 
Sec. 6-72. - Ancillary wine, beer and malt beverage tasting license. 
(a)  The holder of a package beer and wine license shall be eligible for an ancillary wine, beer and malt beverage tasting license to provide samples of wine, beer and malt beverages, offered for sale to customers under the conditions set forth in this section. An ancillary wine, beer and malt beverage tasting license is not authorized for those licensees also holding a package distilled spirits license, or those licensees who offer for sale vehicular fuel. 
(b)  Wine, beer and malt beverage sampling shall be on limited occasions when a customer requests a sample of a wine, beer or malt beverage offered for sale within the premises, or in conjunction with education classes and sampling designed to promote wine, beer and malt beverage appreciation and education. 
(c)  Wine, beer or malt beverage tasting for customers shall be conducted only at a counter area constituting no more than ten percent of the entire floor area of the premises. 
(d)  Such sampling for customers shall be limited to no more than one time per day, on the days of the week authorized by State law to sell beer and wine by the package, for a period of not to exceed two consecutive hours. Samples shall not exceed two ounces, and no customer shall consume more than eight ounces in any two-hour period. 
(e)  The holder of an ancillary wine, beer and malt beverage tasting license may conduct educational classes and sampling for classes not more than two times per week for a period of not to exceed two consecutive hours. All conditions of sampling set forth in this section shall apply to such classes, except for the limitation on floor areas where the classes can be conducted. 
(f)  Wine, beer and malt beverage bottles shall be opened by the licensee or an employee only, and samples shall be poured only by the licensee and/or an employee. 
(g)  No open containers of wine, beer or malt beverage shall be removed from the licensed premises. 
(h)  Such samplings and tasting is permitted within the enclosed portion of the premises only. 
(i)  The annual fee for an ancillary wine, beer and malt beverage tasting license shall be set and may be revised by resolution of the city commission. 
( Ord. No. 14-04-01, 4-15-14 ; Ord. No. 17-04-01 , 4-18-17; Ord. No. 17-7-01 , 8-1-17) 
Sec. 6-73. - Brewpubs. 
(a)  Brewpub means any eating establishment in which beer or malt beverages are manufactured or brewed, subject to the barrel production limitation and such other limitation as are prescribed in the Official Code of Georgia. 
(b)  No individual or entity shall be permitted to own or operate a brewpub without also obtaining a proper license from the Department of Revenue in the manner proscribed, and each brewpub license holder shall comply with all other applicable state and local license requirements; 
(c)  A brewpub license will authorize the holder of such license to manufacture malt beverages in this state shall include the right to sell up to 3,000 barrels of malt beverages per year produced at the brewer's licensed premises to individuals who are on such premises for: 
(1)  Consumption on the premises. 
(2)  Consumption off the premises, provided that such sales for consumption off the premises shall not exceed a maximum of 288 ounces of malt beverages per consumer per day. 
(3)  A license fee of $600.00 shall apply to brewpubs for the sale of malt beverages produced at their licensed premises. Additional licensing fees shall apply should the brewpub intend to sell any alcoholic beverages not produced on premises. 
(d)  A Brewpub may sell malt beverages brewed or manufactured on its premises on all days and at all times that sales of malt beverages by retailers are lawful within the city, including, but not limited to, Sundays. 
(e)  Any brewer engaging in sales of malt beverages pursuant to this Code section shall remit all state and local sales, use, and excise taxes to the proper tax collecting authority, and comply with all other regulations of the Georgia Department of Revenue and the Official Code of Georgia. 
(f)  A brewpub license holder may also obtain a package license for selling wine or malt beverage growlers for malt beverages not produced on its premises, in accordance with section 6-71 of this Code for consumption off the premises, provided the brewpubs remits payment for the package license required. 
(g)  A Brewpubs license holder may obtain an on premises consumption license and offer for on premises consumption any other alcoholic beverages, including wine, distilled spirits, and malt beverages, provided that such alcoholic beverages are purchased from a licensed wholesaler for consumption on the premises; and that the brewpubs obtains and remits payment to the city for the on premises consumption required. 
(Ord. No. 17-7-01 , 8-1-17) 
Secs. 6-74—6-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - WINE[5] 
Footnotes:

State Law reference— Wine, O.C.G.A. § 3-6-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 6-101. - Excise tax. 
(a)  Rate of levy. There is hereby set and levied on the sale of wine an excise tax in the sum of $0.22 per liter and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of a liter. 
(b)  Against whom levied. The wine excise tax shall be paid by each licensed wholesale dealer in wine in the city. 
(c)  Due date, required report. The wine excise tax shall be paid on or before the tenth day of the month following the calendar month in which the beverages are sold or disposed of, and payment shall be accompanied by a report itemizing the exact quantities of wine sold for the preceding calendar month by size of container. Any tax remaining unpaid at the expiration of 15 days from the due date shall be delinquent. 
(d)  Enforcement. The tax levied by this section may be enforced by execution in the same manner as other taxes of the city, and in addition, any failure of payment of such tax shall be grounds for revocation or refusal of the business license of the delinquent taxpayer. The city manager shall administer and enforce the provisions of this section for the collection of the tax herein imposed, and in so doing shall have the power to: 
(1)  Examine, or authorize the examination of, books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment, and other facilities of any person subject to the tax, in order to verify the accuracy of any report made, or if no report is made, to ascertain and determine the amount required to be paid; 
(2)  Require the filing of reports by any person having possession or custody of information relating to the tax herein levied; and 
(3)  Allow a credit on any amount due and payable from persons who paid the tax herein levied but who were erroneously or illegally subjected thereto. 
(e)  Deficiency. 
(1)  Determination of deficiency. If the city has cause to believe that the report of the tax or the amount of the tax required to be paid to the city by any person is not proper, it may compute and determine the amount required to be paid upon the basis of any information that is within or may come into its possession. One or more deficiency determinations may be made of the amount due for one or more monthly period. 
(2)  Interest on deficiency. The amount of the deficiency shall bear interest at an annual rate equal to the bank prime loan rate as posted by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System in statistical release H. 15 or any publication that may supersede it, plus three percent, to accrue monthly. Such annual interest rate shall be determined for each calendar year based on the first weekly posting of statistical release H. 15 on or after January 1 of each calendar year. Interest shall begin to accrue on the due date for which the amount or any portion thereof should have been returned, and shall continue until the date of payment. 
(3)  Notice of determination and service. The city shall give to the person written notice of the determination. The notice may be serviced personally or by mail; if by mail, such service shall be addressed to the person at his address as it appears in the records of the city. Service by mail is complete when mailed with a certificate of service stamped thereon and a copy retained in city files or when delivered by certified mail with a receipt signed by the addressee. 
(4)  Time within which notice of deficiency determination to be mailed. Except in the case of failure to make a return, every notice of a deficiency determination shall be mailed within three years after the 20th day of the month following the calendar month for which the amount is proposed to be determined, or within three years after the return is filed, whichever period should last expire. 
(Code 1987, § 4-105; Ord. No. 16-8-01 , 9-6-16) 
Cross reference— Taxation, ch. 62. 
State Law reference— Local wine excise tax, O.C.G.A. § 3-6-60 et seq.; Rate of interest on past due taxes, O.C.G.A., § 48-2-40. 
Sec. 6-102. - Hours of sale. 
It shall be unlawful to engage in the sale at retail or wholesale of wine except during those hours authorized in section 6-4 and section 6-5. 
(Code 1987, § 33-102(7); Ord. No. 91-5, 6-18-91; Ord. No. 94-06-02, 7-19-94; Ord. No. 17-04-01 , 4-18-17) 
State Law reference— Sunday sales, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-20. 
Sec. 6-103. - Sanitary condition of premises. 
All premises used for the manufacture, distribution and selling of wine at wholesale or retail shall be kept in a safe and sanitary condition as required by the ordinances of this city and the laws of this state. 
(Code 1987, § 33-102(6)) 
Sec. 6-104. - Farm winery annual fee(s). 
Each farm winery tasting room license, at each location, as defined and regulated under section 6-105, shall pay to the city a fee of $600.00 for the operation of a tasting room license only, where such tasting room serves solely as an outlet for the promotion of that farm winery's wine. Should the farm winery also seek authorization from the Revenue Commissioner for the sale of alcoholic beverages not produced by a farm winery for the on premises consumption of alcohol, pursuant to O.C.G.A., § 3-6-21.3, the farm winery shall pay to the city the same license fee(s) that would be applicable to any other licensee seeking licensure for on premises consumption, including the fee for Sunday sales, if Sunday sales are requested. 
(Ord. No. 17-04-01 , 4-18-17) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 17-04-01 , adopted April 18, 2017, repealed the former § 6-104 and enacted a new § 6-104 as set out herein. The former § 6-104 pertained to annual fee and derived from Ord. No. 95-04-01, adopted May 16, 1995. 
Sec. 6-105. - Farm winery tasting room, licensing. 
(a)  The provisions of this section provide a licensing process for the business of operating a Georgia farm winery tasting room in conformance with the laws of the State of Georgia and City of Helen. 
(b)  Definitions. "Farm winery" and "tasting room" shall be defined in accordance with O.C.G.A., § 3-6-21.1 et seq., and as may hereafter be amended. 
(c)  Types of Sales. Wine sold under the provisions of the Georgia Farm Wineries statutes, shall be sold for retail purposes only, sold only in accordance with the state requirements codified at O.C.G.A., § 3-6-21.1 et seq. and incorporated herein by reference, and only under the provisions of a city farm winery license issued hereunder. Sales for the on premises consumption of alcohol may be allowed under a city farm winery license to the extent consistent with the law, rules, and regulations of the State of Georgia, and upon payment of applicable fees as identified in section 6-104. 
(d)  Under this code section, the licensee shall be authorized to carry on the business of operating a farm winery tasting room in their licensed premises. For the purposes of this section, all areas within the city currently, or in the future, zoned PUD, C-1, C-2, C-3, or H/M as defined in chapter 34, "Land Development Code" of the 1994 Helen City Code, are designated as special entertainment districts pursuant to O.C.G.A., § 3-6-21.2. Such designation is made solely for the purpose of allowing Sunday sales in farm winery tasting rooms. 
(Ord. No. 17-04-01 , 4-18-17) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 17-04-01 , adopted April 18, 2017, repealed the former § 6-105 and enacted a new § 6-105 as set out herein. The former § 6-105 pertained to farm winery tasting room and derived from Ord. No. 95-04-01, adopted May 16, 1995. 
Sec. 6-106. - Sunday sales. 
All farm winery tasting rooms, as defined in section 6-105 of the 1994 Helen City Code, and located within a special entertainment district may offer wine for on-premises consumption or in closed packages for consumption off premises on Sundays from 12:30 p.m. until 12:00 midnight, as permitted by O.C.G.A., § 3-6-21.2. 
(Ord. No. 95-04-01, 5-16-95; Ord. No. 17-04-01 , 4-18-17) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 17-04-01 , adopted April 18, 2017, changed the title of § 6-106 from "Hours of Sunday sales" to "Sunday sales." 
Secs. 6-107—6-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference— Alcoholic beverage licenses generally, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-2; local licensing of wine, O.C.G.A. § 3-6-40. 

Sec. 6-121. - Required. 
Each person engaged in the manufacture, distribution and selling of wine at wholesale or retail. not exempted by state law from municipal licensing regulations. shall be required to obtain a license from the city clerk in the manner specified in this division. Operating a farm winery tasting room as authorized by O.C.G.A. § 3-6-21.1(b) shall be construed as selling wine at retail. License Holders who have a License to conduct retail sales of wine shall also be authorized to sell growlers, in accordance with section 6-71 of this Code, and in compliance with the requirements thereof. 
(Code 1987, § 33-102(1); Ord. No. 14-02-01, 2-18-14 ) 
Sec. 6-122. - Fee established. 
The annual business license fee for each place of business engaged in the manufacture, distribution and selling of wine at wholesale or retail or for consumption on premises, shall be $500.00. 
(Code 1987, § 33-102(2); Ord. No. 99-10-01, 10-19-99; Ord. No. 01-05-01, 6-5-01) 
Sec. 6-123. - Publication of notice of application for license; background investigation. 
No application for a license for the sale or manufacture of wine within this municipality shall be acted upon by the city commission until after notice has been run two times in the county legal organ. Such notice shall contain the name of the applicant and the location of the proposed business and shall be run at the applicant's expense. Additionally, a background investigation of the applicant shall be conducted and a public hearing held on the application prior to commission action. A fee of $100.00 shall be charged the applicant to defray the city's expense in conducting the background investigation. 
(Code 1987, § 33-102(3); Ord. No. 98-06-04, 6-25-98) 
Sec. 6-124. - Factors for commission consideration. 
In deciding whether to grant or deny the application for a license to a person engaged in the manufacture, distribution and selling of wine at wholesale or retail, the city commission shall be guided by the same considerations as those applied in granting or denying a license for the sale or manufacture of malt beverages. 
(Code 1987, § 33-102(4)) 
Sec. 6-125. - Change of location. 
A license issued under the provisions of this division shall permit the manufacture, distribution, and selling of wine at wholesale or retail only on the premises described in the application. 
(Code 1987, § 33-102(5)) 
Sec. 6-126. - Ancillary wine, beer and malt beverage tasting license. 
(a)  The holder of a package beer and wine license shall be eligible for an ancillary wine, beer and malt beverage tasting license to provide samples of wine, beer and malt beverages, offered for sale to customers under the conditions set forth in this section. An ancillary wine, beer and malt beverage tasting license is not authorized for those licensees also holding a package distilled spirits license, or those licensees who offer for sale vehicular fuel. 
(b)  Wine, beer and malt beverage sampling shall be on limited occasions when a customer requests a sample of a wine, beer or malt beverage offered for sale within the premises, or in conjunction with education classes and sampling designed to promote wine, beer and malt beverage appreciation and education. 
(c)  Wine, beer or malt beverage tasting for customers shall be conducted only at a counter area constituting no more than ten percent of the entire floor area of the premises. 
(d)  Such sampling for customers shall be limited to no more than one time per day, on the days of the week authorized by State law to sell beer and wine by the package, for a period of not to exceed two consecutive hours. Samples shall not exceed two ounces, and no customer shall consume more than eight ounces in any two-hour period. 
(e)  The holder of an ancillary wine, beer and malt beverage tasting license may conduct educational classes and sampling for classes not more than two times per week for a period of not to exceed two consecutive hours. All conditions of sampling set forth in this section shall apply to such classes, except for the limitation on floor areas where the classes can be conducted. 
(f)  Wine, beer and malt beverage bottles shall be opened by the licensee or an employee only, and samples shall be poured only by the licensee and/or an employee. 
(g)  No open containers of wine, beer or malt beverage shall be removed from the licensed premises. 
(h)  Such samplings and tasting is permitted within the enclosed portion of the premises only. 
(i)  The annual fee for an ancillary wine, beer and malt beverage tasting license shall be set and may be revised by resolution of the city commission. 
( Ord. No. 14-04-01, 4-15-14 ; Ord. No. 17-7-01 , 8-1-17) 
Secs. 6-127—6-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - DISTILLED SPIRITS[7] 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference— Distilled spirits, O.C.G.A. § 3-4-1 et seq.; local regulation thereof, O.C.G.A. §§ 3-4-49, 3-4-110. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 6-151. - Excise tax. 
(a)  Rate of levy. There is hereby set and levied on the sale of distilled spirits, an excise tax in the sum of $0.22 per liter and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of a liter. 
(b)  Against whom levied. The distilled spirits excise tax shall be paid by each licensed wholesale dealer in distilled spirits in the city. 
(c)  Due date, required report. The distilled spirits excise tax shall be paid on or before the tenth day of the month following the calendar month in which the beverages are sold or disposed of, and payment shall be accompanied by a report itemizing the exact quantities of distilled spirits sold for the preceding calendar month by size of container. Any tax remaining unpaid at the expiration of 15 days from the due date shall be delinquent. 
(d)  Enforcement. The tax levied by this section may be enforced by execution in the same manner as other taxes of the city, and in addition, any failure of payment of such tax shall be grounds for revocation or refusal of the business license of the delinquent taxpayer. The city manager shall administer and enforce the provisions of this section for the collection of the tax herein imposed, and in so doing shall have the power to: 
(1)  Examine, or authorize the examination of, books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment, and other facilities of any person subject to the tax, in order to verify the accuracy of any report made, or if no report is made, to ascertain and determine the amount required to be paid; 
(2)  Require the filing of reports by any person having possession or custody of information relating to rentals of guest rooms which are subject to the tax herein levied; and 
(3)  Allow a credit on any amount due and payable from persons who paid the tax herein levied but who were erroneously or illegally subjected thereto. 
(e)  Deficiency. 
(1)  Determination of deficiency. If the city has cause to believe that the report of the tax or the amount of the tax required to be paid to the city by any person is not proper, it may compute and determine the amount required to be paid upon the basis of any information that is within or may come into its possession. One or more deficiency determinations may be made of the amount due for one or more monthly period. 
(2)  Interest on deficiency. The amount of the deficiency shall bear interest at an annual rate equal to the bank prime loan rate as posted by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System in statistical release H. 15 or any publication that may supersede it, plus three percent, to accrue monthly. Such annual interest rate shall be determined for each calendar year based on the first weekly posting of statistical release H. 15 on or after January 1 of each calendar year. Interest shall begin to accrue on the due date for which the amount or any portion thereof should have been returned, and shall continue until the date of payment. 
(3)  Notice of determination and service. The city shall give to the person written notice of the determination. The notice may be serviced personally or by mail; if by mail, such service shall be addressed to the person at his address as it appears in the records of the city. Service by mail is complete when mailed with a certificate of service stamped thereon and a copy retained in city files or when delivered by certified mail with a receipt signed by the addressee. 
(4)  Time within which notice of deficiency determination to be mailed. Except in the case of failure to make a return, every notice of a deficiency determination shall be mailed within three years after the 20th day of the month following the calendar month for which the amount is proposed to be determined, or within three years after the return is filed, whichever period should last expire. 
(Code 1987, § 4-103; Ord. No. 16-8-01 , 9-6-16) 
Cross reference— Taxation, ch. 62. 
State Law reference— Local excise tax on distilled spirits, O.C.G.A. § 3-4-80; Rate of interest on past due taxes, O.C.G.A., § 48-2-40. 
Sec. 6-152. - Distilled spirits by the drink excise tax. 
(a)  Rate of levy. There is hereby set and levied on the purchase of distilled spirits for beverage purposes by the drink an excise tax equal to three percent of the purchase price. 
(b)  Against whom levied. The distilled spirits by the drink excise tax shall be paid by each purchaser at the time of collection for beverages served. 
(c)  Collection, due date, required report. The distilled spirits by the drink excise tax shall be collected by every licensee for the sale of distilled spirits by the drink. All amount of such tax collected by each licensee shall be paid on or before the 20th day of the month following the calendar month in which it was collected and payment shall be accompanied by a report showing the gross receipt of the sale of distilled spirits by the drink and the amount of tax collected on such drinks. Any tax remaining unpaid at the expiration of 15 days from the due date shall be delinquent. 
(d)  Collection fee allowed licensees. Licensees collecting the tax shall be allowed a percentage of the tax due and accounted for and shall be reimbursed in the form of a deduction in submitting, reporting and paying the amount due, if the amount is not delinquent at the time of payment. The rate of the deduction shall be the same rate authorized for deductions from state tax under O.C.G.A. § 48-8-1 et seq. 
(e)  Deficiency. 
(1)  Determination of deficiency. If the city has cause to believe that the return or returns of the tax or the amount of the tax required to be paid to the city by any person is not proper, it may compute and determine the amount required to be paid upon the basis of any information that is within or may come into its possession. One or more deficiency determinations may be made of the amount due for one or more monthly period. 
(2)  Interest on deficiency. The amount of the deficiency shall bear interest at an annual rate equal to the bank prime loan rate as posted by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System in statistical release H. 15 or any publication that may supersede it, plus three percent, to accrue monthly. Such annual interest rate shall be determined for each calendar year based on the first weekly posting of statistical release H. 15 on or after January 1 of each calendar year. Interest shall begin to accrue on the due date for which the amount or any portion thereof should have been returned, and shall continue until the date of payment. 
(3)  Notice of determination and service. The city shall give to the licensee written notice of his determination. The notice may be serviced personally or by mail; if by mail, such service shall be addressed to the licensee at his address as it appears in the records of the city. Service by mail is complete when mailed with a certificate of service stamped thereon and a copy retained in city files or when delivered by certified mail with a receipt signed by the addressee. 
(4)  Time within which notice of deficiency determination to be mailed. Except in the case of failure to make a return, every notice of a deficiency determination shall be mailed within three years after the 20th day of the month following the calendar month for which the amount is proposed to be determined, or within three years after the return is filed, whichever period should last expire. 
(f)  Determination if no return made. 
(1)  Estimates of gross receipts. If any licensee fails to make a return, the city shall make an estimate of the amount of the gross receipts of the licensee, or as the case may be, of the amount of the total sales in this city which are subject to the tax. The estimate shall be made for the period or periods in respect to which the licensee failed to make the return and shall be based upon any information which is in possession of or may come into the possession of the city official. Written notice shall be given in the manner prescribed above. 
(2)  Interest on amount found due. The amount of the determination shall bear interest at the rate of 0.75 percent per month, or fraction thereof, from the 20th day of the month following the calendar month for which the amount or any portion thereof would have been returned, until the date of payment. 
(g)  Penalty for nonpayment. Any licensee who fails to pay the tax herein imposed or fails to pay any amount of the tax required to be collected and paid to the city within the time required shall pay a penalty of 25 percent of the tax owed in addition to interest as set forth above. 
(h)  Enforcement. The tax levied by this section may be enforced by execution in the same manner as other taxes of the city, and in addition, any failure of payment of such tax shall be grounds for revocation or refusal of the business license of the delinquent taxpayer. The city manager shall administer and enforce the provisions of this section for the collection of the tax herein imposed, and in so doing shall have the power to: 
(1)  Examine, or authorize the examination of, books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment, and other facilities of any person subject to the tax, in order to verify the accuracy of any report made, or if no report is made by the operator, to ascertain and determine the amount required to be paid; 
(2)  Require the filing of reports by any person or persons having possession or custody of information relating to the tax herein levied; and 
(3)  Allow a credit on any amount due and payable from persons who paid the tax herein levied but who were erroneously or illegally subjected thereto. 
(Code 1987, § 4-104; Ord. No. 16-8-01 , 9-6-16) 
Cross reference— Taxation, ch. 62. 
State Law reference— Local excise tax on sale of distilled spirits by the drink, O.C.G.A. § 3-4-130 et seq.; Rate of interest on past due taxes, O.C.G.A., § 48-2-40. 
Sec. 6-153. - Hours of sale. 
It shall be unlawful to sell distilled spirits except during those hours authorized in section 6-4 and section 6-5. 
(Code 1987, § 33-103(7); Ord. No. 94-06-02, 7-19-94) 
State Law reference— Sunday sales, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-20. 
Sec. 6-154. - Sanitary condition of premises. 
All premises used for the sale or manufacture of distilled spirits shall be kept in a safe and sanitary condition as required by the ordinances of this city and the laws of this state. 
(Code 1987, § 33-103) 
Secs. 6-155—6-170. - Reserved.

ARTICLE VI. - HOTEL—IN ROOM SERVICE LICENSE 

Sec. 6-181. - License requirements. 
(a)  Notwithstanding any other provisions of this chapter to the contrary, any hotel (as the term " hotel" is commonly used), inn, or other establishment which offers overnight accommodations to the public for hire, may provide "in-room service" of alcoholic beverages if such establishment: 
(1)  Holds a valid city retail package or a valid consumption on the premises license; and 
(2)  Has been authorized to provide "in-room service" by the state revenue commissioner. 
(b)  For purposes of this section, "in-room service" consists of: 
(1)  The delivery of alcoholic beverages in unbroken packages by an employee of the hotel to a registered guest's room when such alcoholic beverages have been ordered by the guest and when the guest shall be billed for the cost of such alcoholic beverages at the time of delivery and when the sale of such alcoholic beverages is completed at the time of delivery; and 
(2)  The provision of a cabinet or other facility located in a hotel's guest room which contains alcoholic beverages and which is provided upon request of the guest and which is accessible by lock and key only to the guest and for which the sale of alcoholic beverages contained therein is final at the time requested except for a credit which may be given to the guest for any unused portion. 
(c)  Except as otherwise provided in this section, in-room service of alcoholic beverages shall be subject to all restrictions and limitations in this chapter relative to the sale of alcoholic beverages. In-room service sales shall be authorized only on such days and only during such hours as the sale of alcoholic beverages is otherwise authorized. 
(d)  All alcoholic beverages sold pursuant to this section shall be purchased from a licensed wholesale dealer and shall be subject to all taxes imposed under this chapter, including the excise tax on mixed drinks where alcoholic beverages are sold as a mixed drink or the ingredients for a mixed drink. 
(e)  All hotels having in-room service shall comply with all requirements promulgated by the Department of Revenue of the State of Georgia dealing with storage of alcoholic beverages and records required to be maintained in order to provide hotel in-room service. 
(f)  No hotel-motel shall be authorized to provide in-room service until it has been issued a license to do so. All such licensees must have a valid city retail package or a valid consumption on the premises license. An additional license fee of $600.00 shall be imposed for in-room service licenses. 
(Ord. No. 17-1-01 , 1-17-17) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 17-1-01 , adopted Jan. 17, 2017, amended the Code by the addition of Art. VI, § 6-176; however, said provisions have been redesignated as § 6-181, at the editor's discretion, for purposes of maintaining Code format. 
Chapter 10 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 08-03-01, adopted April 15, 2008, amended the Code by repealing former ch. 10, §§ 10-1, 10-2, 10-21—10-36, 10-41—10-48, 10-51—10-59, 10-61—10-77, 10-81—10-83, 10-91—10-96, and 10-101, and adding a new ch. 10. Former ch. 10 pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 05-11-01, adopted December 6, 2005. The current chapter is the same as the animal chapter adopted by White County, Georgia, by Res. No. 2005-14 and subsequently amended. Therefore, the history notes following each section indicate amendments by White County resolution, rather than amendment by city ordinance. 
Charter reference— Power of city to regulate animals, § 1.13(28). 
Cross reference— Nuisances, § 26-51 et seq. 
State Law reference— Animal control authorized, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, par. III(a)(3); animals generally, O.C.G.A. § 4-1-1 et seq.; cruelty to animals, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-4; dogfighting, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-37. 

ARTICLE I. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 10-1. - Definitions. 
Adequate food and water. Food and water in sufficient quantity and appropriate for the particular type of animal necessary to prevent starvation, dehydration or a significant risk to the animal's health from a lack of food or water. 
Animal control officer. An individual appointed by the county board of commissioners to administer and enforce the provisions of this chapter including but not limited to the animal control officer, designated agents, employees, the sheriff, the sheriff's deputies or other county law enforcement officers. 
Animal shelter. A facility: 
(1)  Operated by the county board of commissioners or under contract to the board of Commissioners for the purpose of impounding or harboring seized, stray, homeless, abandoned or unwanted dogs, cats and other animals. 
(2)  A veterinary hospital or clinic, which operates for the purpose of impounding or harboring seized, stray, homeless, abandoned or unwanted dogs, cats and other animals in addition to its customary purposes. 
(3)  Operated, owned or maintained by a duly incorporated humane society, animal welfare society or other nonprofit organization for the purpose of providing for and promoting the welfare, protection and humane treatment of animals. 
Dangerous dog. A dog that, according to the records of an appropriate authority has: 
(1)  Attacked, endangered, bitten or has inflicted severe injury on a human being on public or private property; or 
(2)  On more than one occasion severely injured or killed a domestic animal while off the owner's property; or 
(3)  Been used primarily or in part for the purpose of dog fighting or is a dog trained for dog fighting; or 
(4)  When unprovoked, chased or approached a person upon the streets, sidewalks or any public grounds or off the owner's property in a menacing fashion or apparent attitude of attack provided that such actions are attested to in a sworn statement by one or more persons and dutifully investigated by animal control. 
Dead animals. The carcasses or parts of carcasses of animals, regardless of whether they are considered to be farm livestock, poultry, equines, domesticated animals, pets or any other type of animal regardless of the cause of death of such animals. 
Equine. A member of the Equidae species, including horses, mules and asses. 
Governing authority. The county board of commissioners. 
Humane care. The provision of adequate heat, ventilation, sanitary shelter and wholesome food and water consistent with the normal requirements and feeding habits of the animal's size, species and breed. 
Humane society. An unincorporated nonprofit organization existing for the purpose of prevention of cruelty to animals. 
Kennel. An establishment, other than an animal shelter, where dogs or cats are maintained for boarding, holding, training or similar purposes for a fee. 
Livestock. Animals of the equine, bovine or swine class, including goats, sheep, mules, horses, hogs, cattle and other grazing animals and all ratites, including, but not limited to, ostriches, emus and rheas. 
Local government. The county, or when appropriate, the City of Cleveland or the City of Helen. 
Owner. A natural person or any legal entity such as a corporation, partnership, firm or trust which owns, possesses, harbors, keeps, or has custody of an animal. 
Person. A person, firm, corporation, partnership, association, the state, the county or the cities of Cleveland and Helen. 
Pet dealer. A person who sells, offers to sell, exchanges or offers for adoption dogs, cats, birds, fish, reptiles or other animals customarily obtained as pets. However, a person who sells only animals that are produced and raised, not to exceed 30 animals a year, shall not be considered a pet dealer under this chapter. Operation of a veterinary hospital or clinic by a licensed veterinarian shall not constitute the veterinarian as a pet dealer, kennel or stable under this article. 
Potentially dangerous dog. A dog which, when unprovoked, 
(1)  Engages in behavior that requires a defensive action by a person to prevent bodily injury, which occurs off the property of the owner or keeper of the dog attack provided that such actions are attested to in a sworn statement by one or more persons and dutifully investigated by animal control; or 
(2)  Has killed, seriously bitten, inflicted injury or otherwise caused injury while attacking a domestic animal off the property of the owner or keeper of the dog. 
Proper enclosure. An enclosure for keeping a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog securely confined indoors or outdoors in an enclosed and locked pen, fence or structure suitable to prevent the entry of young children and designed to prevent the dog from escaping. Any such pen or structure shall have secure sides and a top. If the dog is enclosed within a fence, all sides of the fence shall be of sufficient height and the bottom of the fence shall be constructed in such a manner as to prevent the dog's escape either from over or from under the fence. Any such enclosure shall also provide protection from the elements. 
Public or private animal refuge. A facility that harbors unwanted animals of any breed including crossbreeds. 
Public roads. A street, road or highway including the full width of the right-of-way which is open to the use of the public for vehicular travel. 
Running at large. Livestock not under manual control of a person on public roads or on property not belonging to the owner unless by permission of the owner of such property. 
Severe injury. A physical injury that results in broken bones or disfiguring lacerations requiring multiple sutures or cosmetic surgery or a physical injury that results in death. 
Stable. A building, structure or other enclosure where equines are maintained for boarding, holding, training, breeding, riding, pulling vehicles or other similar purposes and a fee is charged for maintaining such equines or for the use of such equines. 
Sterilization. The surgical removal of the reproductive organs of a dog or cat in order to render the animal unable to reproduce. 
(Res. No. 2005-13, 7-5-05) 
Sec. 10-2. - Obstruction, interference or hindrance of duties. 
Whoever knowingly and willfully resists, obstructs or opposes an animal control officer in the lawful discharge of official duties by offering or doing violence to the person of such shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as hereinafter set out in section 10-101 (penalties). 
(Res. No. 2005-13, 7-5-05) 
Secs. 10-3—10-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LIVESTOCK RUNNING AT LARGE OR STRAYING 

Sec. 10-21. - Legislative intent; county livestock pounds. 
(a)  The county board of commissioners has found and declared a necessity for a uniform county livestock law embracing all public roads and property in the county. 
(b)  The county commissioners shall provide, or contract for the provision of, truck transportation, establish and maintain suitable places for the keeping of impounded livestock until sold, redeemed or otherwise disposed. 
(Res. No. 2005-13, 7-5-05) 
Sec. 10-22. - Permitting livestock to run at large or stray; releasing impounded livestock; penalty. 
(a)  No owner shall permit livestock to run at large on public roads or any property not belonging to the owner of the livestock except by permission of the owner of such property. 
(b)  Any owner of livestock who intentionally or knowingly permits livestock to run at large on public roads or property not belonging to the owner, unless by permission of the owner of such property, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. Upon conviction thereof, the owner of the livestock shall be punished as hereinafter set out in section 10-101 (penalties). 
(Res. No. 2005-13, 7-5-05) 
Sec. 10-23. - Impoundment of livestock running at large. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the animal control officer to impound livestock found to be running at large. 
(b)  Owners or operators of farms may also impound livestock. If an owner or operator of a farm impounds livestock, it shall be their duty to notify the owner of such livestock immediately. If the owner of the livestock is unknown and is not determined within three days, the person who impounds the livestock shall notify the animal control officer who shall transport the livestock to a county facility as provided for in section 10-21. The animal control officer shall then follow the procedure set out in this chapter as if the animal control officer had originally impounded such livestock. Owners or operators shall receive the feed and care fee allowed in section 10-30. 
(Res. No. 2005-13, 7-5-05) 
Sec. 10-24. - Caring for an impounded animal. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of any person impounding an animal under section 10-23(b) to make reasonable and proper arrangements to provide the impounded animal with humane care and adequate and necessary veterinary services. 
(b)  Any person impounding an animal under this article or providing care for an impounded animal shall have a lien for the reasonable costs of caring for such animal. Such lien may be foreclosed in any court that is competent to hear civil cases. 
(c)  Any person impounding an animal under this article is authorized to return the animal to its owner: 
(1)  Upon payment by the owner of all costs of impoundment and care; 
(2)  Upon the entry of a consent order; 
(3)  If the impounding entity fails to provide humane care to an animal, commits cruelty to animals, or engages in dog fighting. 
(d)  A consent order shall provide conditions relating to the care and treatment of impounded animals, including, but not limited to: 
(1)  The animal being given humane care and adequate and necessary veterinary services. 
(2)  The animal will not be subjected to cruelty. 
(3)  The owner complying with this article. 
(e)  The provisions of subsection (c) of this section shall not apply to an animal that was an object or instrumentality of a crime nor shall any such animal be returned to the owner without the approval of the prosecuting attorney. An agency having custody of an animal that was seized as an object or instrumentality of a crime may, with the consent of the prosecuting attorney, apply to the court having jurisdiction over the offense for an order authorizing such agency to dispose of the animal prior to trial of the criminal case. 
(Res. No. 2005-13, 7-5-05) 
Sec. 10-25. - Notice of impoundment and sale of livestock. 
(a)  Upon the impoundment of livestock, the animal control officer shall serve a notice of impoundment upon the owner, advising the owner of the location where the livestock is being held, the amount due because of the impounding. The notice shall further state that unless the livestock is redeemed within three days from the date of the notice, the livestock shall be offered for sale. 
(b)  In the event the owner of such livestock is unknown or cannot be found, publishing a notice once in a newspaper of general circulation, Sundays and holidays excluded, shall be service upon the owner. Such notice shall be in substantially the following form: 
"To Whom It May Concern: 
The owner of the following described livestock impounded at ____________ / ____________ / ____________ is hereby notified and the amount due to such impounding is ____________ dollars. 
The livestock will, unless redeemed within three (3) days from the date of this notice, be offered for sale at public auction to the highest bidder for cash. 
Description of livestock:  _____ 

 
(c)  Unless the impounded livestock is redeemed within three days from the date of the notice of impoundment, the animal control officer shall give notice of sale. The sale shall be held not less than five days or more than ten days, excluding Sundays and holidays, from the publication date of the notice of sale. The notice of sale shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation, excluding Sundays and holidays, and by posting a copy of the notice at the courthouse door. Such notice of sale shall be in substantially the following form:
