(a)  The purpose and intent of this section is to preserve and/or create as much natural vegetative environment as possible; therefore, all zones must have a coverage of tree dripline area of no less than 25 percent of the total property area (excluding the area of the building footprint plus 15 feet around the building perimeter). The following requirements shall be met: 
(1)  In areas where substantial tree coverage exist as many trees as possible shall be preserved; however, any individual tree with an eight-inch caliper or larger shall not be removed without prior approval of the planning and design review board regardless of its location on the property. 
Exemption: Pine trees are exempt from this requirement; however, for each three pines (with an eight-inch caliper or larger) that are removed one hardwood tree must be planted, or the provisions of subsection (a) above must be met, whichever provides for the greater tree coverage. 
(2)  In areas where no trees exist, hardwood trees of at least eight feet in height, indigenous to the area must be planted, and which upon maturity will provide the minimum coverage in subsection (a) above. Placement of trees to be planted must be clearly shown on the landscaping plan. 
(b)  Meeting the initial minimum requirements of subsection (a) also requires the proper treatment and protection of trees used to meet this requirement. This means that if any tree used to meet the requirement dies within five years of the approval for development, it must be replaced by a tree of at least eight feet in height and the new tree must meet the same five-year requirement. 
(c)  Not to exclude the use of others which might be approved subject to their meeting the height or growth requirements stated herein, the following plants are approved for this purpose: 

 
(Ord. No. 90-3, § 6(C), 6-19-90; Ord. No. 91-3, 4-16-91; Ord. No. 96-07-02, 8-19-96) 
Sec. 34-254. - Parking regulations. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of parking regulations is to ensure enough off-street parking area so that the street traffic is not impaired, while providing for the orderly flow of traffic. 
(b)  Requirements. 
(1)  The parking area shall be paved according to the following design standards: 
a.  Asphalt. 
Light duty (auto): 
1.  6 inches of graded aggregate base. 
2.  2 inches of type E or F asphalt. 
Heavy duty (trucks): 
1.  6 inches of graded aggregate base. 
2.  2 inches of type B asphalt or plant mix base. 
3.  1½ inches of type E or F asphalt surface. 
All materials and workmanship shall conform to current state DOT specifications. 
b.  Concrete. 
1.  Light duty (auto): 5 inches 3000 # strength. 
2.  Heavy duty (trucks): 8 inches 3000 # strength. 
All materials and workmanship shall conform to current state DOT specifications. 
c.  Alternative paving material will be considered by the planning and design review board, including brick pavers, cobblestones and other suitable materials. 
(2)  Parking space dimensions shall be equal to or greater than: 
a.  Standard space: 9 feet by 19 feet. 
b.  Parallel space: 9 feet by 23 feet. 
c.  Handicapped space: 13 feet by 20 feet. 
d.  Loading space: 10 feet by 50 feet. 
(3)  The width of the interior driveways shall be measured from the back of curb to the back of curb according to the following standards: 
a.  One-way traffic: 12 feet. 
b.  Two-way traffic: 24 feet. 
(c)  Minimum space requirements. 
(1)  Amusement park: one space per hole for miniature golf, one space per every five seats on carnival type rides, and one space per two employees; with a minimum total of 20. 
(2)  Automobile sales and service: one space per every 300 square feet of gross floor area. 
(3)  Apartments (garden or multi): one space per bedroom; minimum two spaces per unit. 
(4)  Churches: one space per four seats in the main assembly area. 
(5)  Clubhouses: one space per 200 square feet of floor area. 
(6)  Commercial entertainment and recreation: one space per 100 square feet of gross floor area. One per every four seats for places of assembly containing fixed seats. 
(7)  Condominium: one space per bedroom; minimum two spaces per unit. 
(8)  Day care centers: 2.5 spaces per classroom. 
(9)  Duplexes: one space per bedroom; minimum two spaces per unit. 
(10)  Gas service station/convenience store: three spaces per service bay with a minimum of eight spaces. 
(11)  Golf courses: two spaces per hole, plus ten for the clubhouse and one for every two employees. 
(12)  Hotel/motel/motor court: one space per unit and one per every two employees. 
(13)  Industrial plant: one space per 200 square feet of gross floor space or one space per every two employees, whichever is greater. 
(14)  Office: one space per 200 square feet. 
(15)  Office/medical: five spaces per practitioner. 
(16)  Residence, single-family: two spaces per unit. 
(17)  Restaurant: one space per every four seats plus one space for every two employees, plus, where drive through service is provided, three spaces per service window. 
(18)  Retail: four spaces per 1,000 square feet of gross floor area. 
(19)  School, primary/elementary: two spaces per classroom. 
(20)  Taverns and clubs: one space per 100 square feet of gross floor area. 
(Ord. No. 90-3, § 7, 6-19-90) 
Sec. 34-255. - Home occupations. 
(a)  Definition. A home occupation is an occupation for gain or support which is customarily conducted at the home, which is incidental to the use of the dwelling unit, which employs not more than two people not residents of the premises, and utilizes not more than 25 percent of the total actual floor area is used for the home occupation purposes. 
(b)  Requirements: 
(1)  No more than two persons, other than members of the family residing on the premises, shall be engaged in such home occupation. 
(2)  The use of the dwelling unit for the home occupation shall be clearly incidental and subordinate to its use for residential purposes, with no more than 25 percent of the total actual floor area of the dwelling unit being used in the conduct of the home occupation. 
(3)  No home occupation shall be conducted in any accessory building. 
(4)  There shall be no change in the outside appearance of the building or premises. 
(5)  Other than one sign, there shall be no visible evidence of the conduct of such home occupation. This sign shall be mounted against the wall of the principal building, shall be nonilluminated, and shall not exceed one square foot in area. 
(6)  No inventory of goods for sale shall be stored or maintained in or about the premises. 
(7)  No traffic, other than that which would normally be expected in a residential neighborhood, shall be generated by the home occupation. 
(8)  No materials, equipment or business vehicles may be stored or parked on the premises, except one business vehicle with a carrying capacity that does not exceed a one-half ton. This vehicle must be used exclusively by the resident and may be parked in the carport, garage, rear yard or side yard. 
(9)  The offsite employees of the home occupation shall not congregate on the premises for any purpose not concerning the business of the home occupation. 
(10)  No equipment or process shall be used in such home occupation which creates noise, vibration, glare, fumes, odors or electrical interference detectable to the normal senses at the lot line of the operation in other than a single-family residence. 
(11)  In the case of electrical interference, no equipment or process shall be used which creates unusual or audible interference in any radio or television receiver off the premises, or cause fluctuations in electrical line wattage off the premises. 
(12)  Home occupations shall be allowed in single family dwelling units, duplexes and townhouses. They shall be prohibited from condominium or apartment developments. 
(Ord. No. 90-3, § 8, 6-19-90) 
Sec. 34-256. - Outdoor holiday lighting. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose and intent of this section is to provide a uniform lighting plan for outdoor holiday lights in the commercial business districts in the city. The city desires to promote tourism, minimize intrusion, and enhance city aesthetics during the holiday season as a matter of public policy. Accordingly, it is the purpose of this chapter to establish community standards for the use of outdoor holiday lighting within the city's commercial business districts which enhance the aesthetics of the city, promote tourism within the city's commercial business districts, provide a uniform appearance for these purposes, delineate a timetable for the use of holiday lighting, establish limits of illumination levels, and provide for energy conservation. 
(b)  Definitions. 
Commercial buildings are defined as including those buildings and all lodging facilities within the C-1, C-2, C-3 and hotel/motel zoning classifications of the city. 
C7 lights are defined as traditional larger holiday lights burning at five watts each. 
LED lights are defined as lights which use a light emitting diode for illumination, rather than a traditional filament. 
(c)  Requirements. Holiday lighting shall comply with the following standards: 
(1)  All commercial buildings within the city limits must comply. Lighting must be either warm white LED lights or C7 clear lamps on SPT1 or SPT 2 wiring. 
(2)  Lamps/Lights must be located every six inches on either green or white wiring. 
(3)  The lights must be operational from each Friday before Thanksgiving through the third weekend of January. 
(4)  Lights must edge the rooflines of the building wherever the building borders a city street. 
(5)  The lighting along the roofline edge is to include the peaks, gables, and other architectural features of the building roof. 
(6)  Lights must be operational from dusk till dawn. 
(Ord. No. 08-11-02, 1-6-09; Ord. No. 09-06-02, 7-21-09) 
Secs. 34-257—34-500. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - LAND DEVELOPMENT ORDINANCE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 34-501. - Title. 
This article shall be known and may be cited as the "Land Development Ordinance of the City of Helen, Georgia." 
(Code 1987, § 14-101) 
Sec. 34-502. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. The words "used" or "occupied" as applied to any land or building shall be construed to include the words "intended, arranged or designed to be used or occupied." Other words are defined as follows: 
Alley means a private or public thoroughfare which affords only a secondary means of access to a building or property and is not intended for general traffic circulation. 
Alteration means any change in the supporting members of a building, any modification or change in construction, any addition which increases the area or height, any change in use or movement of a building from one location to another. 
Building means any structure, either temporary or permanent, above- or belowground, having a roof or other covering, and designed, built, or used as a shelter or enclosure for persons, animals, property of any kind, including tents, awnings or vehicles used for purposes of a building. 
Building line means a line formed by the face of a building, and for the purposes of this article, a minimum building line is the same as a front setback line.F 
Building, principal means a building in which is conducted the main use of the property on which the structure is located. 
Centerline of street means that line surveyed and monumented by the governing body and designated as the center of a public street. If a centerline has not been surveyed, it shall be the line running midway between the outside curbs or ditches of such street. 
Commercial development means any development intended for other than exclusive use as a detached one-family dwelling or accessory building thereto, including but not limited to the following uses: retail, wholesale, general service, public service, manufacturing and any other industrial, agricultural and multifamily dwelling. 
Design standards means criteria that must be followed and implemented as an integral part of a building permit application regarding exterior and interior design characteristics regarding public use facilities, e.g., restaurants, retail shops, motels, etc. These criteria comprise written standards that may be in a textual, graphically illustrated, or photographed format for use in explanation to the applicant of the requirements. 
Enforcement officer means as provided in section 34-26. 
Lot means a parcel of contiguous land in the same ownership which is not divided by any public highway or alley, including any part thereof subject to any easement for any purpose other than a public highway or alley, but excluding any part thereof severed from another lot where severance creates any nonconforming use or structure. 
Lot width means the distance between the side lot lines measured at the front building line. 
Manufactured home means a structure, transportable in one or more sections, which is built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities. The term includes manufactured homes, park trailers, travel trailers and other similar vehicles. See also the definition for "temporary structure." 
Planned unit development. A planned unit development is: 
(1)  Land under unified control, planned and developed as a whole in a single development operation or a programmed series of development operations for dwelling and/or commercial units and related uses and facilities, which includes principal and accessory uses and structures substantially related to the character of the development itself and the surrounding area of which it is a part; 
(2)  Is developed according to comprehensive and detailed plans which include not only streets, utilities and lots, but also other uses and improvements on the land as related to buildings envisioned; and 
(3)  Which includes a program for full provision, maintenance and operation of such areas, improvements, facilities and services as will be for common use by some or all of the occupants of the PUD, but will not be provided, operated or maintained at public expense. 
The minimum land area which may be utilized for a PUD is 15 acres. 
Residential development means any development intended for exclusive use as a detached one-family dwelling or accessory building thereto. 
Structure means anything constructed or erected, the use of which requires more or less permanent location on the ground, or which is attached to something having more or less permanent location on the ground not including utility poles. 
Subdivision means all divisions of a tract or parcel of land into two or more lots, building sites, campsites or other divisions for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of sale, lease, rent or building development, and includes all division of land involving a new street or a change in existing streets, and includes a resubdivision and, where appropriate to the context, relates to the process of subdividing or to the land or area subdivided; provided, however, that the following are not included within this definition: 
(1)  The combination or recombination of position of previously platted lots where the total number of lots is not increased and the resultant lots are equal to the standards of the county. 
(2)  The division of land into parcels of five acres or more where no new street is involved. 
Temporary structure means a structure constructed totally or in part away from the permanent site, which is transportable in nature, eg. trailers, railroad cars and vending carts. See also the definition for "manufactured home." 
Tower means: 
(1)  A building or structure high in proportion to its lateral dimensions, either isolated or forming a part of any building. 
(2)  A tall structure extending far upward. 
Yard means a space on the same lot with a principal building, which is open, unoccupied, and unobstructed by buildings or structures from ground to sky except where encroachments and accessory buildings are expressly permitted. 
Yard, front means an open, unoccupied space on the same lot with a principal building, extending the full width of the lot and situated between the street line and the front line of the building projected to the side lines of the lot. 
Yard, rear means an open, unoccupied space on the same lot with a principal building, extending the full width of the lot and situated between the rear line of the lot and the rear line of the building projected to the side lines of the lot. 
Yard, side means an open, unoccupied space on the same lot with a main building, situated between the building and the side line of the lot and extending from the rear line of the front yard to the front line of the rear yard. 
(Code 1987, § 14-102; Ord. No. 92-7, 12-15-92) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 34-503. - Penalties for violation. 
Any person who violates any provision of this article or any amendment thereto, or who fails to perform any act required hereunder or does any prohibited act, shall be punished as provided in section 1-7. 
(Code 1987, § 14-801) 
Sec. 34-504. - Technical code architectural guidelines adopted by reference. 
City of Helen, Georgia Architectural Guidelines, prepared by Hill Studio, P.C., dated September 27, 1994, as now or hereafter amended or supplemented with approval by the city commission, is adopted by reference, and is on file with the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 96-09-01, 10-31-96) 
Sec. 34-505. - Regulations affect every building and use. 
No building or land shall hereafter be used or occupied and no building or part thereof shall be erected, moved or altered except in conformity with the regulations specified in this article, and without first obtaining permits. In the enforcement of the provisions of this article, the building inspector may withhold building or occupancy permits until all provisions of this article are complied with or his decision is rescinded by the board of appeals. 
(Code 1987, § 14-103) 
Sec. 34-506. - Subdivision of land. 
(a)  No person shall sell, transfer, agree to sell, or negotiate to sell any land by reference to or exhibition on a subdivision plat, or make any other use of a subdivision plat before the streets on such plat have been approved by the planning and design review board of the city and recorded in the office of the clerk of superior court of the county. The description of any land by metes and bounds in the instrument of transfer or other documents shall not exempt the transaction from this article. 
(b)  Any subdivider of land within the city shall submit to the planning and design review board the required plats of the subdivision which shall conform to the requirements of this article. No subdivider shall proceed with any construction work on the proposed subdivision, including the clearing of land, before obtaining approval of the planning and design review board. No building permit shall be issued for and no building or other structure shall be erected or placed on any lot within the city unless the street giving access to the lot upon which said building is proposed to be placed shall have been accepted or opened as, or shall have otherwise received the legal status of a public street prior to that time, or unless such street corresponds in its location and lines with a street shown on a subdivision plat approved by the city commission or on a street plat made and adopted by city commission. Any building erected in violation of this section shall be deemed an unlawful structure, and the building inspector, city attorney or other official designated by the city commission may bring appropriate action to enjoin such erection or cause it to be vacated or removed. 
(Code 1987, § 14-104) 
Sec. 34-507. - Only one principal building on any lot. 
Only one principal building and its customary accessory buildings may hereafter be erected on any lot, except for multifamily buildings and townhouses. This section shall apply to the development of a planned commercial and/or residential development which shall be approved by the planning and design review board. 
(Code 1987, § 14-105) 
Sec. 34-508. - Reduction of lot area prohibited. 
No lot shall be reduced in size so that lot width, yard requirements, or other requirements of this article are not maintained. 
(Code 1987, § 14-106) 
Sec. 34-509. - Remedies. 
In case any building is erected, constructed, reconstructed, altered, repaired, converted or maintained, or any building or land is used in violation of this article, or any street construction is begun in violation of this article, the city manager, the planning and design review board, the building inspector, the city commission or any other person who would be damaged by such violation, in addition to other remedies, may institute an action for injunction, mandamus, or other appropriate action or procedure to prevent the illegal use of buildings or land or to prevent any act which would constitute a violation of this article. 
(Code 1987, § 14-802) 
Sec. 34-510. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 96-09-01, adopted October 31, 1996, amended the Code by repealing § 34-510. Former § 34-510 pertained to amendments and modifications to this article, and derived from the Code of 1987, § 14-701. 
Secs. 34-511—34-525. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 
Subdivision I. - General Provisions 

Sec. 34-526. - Administrative officer. 
The city manager or designee shall administer and enforce the provisions of this article. He shall administer the provisions of this article and shall have all administrative powers in connection therewith which are not specifically assigned to some other officer or body. He shall have no power to vary or waive the requirements of this article. 
(Code 1987, § 14-501) 
Sec. 34-527. - Building permit. 
(a)  Required. No building or other structure shall be erected, moved, extended, enlarged, repaired, painted, or structurally altered, nor shall any excavation or filling of any lot for the construction of any building be commenced until the city manager or designee has issued a building permit for such work. Permits shall be issued and fees charged according to the provisions of the city safety codes. 
(b)  Application. Application to the city manager or designee for a building permit shall be in accordance with the provision of the city building codes and shall be accompanied by site plans in five copies (per the provisions of section 34-576). Any building permit issued shall become invalid 12 months after date of issue subject to renewal upon application to the city manager. 
(c)  Performance bond . In addition to the other requirements of this section, all applications for a permit for a building project in the C-1 or C-2 zoning districts, as described in sections 34-183 and 34-184 of this code, must be accompanied by a performance bond equal to 125 percent of the cost of the project. The performance bond may be submitted in a form acceptable to the city manager or designee with a surety company licensed to do business in the state, to enable the city to complete the project on public and/or private property in the event the contractor or the contractor's insurance company fails to pay for the project's completion. No building permit shall be issued for the C-1 or C-2 zoning districts until such a performance bond has been received. 
(d)  Appeal from denial. If a building permit is denied, the applicant may appeal such denial as such process is provided for in the applicable safety code. If such safety code does not contain an appeal process, the appeal shall go to the board of appeals as provided for in this chapter. 
(Code 1987, §§ 14-502—14-504; Ord. No. 10-04-01, 4-20-10) 
Sec. 34-528. - Certificate of occupancy. 
(a)  A certificate of occupancy issued by the city is required in advance of occupancy or use of any building. A certificate of occupancy, either for the whole or a part of a building, shall be applied for coincidently with the application for a building permit and shall be issued within ten days after the building or structural alteration of the building has been completed in conformity with the provisions of this article and the city building codes. 
(b)  Except as hereinafter provided, upon notification to the city manager, or his designee, by the owner, or the owner's agent, that all construction has been completed in accordance with city ordinance requirements, and in compliance with the plans approved by the planning design and review board, the city manager, or his designee, shall ascertain such completion and compliance and shall, without unreasonable delay, issue an occupancy certificate therefore. 
(c)  A certificate of occupancy shall not be issued unless the proposed use of a building or land conforms to all applicable provisions of the City Code and does not deviate in any material or substantial respect from the plans approved by the planning design and review board. If the certificate of occupancy is denied, the city manager, or his designee, shall, within five days, state in writing the reasons for denial, and the notification of completion shall be deemed withdrawn. 
(d)  Following the denial of an occupancy certificate pursuant to 34-528(c), the owner, or his agent, shall take such action, if any, as he deems appropriate to comply with all City Code requirements and the approved plans, and thereafter, at the convenience of the owner, request a certificate of occupancy, in writing, to the city manager or designee at least five days prior to the next regular meeting of the planning and design review board. The owner, or his agent, shall appear in person at the planning and design review board meeting, at which the request is to be considered, to furnish additional information which the planning and design review board deems necessary in order to make an official recommendation to the city commission concerning the issuance of an occupancy certificate. Any such recommendation shall be in writing, and delivered to the city commission for consideration at their next meeting, and any negative recommendation shall specifically address, by reference to specific City Code provisions and specific reference to approved plans, (or deviations therefrom), why the occupancy certificate should be denied. At the city commission meeting the commission shall consider such request and recommendation and determine whether or not the owner is entitled to a certificate of occupancy. If the determination is to issue a certificate of occupancy, the commission shall direct the city manager to promptly issue such certificate. Should the determination be that the owner is not then entitled to such certificate, the commission then shall advise the owner of the specific reasons for denial. Such decision shall not be tabled or delayed except at the request of the owner. Any failure to address the issue at the city commission meeting, except for a request to table by the owner, shall result in the prompt issuance of the certificate of occupancy. 
(Code 1987, § 14-505; Ord. No. 05-09-02, 9-20-05) 
Sec. 34-529. - Preliminary street approval. 
(a)  Prior to beginning any work on any new street, the developer shall submit to the city manager or designee three copies of a preliminary plan of the proposed street not less than five working days prior to the next meeting of the planning and design review board. The street plans shall be drawn in such detail as to show that all specifications will be met. At a minimum, the plans shall show a horizontal plan, a vertical profile and a typical cross-section plan. 
(b)  The planning and design review board shall review the plan and submit its findings in writing to the city commission. 
(c)  Within 30 days of the date of submittal, the city commission shall: 
(1)  Approve the plan if it meets all requirements of this article; 
(2)  Approve the plan conditional upon specified changes required of the developer to meet all requirements of this article; or 
(3)  Reject the plan for specified written reasons. 
(d)  The action of the city commission shall be placed in writing on a copy of the plan by the city clerk and returned to the developer by the planning and design review board. 
(e)  The rejection of a street plan by the city commission shall not prevent the developer from resubmitting a modified or new plan for a new consideration by the planning and design review board. 
(Code 1987, § 14-506) 
Secs. 34-530—34-550. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Appeals, Variances, Etc. 

Sec. 34-551. - Board of appeals; powers. 
The board of appeals shall have the following powers: 
(1)  To hear and decide when an official allegation is made that there is an error in any order, requirement, decision or determination made by an administrative official in the enforcement of this article. 
(2)  To hear and decide special exceptions to the terms of this article except as to the use of property upon which such board is required to pass under this article. 
(3)  To authorize, upon appeal, such variances, other than uses, from the terms of this article as will not be contrary to the public interest, where owing to special conditions a literal enforcement of the provisions of this article will in an individual case result in practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship. In every case the spirit of this article shall be observed, public safety and welfare secured and substantial justice done. Such variance may be granted in an individual case of practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship upon a finding by the board of appeals that: 
a.  There are extraordinary and exceptional conditions pertaining to the particular piece of property in question because of its size, shape, or topography; 
b.  The application of this article to the particular piece of property would create practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship; 
c.  Such conditions are peculiar to the particular piece of property involved; and 
d.  Relief, if granted, would not cause substantial detriment to the public good or impair the purposes and intent of this article. 
(Code 1987, § 14-606) 
Sec. 34-552. - Conditions for granting variance. 
In order to make a variance permissible, certain conditions shall be shown: 
(1)  There must be a proven hardship. This must be done by showing beyond a doubt the inability to make a reasonable use of the land if the provisions of this article were applied literally. 
(2)  The hardship cannot be self-created. An example is the case where the lot was purchased with knowledge of an existing restriction or claiming hardship in terms of prospective sales. 
(Code 1987, § 14-607) 
Sec. 34-553. - Action on appeal. 
In exercising its power, the board of appeals may, in conformity with the provisions of this article, reverse or affirm, wholly or partly, or may modify the order, requirements, decision or determination, and to that end shall have all powers of the officer from whom the appeal is taken and may issue or direct the issuance of a permit, certificate or other document as required. 
(Code 1987, § 14-608) 
Sec. 34-554. - Appeals. 
(a)  How taken. Appeals to the board of appeals may be taken by any person aggrieved or by any officer, department, board or bureau of the city affected by any decision of the city manager or designee or the planning and design review board made in connection with this article. Such appeals shall be taken within a reasonable time, as provided in the rules of the board, by notifying the officer from whom the appeal is taken and filing with the secretary of the board of appeals a notice of the appeal, specifying the grounds therefor. The officer from whom the appeal is taken shall forthwith transmit to the city clerk all papers constituting the record upon which the action appealed from was taken. 
(b)  Notice of hearing. The board of appeals shall fix a reasonable time for the hearing of the appeal or other matters referred to it, and give public notice thereof, as well as due notice to the parties in interest, and shall decide the same within a reasonable time. Upon a hearing, any party may appear in person, by agent or by attorney. 
(c)  Stay of proceedings; exception. Any appeal stays all legal proceedings in furtherance of the action appealed from, unless the officer from whom the appeal is taken certifies to the board of appeals, after the notice of the appeal shall have been filed, that, by reason of facts stated in the certificate, a stay would in his opinion cause imminent peril to life and property. In such case, a stay will not be issued unless a restraining order is issued by either the board of appeals or a court of record on application, on notice to the officer from whom the appeal is taken, and on due cause shown. 
(Code 1987, §§ 14-603—14-605) 
Secs. 34-555—34-575. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - REQUIREMENTS FOR NEW CONSTRUCTION 

Sec. 34-576. - Design review. 
(a)  All developments within the city require a site analysis, a comprehensive site plan and an architectural design plan. Any design plan for a development estimated to cost in excess of $50,000.00 shall require either an architect or engineer's stamp as appropriate to the project. (On completion of construction of the development, the architect or engineer shall be required to certify compliance with the design plan as approved.) Additionally, developments within areas of special flood hazard require a hydrological study and engineer's certification in conformity with article VI. These initial design requirements must be submitted to the planning and design review board before any permit applications are submitted for approval. 
(b)  A current design review package, available from city hall, shall be obtained and completed, as applicable, before the project is initially presented to the planning and design review board. 
(c)  Design standards shall be followed by an applicant according to the following criteria: 
(1)  Roof. The primary roof of all new structures and any existing structure for which a modification of 50 percent of the existing exterior dimensions in lineal perimeter is planned shall have a minimum roof pitch of no less than six feet of rise per 12 feet of run ( 6/12 pitch). The primary roof shall be covered with red fiberglass shingles. Any towers, bay windows or other adjunct parts of the structure may be covered with red shingles, copper or standing seam metal roofing when approved by the planning and design review board. 
(2)  Exterior and interior trim. The trim of all exterior building surfaces and publicly exposed interior building surfaces is regulated as follows for any new building or a proposed alteration to a building for which a modification of 25 percent of the existing usable square footage or for which an expenditure of more than $10.00 is planned. Trim standards shall meet design motif on all fascia. 
(3)  Glass window surface as a percentage to total exposed wall surface for each building elevation. The permitted maximum percentage of glass window surface in square feet shall be regulated in proportion to the total wall surface of each building elevation plan at the discretion of the planning and design review board. However, in no event shall the permitted maximum percentage of glass window surface exceed 40 percent of the total wall surface. (The total wall surface shall include any area proposed for use as a glass window or door.) 
(4)  Building scale. The scale of all new construction or 50 percent modification to an existing building as may be determined by additions to lineal perimeter distance of the exterior walls may follow a maximum seven-eighths scale to full size ( 7/8 scale) on all front and side exterior elevations. 
(5)  Building contiguity. The application for a building permit shall include a proposed design for the physical connection of the proposed building to any building and each elevation that may be on the same lot or on adjoining lots, whether or not such lots may be owned by the applicant. Such design shall include connections by extended wall lines, connected roof lines, or connected balconies and walkways. The purpose of contiguity is the facilitation of maximum ease in pedestrian access while maintaining a unity in design. 
(6)  Lighting standards. Illuminescence shall be regulated as follows: 
a.  Exterior mounted lights may be of any type except neon. Except for gas lights, all other exterior lights shall be shielded to prevent direct lighting exposure to public view. 
b.  Interior lights may be of any type. Except for gas or kerosene lights, all other interior lights shall be shielded to prevent direct lighting exposure to public view. Additionally, interior neon lights shall not be placed in windows or otherwise displayed so as to be visible from the street, sidewalk or other public rights-of-way. 
c.  The lighting standards referenced in this subsection shall not apply to internally illuminated signage which has been approved by the city in accordance with the requirements of chapter 34, article VII, Signs. 
(7)  Building colors. The exterior colors of buildings shall be one or more of the colors shown on Ace Paint Exterior Colors for Your Life color chart (you may use any manufacturer's paint as long as colors match the approved colors in the referenced color chart). A copy of this color chart is maintained in Helen City Hall. 
(8)  Window and door design. Exterior and interior windows and doors shall be regulated as follows: 
a.  Windows: minimum number of grid sections per installed frame: 4. 
b.  Doors: minimum number of panels per installed frame: 2. 
Prohibited door types: thin rail shutters, sliding partition made from vinyl or similar cloth material, hollow core, solid core single panel (trim can be applied to solid core single panel door to create two or more panel effect). 
(9)  Roof overhang, balcony overhang and portico standards. The overhang of roofs, balconies and porticos shall be regulated as follows: 
a.  Roofs: minimum roof overhang: 36 inches; maximum roof overhang: six feet. 
b.  Balconies: minimum balcony overhang: four feet; maximum balcony overhang: nine feet. Balcony shall be cross-hatched beneath the top rail or filled in an alpine design. 
c.  Minimum portico overhang: two feet; maximum portico overhang: six feet. 
Porticos must be a gable design. Shed roofs are prohibited. 
(10)  HVAC equipment and utility meters. All HVAC equipment, including vents, and utility meters shall be enclosed or otherwise rendered unobtrusive, and be reasonably protected against damage. However, utility meters must be left accessible for servicing and reading. 
(11)  Handicapped accessibility. See section 34-801 for construction standards. 
(12)  Water conservation standards. See section 70-35 for maximum flow rates of plumbing fixtures and trim. 
(13)  General motif. The general motif for commercial developments shall be Alpine design as shown in the city of Helen, Georgia Architectural Guidelines, prepared by Hill Studio, P.C., dated September 27, 1994. 
(Code 1987, § 14-201; Ord. No. 92-7, 12-15-92; Ord. No. 96-09-01, 10-31-96; Ord. No. 08-10-02, 11-18-08; Ord. No. 12-08-01, 9-18-12; Ord. No. 14-01-01, 2-18-14 ) 
Sec. 34-577. - Fire sprinkler systems. 
(a)  Commercial fire sprinklers. All new commercial construction shall be equipped with automatic fire sprinkler systems installed according to National Fire Protection Standard 13, latest edition as adopted by the State of Georgia, where required by NFPA Life Safety Code 101 or Standard Building Code, due to size or use. All other buildings not meeting the NFPA 13 Code criteria may elect to use the Cobb County, Georgia Standard for the installation of sprinkler systems in small commercial buildings as adopted by the City of Helen (reference Appendix A to Ordinance No. 94-02-2), with the exception of the following: 
(1)  Detached unenclosed structures of less than 210 square feet, i.e., pavilion, deck. 
(2)  Detached one-story noncombustible unenclosed covered vehicle storage areas, maintaining a minimum of 30 feet of open separation from any structure, with no storage capabilities and which is less than 1,000 square feet. 
(b)  Multi-family residential fire sprinklers. All new multi-family residential construction of three or more attached units, exclusive of one and two family dwellings, shall be equipped with automatic fire sprinkler systems installed according to the requirement of the National Fire Protection Standard 13R, latest edition as adopted by the State of Georgia, with the same exceptions as found in section 34-577(a)(1) and (2). 
(c)  Maintenance and testing of sprinkler systems. All new and existing sprinkler systems must be maintained and tested annually, according to NFPA Fire Protection Standard 25 or SBCCI Standard Fire Prevention Code Section 603, latest edition as adopted by the State of Georgia, by a sprinkler contractor who holds a certificate of competency issued by the state fire marshal's office. Written notification of the results of annual tests must be forwarded on such forms as the fire marshal may require, to the fire marshal's office within 30 days of the test, with the exception of the following: 
(1)  Systems installed in one and two family dwellings under NFPA 13D regulations. 
(2)  Any time a deficiency is found or reported concerning a sprinkler system, a test or maintenance can be immediately required by the fire chief or fire marshal. 
(Ord. No. 89-13, § 14-204, 1-16-90; Ord. No. 94-02-2, 3-15-94) 
Editor's note— Appendix A, referenced in § 34-577 above, has not been set out at length herein but is on file and available for inspection in the offices of the city. 
Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, ch. 30. 
Sec. 34-578. - Manufactured homes and temporary structures. 
(a)  Manufactured homes and temporary structures of a type which are constructed totally or in part away from the permanent site shall not be situated within the city except as provided hereinbelow: 
(1)  Extreme hardship. 
a.  Acceptable hardships include, but are not limited to, providing temporary housing for convalescence or short-term housing during the construction of permanent housing; and storage of building materials and tools during the construction or renovation of a permanent structure of at least 10,000 square feet. 
b.  Within the abovementioned exceptions, applicants for such housing must submit a statement from a competent medical authority that the convalescent care is required and a statement from the applicant that suitable facilities are not available within a permanent structure on the property in question; or a statement from a building contractor certifying the imminent construction of a conforming structure which will replace the temporary structure. 
c.  The maximum period for the use of any manufactured home and temporary structure to mitigate a hardship shall not exceed 270 days from the issuance of a permit. 
d.  The procedure for applying for such a permit is as follows: 
1.  Submit application for a temporary permit to the planning and design review board with a nonrefundable fee of $250.00. 
2.  Appear at a hearing to review the matter. 
3.  If approval is granted, all applicable permits must be applied for and paid before work commences. All work will be performed subject to city ordinances and regulations. 
(2)  Planned unit development (PUD). 
a.  One manufactured home or temporary structure may be permitted for any approved planned unit development to consist of 50 or more single-family houses, provided that the situation of such manufactured home or temporary structure shall otherwise be deemed a conforming structure for the purposes of this article and provided further that its use at all times shall be exclusively for sales, marketing or other administrative operations on behalf of that approved planned unit development solely. 
b.  The maximum period for the use of any manufactured home or temporary structure as adjunct to development of an approved PUD shall not exceed two years. However, a special temporary permit must be applied for, and be approved by the planning and design review board annually. 
c.  The procedure for applying for such a permit is set forth in subsection (1)d. above. 
(3)  Parking lot attendant weather protection booths: 
a.  One protection shelter shall be allowed per parking lot. 
b.  This structure may be built on site, or off-site and transported to the site. The construction materials shall be wood frame with a stucco texture finished board exterior. The roof shall be gable shaped, with an approved slope, finished with an approved color shingle, and the fascia shall have an approved Alpine designed decorative trim. The corners, doors, and windows shall be framed with a one by four to conform to the Alpine theme. The colors shall conform to the City of Helen color chart. 
c.  The structure shall be anchored to the ground with an approved anchorage system similar to that used for mobile homes. 
d.  The maximum plan size shall be four feet in width and eight feet in length, or have a maximum area of 32 square feet. 
(b)  Existing manufactured homes within the city are excepted from the above provisions only until the present nonconforming unit is vacated or removed from the property. Once such unit is first vacated, the unit must be removed from the property within 30 days. 
(Ord. No. 89-2, § 14-208, 4-18-89; Ord. No. 89-13, § 14-209, 1-16-90; Ord. No. 96-07-02, 8-19-96) 
Sec. 34-579. - Nonconforming uses of land or building. 
The city acknowledges the evolving nature and scope of development within its boundaries, but also recognizes that areas already developed require the full protection of the city to guard against erosion of the highest and best use of any specific property or area. To this end, specific uses of land or buildings which are not compatible with this article or which could create serious obstacles to the public safety and welfare shall not be allowed. The planning and design review board shall be charged with reviewing applications for both building and development permits and business licenses to preclude the encroachment of those uses which are not in the best interest of the growth and prosperity of the city, subject to the review provisions of this article. 
(Code 1987, § 14-209; Ord. No. 89-13, § 14-210, 1-16-90) 
Secs. 34-580—34-625. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS 
Subdivision I. - General Provisions 

Secs. 34-626—34-650. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Streets 

Sec. 34-651. - Streets required to meet standards. 
All streets constructed by land developers in the city following the enactment of the ordinance from which this article is derived shall meet all design and construction standards. The designation of a street by a developer as a private way, or as limited access shall not release the developer from these standards. 
(Code 1987, § 14-301) 
Sec. 34-652. - Plans. 
(a)  Street work performed according to plan. The developer shall construct the street according to the approved plan. Any change from the approved plan or the standards of this article during the construction process shall void the action of the planning and design review board in approval of the preliminary plan, requiring that a new plan be submitted by the developer. 
(b)  Modification of street plan. Should the developer find it necessary, during the construction phase, to change the plan, then he may apply to the planning and design review board for a modification by the same process as stated in this article. The planning and design review board is hereby authorized to modify the plan for a good and sufficient reason, and such reason shall be set out by motion granting the modification. 
(c)  Final approval. 
(1)  Following completion of the construction, upon the posting of a guaranty or surety and upon the submittal of a set of as-built plans conforming with the approved plan and the standards of this article as surveyed by a registered surveyor or civil engineer, the city commission shall approve the street and authorize the city manager or designee to issue building permits for lots abutting the street. 
(2)  Following the approval of the street by the city commission, the city clerk shall note the approval of the street upon four copies of a plat of the street, two copies of which can be recorded in the minutes of the city, one copy to be recorded by the developer in the records of the clerk of court of the county, and one copy to be retained by the developer. 
(Code 1987, §§ 14-507—14-509) 
Sec. 34-653. - Design requirements. 
Streets shall conform to the following design requirements: 
(1)  Minimum right-of-way width: 40 feet. 
(2)  Minimum pavement width: 18 feet subject to the following requirements: 
a.  Streets in developments restricted to single-family residential use: 18 feet excluding curb. 
b.  All other streets: 28 feet, including curb. 
(3)  Minimum cul-de-sac right-of-way: 100 feet diameter. 
(4)  Minimum cul-de-sac pavement width: 80 feet diameter, excluding curb. 
(5)  Minimum alley right-of-way and pavement width: 16 feet. 
(6)  Maximum vertical grade: For lengths of street not exceeding 200 feet: 20 percent if immediately followed by a length of 200 feet with a maximum grade not exceeding ten percent. 
(7)  Minimum vertical grade: 1½ percent. 
(8)  Minimum horizontal radii of centerline curvature: 100 feet. 
(9)  Minimum sidewalk width: 6 feet. 
(Code 1987, § 14-302) 
Sec. 34-654. - Intersections. 
Street intersections shall be as nearly at right angles as possible. No street intersections shall be at an angle of less than 75 degrees. 
(Code 1987, § 14-303) 
Sec. 34-655. - Curbline radii. 
Property lines at street intersections shall be rounded with a curb radius of 20 feet; and where the angle of intersection is greater than 75 degrees, the city commission may require a greater radius. The city commission also may permit comparable cutoffs or chords in place of rounded corners. 
(Code 1987, § 14-304) 
Sec. 34-656. - Slope development. 
Street alignments are subject to performance standards as are appropriate to the city commission and state construction requirements as may be adjusted to any given site limitation. In addition: 
(1)  The street system shall follow parallel contours of the land as closely as possible. 
(2)  Depth of cuts and fills shall be held to a minimum in order to avoid excessive land disturbance. The smallest practical area shall be denuded at any one time during the construction period. Suitable vegetative cover or mulch shall be applied immediately following construction to all denuded areas located on a street right-of-way. Advice from the local soil conservation service field engineer or a qualified soil engineer is recommended. 
(3)  Permanent drainage structures shall be designed for anticipated runoff and be installed in the initial phase of road construction. 
(Code 1987, § 14-305) 
Secs. 34-657—34-665. - Reserved. 
Subdivision III. - Water and Sewers 

Sec. 34-666. - Waiver of requirements. 
The requirements of this subdivision shall not apply if the developer enters into a contract with the city for the installation of water and sewer mains by the city or its subcontractors. The contract shall be drawn according to provisions and standards established by the city. 
(Code 1987, § 14-310) 
Sec. 34-667. - Water supply system. 
(a)  Water mains within the corporate limits of the city must be provided with connections to each lot. Minimum diameter of water pipes shall be six inches, and pipes shall be constructed with ductile iron pipe. All pipes must be of size to maintain adequate pressure in accordance with standards established by the Southeastern Fire Underwriters Association. 
(b)  If a municipal water supply is not available to the development at the time of development, the developer should provide an adequate water source and an adequate water storage facility. This should be accomplished by a community water system. 
(c)  The community water system shall be sanitary and shall have a minimum adverse pressure of 40 pounds per square inch at each lot in the development. 
(d)  The community water system shall be approved by the appropriate health agency; and a letter of approval from the state department of human resources, public health division, or the state department of natural resources, water supply section, as appropriate, shall accompany the recording permit application. 
(Code 1987, § 14-306; Ord. No. 03-05-01, 6-17-03) 
Sec. 34-668. - Water distribution plan. 
A water distribution plan shall be provided by the developer for all developments having a community water supply system. It shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Location and size of water distribution system including pipes, valves, fittings, hydrants, high-pressure pumping equipment, pressure-reducing valves, etc., complete to individual lots. 
(2)  Location and size of all wells, storage tanks and lift stations. 
(3)  A certificate in the exact language set forth below, properly executed by a registered engineer for the developer, shall be attached or affixed to the water distribution plan: 
WATER SUPPLY CERTIFICATION 
State of Georgia, City of Helen 
"The water supply system proposed for (Name of development or subdivision) meets all design requirements for an acceptable water supply system based on the appropriate code of the State of Georgia." 

 
(Code 1987, § 14-307) 
Sec. 34-669. - Sanitary sewers. 
If the sewage disposal facilities cannot be connected to a trunkline sewer at the time of the development of the subdivision, septic tanks or other approved method of sewage treatment shall be installed by and at the expense of the subdivider or lot purchaser for interim use, in conformity with the requirements of the appropriate health agency. 
(Code 1987, § 14-308) 
Sec. 34-670. - Sanitary sewerage plan. 
A sanitary sewerage plan shall be provided by the developer for those developments offering such service and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Location and size of all existing and proposed sewer lines in the development and tie points to other systems. Location of all sewer laterals. 
(2)  Direction of flow of each sewer line and average slope as built. 
(3)  Location of each manhole and other sewerage system appurtenances including lift stations, oxidation ponds and treatment plants. 
(4)  Profile of sewerage system. 
(5)  A certificate in the exact language as set forth below, properly executed, shall be attached to the sanitary sewerage plan. 
SANITARY SEWERAGE SYSTEM CERTIFICATION: 
State of Georgia, City of Helen 
"I, ____________ , a registered engineer, certify that the sanitary sewerage system shown on this drawing is properly designated; meets all local and state specifications; and is adequate both in size and established depth to serve the drainage area whose sewage would normally be carried through this development or subdivision system, whether or not the total area to be served is within this subdivision. It is further certified that the information shown hereon is true and correct." 

 
"I, (Appropriate Official), hereby attest to the fact that this sewerage system and treatment plant is satisfactory and meets all requirements of the State of Georgia." 

 
(Code 1987, § 14-309) 
Subdivision IV. - Sewer System Interceptors[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 06-08-01, adopted September 19, 2006, amended the Code by repealing former subdiv. IV, §§ 34-671—34-673, and adding a new subdiv. IV. Former subdiv. IV pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 05-01-04, adopted February 15, 2003. 

Sec. 34-671. - Purpose. 
Excessive amounts of fats, oils and grease, grit, sand and other solid or viscous materials can cause blockage and obstruction in the sanitary sewer and treatment systems, causing untreated wastewater to overflow into the environment. Much of the waste material that has the potential to cause blockage or obstruction originates from commercial facilities, such as food preparation facilities. This article sets forth minimum and uniform requirements for the treatment and disposal of commercial waste into the sanitary sewer system. The objectives of this article are to minimize the discharge of pollutants associated with commercial waste discharged into the sanitary sewer system that may interfere with normal operation of the system. 
(Ord. No. 06-08-01, 9-19-06) 
Sec. 34-672. - Definitions. 
All terms used in this subdivision shall be interpreted in accordance with the definitions and abbreviations as set forth in this section, or in any other section of this article: 
City means the City of Helen, represented by its elected officials, city manager, or their authorized agent or employees. 
Commercial wastes means: 
(1)  Nontoxic, nonhazardous liquid wastewater from commercial facilities; or 
(2)  Grease interceptor contents generated by a commercial food operation or institutional food preparation facility, including without limitation, fats, grease, and food scraps. 
EPD means the State of Georgia Department of Natural Resources, Environmental Protection Division or its duly authorized representative. 
F.O.G. means fats, oils, and grease. 
F.O.G. separator means a structure or device designed to collect and retain oils, grease, and fatty substances usually found in kitchen or similar wastes. 
Grease interceptor means a structure or device designed to collect and retain oils, grease, and fatty substances usually found in kitchen or similar wastes. 
Grease trap refers to a F.O.G. separator or interceptor. 
Grit trap means a structure or device designed primarily for the accumulation and removal of grit. 
Hazardous waste means any waste that has been defined as a hazardous waste in regulation promulgated by the Rules of Georgia Department of Natural Resources Environmental Protection Division, Chapter 391-3-11. 
mg/L means milligrams per liter. 
Oil-water separator means a structure or device designed primarily to collect and retain oily substances. 
Originator means the owner or operator of the grease or F.O.G. interceptor, grit trap, oil-water separator, or sand trap from which commercial wastes are removed. 
Registration means acceptance by the EPD of a transporter. 
Sand trap means a receptacle designed for the accumulation and removal of sand, grit, rocks and other similar debris. 
Septic waste means the contents of a septic tank. 
User means any person who contributes, causes, or permits the introduction of wastewater into the sanitary sewer system. 
(Ord. No. 06-08-01, 9-19-06) 
Sec. 34-673. - Sand and oil/grease traps. 
(a)  Requirement for. 
(1)  All users involved in the preparation of food for commercial purposes shall provide oil/grease traps. Grease traps shall be designed as appropriate for the size of the facility as specified in subsection (b), below. Additionally, any user who generates a wastewater which contains greater than the quantity of oil and grease than 100 mg/L, and provided that the excess oil and grease is floatable and can be effectively removed in an oil/grease trap, then said user will be required to install an oil/grease trap. 
(2)  All users whose wastewater stream is associated with unusually large quantities of grit, sand or gravel shall be required to install a sand trap. All car/truck wash systems shall be required to install a sand trap; design specifications and calculations must be submitted and approved by the city before installation. 
(3)  No originator may cause or permit any F.O.G. to bypass or avoid the oil/grease trap. 
(4)  The requirements of this ordinance section shall not apply to private living quarters or dwelling units. 
(b)  Design criteria. 
(1)  For restaurants and other eating establishments. 
a.  Required except as provided in c. below. All oil/grease traps used in conjunction with restaurants or other eating establishments shall be a minimum of 1500 gallons and shall have a total volume size to be such to allow one change of contents per 24 hour period. All oil/grease traps must be designed in accordance with Department of Human Resources Public Health, Chapter 290-5-26 Section 12, Grease Traps. 
b.  Required except as provided in c. below. All existing in ground oil/grease traps, for existing eating establishments, must have a filter system installed on the discharge side of the trap. 
c.  Under the counter oil/grease traps are determined to constitute a high risk of failure to prevent F.O.G. from contaminating the public sewer system and are not recommended, and specifically discouraged. However, due to various circumstances existing within the city, all existing and anticipated originators may not be able to provide an in ground oil/grease trap, and therefore, under the counter oil/grease traps will be permitted as hereinafter provided in this subdivision. All such under the counter oil/grease traps must be designed so that they prevent water flow if the trap is filled to capacity and, when filled to capacity the water flow will back up unless the trap is cleaned out. 
d.  All oil/grease traps shall be designed to fully and efficiently function at the maximum daily flow. 
e.  Design details, specifications and calculations must be submitted and approved by the city before installation. 
(c)  Maintenance. 
(1)  All grease, oil and sand traps shall be maintained by the user at their expense, in continuously efficient operation at all times. 
(2)  In the maintaining of grease traps, the owner shall be responsible for the proper removal and disposal by appropriate means of the captured material, and shall maintain records of the dates, and means of disposal, which are subject to review by the city. All manifests or other records of removal shall be provided to the city on a quarterly basis. The frequency of removal shall be such as to ensure that no overflows of oil, grease or sand into the wastewater system ever result. The frequency for maintaining these traps shall, at the minimum, be as follows based on the classifications listed: 
Class I - Food establishments with an under-the-counter trap: Monthly. 
Class II - Food establishments with an in ground oil/grease trap of at least 1,500 gallons and serving less than 100 customers in a 24-hour day, during the highest annual serving 24-hour period: Two times per year. 
Class III - Food establishments with an in ground oil/grease trap of at least 1,500 gallons and serving more than 100 customers but less than 250 customers in a 24-hour day, during the highest annual serving 24-hour period: Four times per year. 
Class IV - Food establishments with an in ground oil/grease trap of at least 1,500 gallons and serving more than 250 customers in a 24-hour day, during the highest annual serving 24-hour period: Monthly. 
(d)  Under the counter oil/grease traps. 
(1)  Under the counter oil/grease traps shall not be permitted in any food establishment using a dishwashing machine. 
(2)  Under the counter oil/grease traps shall be allowed only upon application for an annual permit for an under the under counter oil/grease trap. All such permit applications shall provide such information as required by the application developed by the city manager, and shall contain at least the following: (a) a full and complete description of the under the under counter oil/grease trap; (b) the capacity of the oil/grease trap; (c) the location, and means of access, of the oil/grease trap; (d) the manufacturer's and/or installers recommendations for maintenance of the oil/grease trap; and (e) the expected useful life of the oil/grease trap. 
(e)  Proper disposal of collected materials. A current licensed waste disposal firm must perform any removal and hauling of the collected materials from the sand/oil/grease traps. Under no circumstances shall the collected materials ever be returned to the city's wastewater collection system. It is the responsibility of the originator to provide the city, within ten days of waste disposal firm's manifests showing compliance with the maintenance provisions of oil/grease traps. 
(Ord. No. 06-08-01, 9-19-06) 
Sec. 34-674. - Permits and permit fees. 
In order to identify users, and provide funds for administration and enforcement of this subdivision, all users of sand, oil, or grease traps shall secure an annual permit from the city, and pay an annual fee therefor to the city, simultaneously with the due date of any occupational tax due upon the user's business, as follows: 
(1)  Class I food establishments - $300.00; class II, III, and IV food establishments - $100.00; and sand traps - $100.00. 
(2)  Every user shall fully complete an application for permit as provided by the city and developed by the city manager. 
(3)  All permits shall be valid for the then current calendar year, and are transferable to a subsequent owner/operator at the same location, but are not transferable to a different location. 
(4)  All renewal permit applications shall require only disclosures reflecting changes to the original or previous permit application. 
(Ord. No. 06-08-01, 9-19-06) 
Sec. 34-675. - Enforcement. 
Inspection and entry. Representatives of the city, after proper identification, shall be permitted to enter the premises of any originator, transporter, processor, or disposal site servicing the city's jurisdiction at any reasonable time for the purpose of making inspections to determine compliance with this article or the commercial waste transporter permit. Representatives of the city during inspections of the originator may review records to determine compliance with provisions of these regulations. The right of inspection shall include the right to measure, observe, sample, test, record, review and make copies of all pertinent documents in accordance with this subdivision. 
(Ord. No. 06-08-01, 9-19-06) 
Sec. 34-676. - Violations. 
Upon any violation of any provision of this subdivision, the city may take any or all of the following actions: 
(1)  Discontinue water and sewer service to the offending premises until the problem is rectified to the full satisfaction of the city; 
(2)  Charge a sewer surcharge in the amount of $1,000.00 for each violation; 
(3)  Charge a civil penalty not to exceed $1,000.00 per violation; 
(4)  Apply for appropriate court action to abate or halt such discharge; 
(5)  Pursue any penalty provided in Sec. 1-7 of this Code; or 
(6)  Any combination of the above. 
(Ord. No. 06-08-01, 9-19-06) 
Sec. 34-677. - Severability. 
If any paragraph, subparagraph, sentence, clause, phrase or any portion of this subdivision shall be declared invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, or if the provisions of any part of this subdivision as applied to any particular situation or set of circumstances, shall be declared invalid or unconstitutional, such validity shall not be considered to affect the portions of this subdivision not so held to be invalid, or the application of this subdivision to other circumstances not so held to be invalid. It is hereby declared to be the intent of the city commission to provide for separate and divisible parts, and it does not hereby adopt any and all parts hereof held invalid for any reason. 
(Ord. No. 06-08-01, 9-19-06) 
Sec. 34-678. - Liberal construction. 
It is hereby further provided that any ordinance or law, which may be applicable hereto and aid in carrying out the intent, purpose and provisions hereof, shall be liberally construed to be in favor of the city and is hereby adopted as a part hereof. 
(Ord. No. 06-08-01, 9-19-06) 
Sec. 34-679. - Sewer system interceptors existing prior to October 1, 2006. 
(a)  All under the counter oil/grease traps in existence and use prior to October 1, 2006, and otherwise complying with the provisions of subdivision IV. Sewer system interceptors, may remain in service provided: 
(1)  They now are designed, or will be modified by January 1, 2007, to be designed, to fully and efficiently function at the maximum daily flow; 
(2)  All such under the counter oil/grease traps must be designed, or modified by January 1, 2007, so that they prevent water flow if the trap is filled to capacity and, when filled to capacity the water flow will back up unless the trap is cleaned; 
(3)  All such under the counter oil/grease traps must be designed, or modified by January 1, 2007, so that they utilize a filter which prevents any oil or grease from entering the city sewer system; and 
(4)  There is no increase in seating capacity. 
(b)  All class II, class III, and class IV food establishments with an in ground oil/grease trap of at least 800 gallons in existence and use prior to October 1, 2006, and otherwise complying with the provisions of subdivision IV. Sewer system interceptors, may remain in service provided: 
(1)  They now are designed, or will be modified by January 1, 2007, to be designed, to fully and efficiently function at the maximum daily flow; 
(2)  All such oil/grease traps must be designed, or modified by January 1, 2007, so that they prevent water flow if the trap is filled to capacity and, when filled to capacity the water flow will back up unless the trap is cleaned; all such oil/grease traps must be designed, or modified by January 1, 2007, so that they utilize a filter which prevents any oil or grease from entering the city sewer system; and 
(3)  There is no increase in seating capacity. 
(Ord. No. 06-10-01, 12-5-06) 
Subdivision V. - Rules and Regulations for Water, Sewers, and Sewer System Interceptors 

Sec. 34-680. - City manager authorized and directed to promulgate rules and regulations. 
The city manager shall adopt and publish such rules and regulations for subdivision III and IV of this chapter 34, article IV, division 4, dealing with water, sewers, or sewer system interceptors as may be consistent therewith, and any such rule or regulation shall have the force and effect of law. Any such rules or regulations may be amended, modified, or supplemented by the city manager upon compliance with the requirement of this subdivision. 
(Ord. No. 06-08-02, 8-15-06) 
Sec. 34-681. - Approval of initial rules and regulations. 
The city commission has reviewed and approved, the initial submission of rules and regulations entitled "City of Helen, Water and Sewer Plan Review/Approval Process Manual," dated June, 2006, consisting of: 
(1)  A cover sheet bearing that title, a table of contents therefor, pages 1—8 thereof; 
(2)  A cover sheet bearing the title "Application and Plan Review Process Flow Chart" followed by a single page flowchart; 
(3)  A cover sheet bearing the title "Preliminary Project Information" followed by a single page fill-in-the blanks information sheet; 
(4)  A cover sheet bearing the title "Drinking Water Project Submittal Form" followed by a single page fill-in-the blanks submittal form; 
(5)  A cover sheet bearing the title "Sanitary Sewer Extension Submittal Form" followed by pages 1—4 of a fill-in-the blanks submittal form; 
(6)  A cover sheet bearing the title "Inspection Request Form" followed by a single page fill-in-the blanks request form; 
(7)  A cover sheet bearing the title "Maintenance/Performance Bond" followed by a single page fill-in-the blanks bond form; 
(8)  A cover sheet bearing the title "Sewer or Septic Line Connection Subcontractor Affidavit" followed by a single page fill-in-the blanks affidavit form; 
(9)  A cover sheet bearing the title "Water and Sewer Development Permit" followed by a single page fill-in-the blanks specimen permit; and affidavit form; 
(10)  A cover sheet bearing the title "Certificate of Completion Form" followed by a single page fill-in-the blanks specimen certificate. 
(Ord. No. 06-08-02, 8-15-06) 
Sec. 34-682. - City clerk to maintain and archive rules and regulations. 
All such rules and regulation shall be maintained by the city clerk, as a separate volume, in both printed and electronic media form, and available for review and inspection by the public at all times during business operation at city hall. The city clerk shall, in both print and electronic format, maintain an archive of the initial rules and regulations and any subsequent change thereto, so that it can be conclusively determined the rules and regulations in effect on any date. 
(Ord. No. 06-08-02, 8-15-06) 
Sec. 34-683. - Review by city commission. 
The city commission shall comply with any responsibility for changes to the rules and regulations which may be required pursuant to City Charter, by directing the city manager to make such changes as he or she shall deem appropriate, and present, at a public meeting, such changes for review and comment to the city commission. Unless the city commission, by vote, shall determine that some, or all, of the changes are inappropriate, such changes shall be effective on the fourteenth day following the meeting at which the changes are reviewed and commented upon, (unless a different effective date is stated within the changes themselves or by the commission). Thereafter, the city clerk shall, within 60 days from the effective date of the changes, revise the printed and electronic rules and regulations to reflect the changes; indicate the volume revision; indicate the sections affected by the changes, indicate the effective date of each revision; and provide a publicly available archive of the prior volume 
(Ord. No. 06-08-02, 8-15-06) 
Sec. 34-684. - Penalties. 
Any firm, person, or corporation who shall do anything prohibited by the promulgated rules or regulations, as the same exists or as may hereafter be amended, modified, or supplemented, or who shall fail to do anything required by such rules or regulations, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, amenable to the process of the municipal court of the city, and, upon conviction, shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 or by confinement in the county jail or correctional institution not to exceed 60 days, either fine or confinement, or both, in the discretion of the court. Each and every day that such violation exists shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 06-08-02, 8-15-06; Ord. No. 11-3-03, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 34-685. - City commission retains right to grant variance, amend, void or nullify. 
Nothing herein shall limit the right of the city commission to grant variance from, amend, void, or nullify all or any portion of any rule or regulation. 
(Ord. No. 06-08-02, 8-15-06) 
Secs. 34-686—34-700. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS 

Sec. 34-701. - Performance and specifications. 
Every developer shall be required to make the improvements outlined in this subdivision in accordance with the specifications herein or otherwise adopted by the city. The necessity for storm drainage on each site will be determined by the criteria in article VI. 
(Code 1987, § 14-401) 
Sec. 34-702. - Grading. 
(a)  Generally. All streets, roads, and alleys shall be graded by the developer so that pavement and sidewalks can be constructed to the required cross section. The minimum width of grading shall be the pavement width as specified in section 34-653, plus six feet on each side. Deviation from the above will be allowed only when due to special topographical conditions. 
(b)  Preparation. Before grading is started, that part of the right-of-way consisting of the area to be paved plus the shoulders, shall be first cleared of all stumps, roots, brush, other objectionable materials, and all trees not intended for preservation. 
(c)  Cuts. All tree stumps, boulders and other obstructions shall be removed to a depth of two feet below the subgrade. Rock and fill areas, when encountered, shall be scarified to a depth of 12 inches below the subgrade. 
(d)  Fill. All suitable material from roadway cuts may be used in the construction of fills, approaches, or at other places as needed. Excess materials, including organic materials, soft clays, etc., shall be removed from the roadway. The fill shall be spread in layers not to exceed 12 inches loose and compacted by a sheeps-foot roller. The filling of utility trenches and other places not accessible to the roller shall be mechanically tamped. 
(e)  Subgrade. The subgrade shall be properly shaped, rolled, and uniformly compacted to conform with the lines, grades, and typical cross sections as shown on drawings approved by the planning and design review board. Unsuitable materials shall be excavated and replaced with acceptable compacted material. 
(Code 1987, § 14-402) 
Sec. 34-703. - Storm drainage. 
An adequate drainage system, including necessary open ditches, pipes, culverts, intersectional drains, drop inlets, bridges, etc., shall be provided for the proper drainage of all surface water. Cross-drains shall be provided to accommodate all natural waterflow, and shall be of sufficient length to permit full roadway width and the required slopes. The size of pipe to be provided shall be engineeringly determined by the developer; but in no case shall the pipe diameter be less than 15 inches. 
(Code 1987, § 14-403) 
Sec. 34-704. - Storm drainage plan. 
A storm drainage plan shall be submitted at the preliminary review stage and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Location of proposed drainage ways, streams and sediment ponds within the development. 
(2)  Location, size and invert elevations of proposed drainage structure including culverts, bridges, pipes, drop inlets, and top elevations of headwalls, diversion ditches, etc. 
(3)  Area of land contributing runoff to each drainage feature. 
(4)  Location of easements and rights-of-way for drainage ways and maintenance accesses therefor. 
(5)  Typical improvements around drainage features and culverts, if any. 
(6)  Direction of waterflow throughout the subdivision and computed velocities at those points deemed necessary by the planning and design review board. 
(7)  Detailed engineering drawings on all impoundment structures, dams, sediment ponds, etc. 
(Code 1987, § 14-404) 
Sec. 34-705. - Installation of utilities and driveways. 
After grading is completed and approved and before any base is applied, all of the underground work, water mains, gas mains, etc., and all service connections shall be installed completely and approved throughout the length of the road and across the flat section. All driveways for houses to be built by the developer shall be cut and drained. 
(Code 1987, § 14-405) 
Sec. 34-706. - Street and alley improvements. 
(a)  Curb and gutter required. All streets shall provide curbs and gutters constructed with either precast concrete curb, asphalt curb or integral concrete curb and gutter conforming to the following dimensions or as approved by the planning and design review board: 
(1)  Precast concrete curb: 6 by 18 inches. 
(2)  Miami Roll curbs: 24 inches wide. 
(3)  Asphalt curb: according to state DOT specifications. 
(4)  Integral concrete curb and gutter: cross section as approved by the city manager. 
(b)  Exception to curb and gutter requirement. An exception may be made to the curb and gutter requirement provided the developer furnishes proof satisfactory to the city manager that all road grades and road ditches will be stabilized without use of curb and gutters. In lieu of curb and gutter, the developer may stabilize road ditches by paving or by rock check dams or by methods approved by the city manager. 
(c)  Paving required. All streets must be prepared according to the following methods or by equivalent methods acceptable to the city manager: 
(1)  Base.
