(2)  All burned out bulbs (if the sign falls within the permitted category of illuminated signs which are permitted under section 34-1102 of this chapter) must be replaced. 
(3)  All panels or portions of any sign which are damaged must be replaced. 
(4)  All sign copy shall be maintained securely to the face of the sign, and all missing copy must be replaced. 
(5)  All existing signs must be maintained in good repair, and will be subject to annual examination in accordance with subsection 34-1034(a) of this chapter. 
(6)  All signs shall be designed, constructed, installed and maintained in compliance with the applicable building and electrical codes and in accordance with any applicable state law governing sign placement and sign characteristics. 
Ord. No. 11-06-02, 7-19-11) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 11-06-02, adopted July 19, 2011, deleted the former § 34-1026 and enacted a new § 34-1026 as set out herein. The former § 34-1026 pertained to authority to issue notices, enter premises for enforcement purposes and derived from Ord. No. 05-01-01, 2-15-05. 
Sec. 34-1027. - Legal signs. 
(a)  Any existing and permitted sign which complies with the provisions of this article, and any subsequent amendment hereto, is hereby deemed to be a legal sign. Any proposed alteration to or relocation of such sign shall not be undertaken until the permit required by subdivision II has been issued, unless the proposed alteration is specifically exempt from such permit requirement. 
(b)  Any legal sign which does not comply with the provisions of this article solely due to the enactment of an amendment hereto subsequent to the effective date of this article shall, upon the effective date of such amendment, become a nonconforming sign and subject to the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 05-01-01, 2-15-05) 
Sec. 34-1028. - Nonconforming signs. 
(a)  Any sign erected or existing as of the date of the first reading of the ordinance from which this article is derived, and which has a valid permit from the city, but which does not conform to the provisions of this article is hereby deemed to be a non-conforming sign. A non-conforming sign may be maintained by painting, refinishing, refurbishing, or repairing the sign, or sign structure as it was originally permitted by the city. Any alteration, relocation, replacement, or redesign of a sign other than for the permitted maintenance purposes described above will render the prior permit void, and such sign shall be reclassified as an illegal sign pursuant to section 34-1029. Signs which were non-conforming to the and illegal under the prior ordinance and which do not conform to this Code remain an illegal sign under section 34-1029. 
(b)  Any nonconforming sign may become a legal sign if, after compliance with the provisions of this article, it is brought into conformity. 
(Ord. No. 05-01-01, 2-15-05; Ord. No. 16-06-01 , 6-21-16) 
Sec. 34-1029. - Illegal signs. 
Any sign erected or existing as of the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived which does not have a valid permit from the city, is hereby deemed to be an illegal sign and such sign and the person or persons responsible for such sign shall be subject to the provisions of this article. Signs located on any property annexed into the city after the effective date of this article must conform to the provisions of this article within six months of final annexation date. 
(Ord. No. 05-01-01, 2-15-05) 
Secs. 34-1030, 34-1031. - Reserved. 
Sec. 34-1032. - Impoundment of signs. 
(a)  The city manager and his staff shall have the authority to remove and impound all signs, without notice to the owners thereof, placed within any city street or highway right-of-way. 
(b)  The owner of an impounded sign may recover same upon the payment of $50.00 for each sign prior to the expiration of the ten-day impoundment period. In the event it is not claimed within ten days, the administrator shall have the authority to dispose of such sign. 
(Ord. No. 05-01-01, 2-15-05) 
Sec. 34-1033. - Fees. 
(a)  In order to defray the administrative costs associated with processing permit applications for signs and inspection of signs, a non-refundable application fee of $25.00 shall be paid at the time of sign application. If the application is approved, a fee of $75.00 shall be due for the sign permit, if issued. If a variance request is required to be heard, an additional $50.00 fee shall be due for the application for the requested variance. 
(b)  Temporary permitted signs. Those temporary signs which are required to obtain a permit will be charged an application/permit fee of $25.00. 
(c)  Reinspection fee. If a reinspection of the sign is required after initial installation, a reinspection fee of $25.00 shall be charged. 
(Ord. No. 05-01-01, 2-15-05; Ord. No. 16-06-01 , 6-21-16) 
Sec. 34-1034. - Sign inspection. 
(a)  Existing signs. All commercial signs will be reviewed and inspected annually, concurrent with the city occupation tax certificate. The owner of such sign shall execute an affidavit stating the sign(s) are all in good repair, and file such affidavit with the payment of the occupation tax. 
(b)  New signs. 
(1)  Within ten working days of completion of approved work related to a permitted sign, the permittee or sign contractor shall notify the city manager, or his designee, that such sign is ready for a final inspection. The city manager, or his designee, shall conduct the final inspection for the purpose of verifying that the sign is in compliance with the requirements of the permit and all other provisions of this article. 
(2)  Failure to obtain a satisfactory inspection result shall render the permit invalid, and the applicant shall be required to reapply for a permit or remove the sign or sign structure. 
(Ord. No. 05-01-01, 2-15-05) 
Sec. 34-1035. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 16-06-01 , adopted June 21, 2016, repealed § 34-1035, which pertained to display of decals and derived from Ord. No. 05-01-01, adopted Feb. 15, 2005. 
Secs. 34-1036—34-1050. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Permit 

Sec. 34-1051. - Required; exceptions. 
(a)  Unless specifically exempted by this section, no sign or sign structure shall be erected, displayed, moved, relocated or altered until a permit fee has been paid and a sign permit issued by the planning and design review board. 
(b)  A permit is not required for the following types of signs: 
(1)  An official sign or notice issued by any court, public agency or office. 
(2)  A traffic directional, warning or information sign authorized by any public agency. 
(3)  A private street or road name sign or a traffic directional sign which does not exceed one square foot per sign face. 
(4)  Current real estate signs, not more than one on each road frontage, advertising property for rent, lease, or sale, not to exceed nine square feet per sign face, provided such sign(s) are removed within 30 days of the completion of the advertised transaction. 
(5)  An ingress/egress sign which does not exceed one square foot per sign face. 
(6)  Temporary holiday decorations, which do not contain advertising, provided such decorations are installed no more than 45 days prior to the holiday, and removed not more than ten days following the holiday. 
(7)  Flags which are not utilized for a commercial message and which are maintained in good repair, provided that the flag is either attached to a flagpole mounted in the ground or attached to a structure, and the flagpoles shall conform to the applicable setback restrictions of the zoning district. The location and flagpole must be placed in an area that does not create any traffic safety issue, and shall not exceed the height of the primary structure on the lot. 
(8)  Banners, maintained in good repair, flown for holidays; citywide special events which involve the city as a whole, such as Fasching, Mayfest, and Oktoberfest; or permitted banners for permitted special events. 
(9)  Vehicle signs, if such vehicle is regularly used in the conduct of the business or activity advertised on the vehicle. A vehicle shall not be considered as "regularly used in the conduct of the business or activity" and this permit exemption shall not apply if the vehicle is used primarily, (i) for advertising, or (ii) for the purpose of advertising. 
(10)  Patio Umbrellas. 
(11)  All signs containing non-commercial messages only. However, any temporary sign which does not require a permit because it contains a non-commercial message and which pertains to an event to be concluded on a date certain shall be removed within 14 days after the conclusion of the event. 
(c)  A permit is not required prior to engaging in sign alterations if such alteration involves only: 
(1)  The changing of copy on a permitted changeable copy sign; or 
(2)  The painting or refinishing of the surface of a sign face or sign structure of a permitted sign to keep the appearance of such sign as it existed on the date such sign received a permit. 
(Ord. 05-01-01, 2-15-05; Ord. No. 10-01-03, 1-19-10; Ord. No. 10-08-02, 8-17-10; Ord. No. 11-06-02, 7-19-11; Ord. No. 14-01-01, 2-18-14 ; Ord. No. 16-06-01 , 6-21-16) 
Sec. 34-1052. - Application. 
(a)  Where to apply. Any application for a sign permit shall be submitted to the city manager on a form supplied by the city. 
(b)  Information required. The following information shall be submitted with the application for a sign permit: 
(1)  Name, address, telephone number and city occupation tax license number of sign permittee; 
(2)  Legal description and/or street address of premises or property upon which the sign is to be located; 
(3)  The type of sign for which a permit is being sought; 
(4)  An exact color rendering, to scale, of the proposed sign showing elevations of the sign, and the relationship to other existing adjacent signs. In the case of a freestanding sign, the rendering shall include a site plan showing the sign location and any existing or proposed landscaping which is affected by each sign; 
(5)  If required by the planning and design review board, a copy of stress sheets and calculations indicating that the sign is properly designed for dead load and wind pressure in any direction, as required in chapter 12 of the Standard Building Code as adopted by the city. 
(Ord. No. 05-01-01, 2-15-05) 
Sec. 34-1053. - Determination of board to issue or deny permit. 
Upon compliance with the provisions of this article, the planning and design review board shall issue a permit for such sign or sign structure within 45 days of receipt of a completed permit application. Failure to comply with any provision of this article shall result in a denial of the application. 
(Ord. No. 05-01-01, 2-15-05) 
Sec. 34-1054. - Expiration. 
A sign permit shall be valid for a period of 90 days from the date of its issuance and noted on the permit, unless a 30-day extension is granted for good cause shown by the applicant. Failure to complete approved work related to the permitted sign within such 90-day period shall result in the expiration of the permit. 
(Ord. No. 05-01-01, 2-15-05) 
Sec. 34-1055. - Appeal and variance. 
(a)  Denial of application. In the event of denial by the planning design and review board of a sign permit application, an appeal may be made to the city commission. The applicant may appeal to the city commission for relief based on: 
(1)  Grounds that his sign application met the criteria of the Helen Municipal Code as presented. 
(2)  To request a variance from the Helen Municipal Code. 
(b)  If a variance is requested, the planning design and review board shall deny the application, but make a recommendation to the city commission, based on information submitted by the applicant and review by the city building and zoning inspector, as to whether the city commission should approve a variance request. Variance requests should only be approved in such circumstances where: 
(1)  The property itself, or a building being constructed on said property, results in extraordinary conditions in which a variance is justified because of the size, shape, location, or topography of the property or building. 
(2)  The application of this article to this particular piece of property or building would create an unusual hardship on the applicant. 
(3)  If the size, shape, or location of the building being constructed (or a modification of an existing building) will cause the hardship, the request for a sign application variance must be made as a part of the building permitting process. 
(4)  Variances should not be granted where the extraordinary conditions the applicant relies on are the result of actions of the applicant or the owner of the property. 
The decision of the city commission with regard to variance requests will be a final determination from the city. The city commission shall make a decision on a variance request within 30 days of the recommendation of the planning design and review board. 
(Ord. No. 16-06-01 , 6-21-16) 
Secs. 34-1056—34-1100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - STANDARDS AND REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 34-1101. - Setback from right-of-way, and visual restrictions. 
No portion of a sign or sign structure shall be allowed on any city right-of-way without special approval of the city commission, and not withstanding any other size restrictions, and in addition thereto, neither the sign structure nor sign face may obstruct or impair safe vehicular or pedestrian traffic. 
(Ord. No. 05-01-01, 2-15-05) 
Sec. 34-1102. - Sign illumination. 
(a)  In the non-residential zoning districts, up to one lighted commercial sign which is internally lit or is composed of lighted elements may be permitted and approved. The dimension of the sign face shall not exceed four square feet in the "walking area" of the city; or six square feet in the "driving area" of the city, as those terms are defined in Code section 34-1001. Additionally, hotels, motels, or other rentals providing overnight accommodations may also display one additional illuminated commercial sign which does not exceed seven inches in height. 
(b)  Light sources to illuminate signs shall be shielded from all adjacent residential buildings and streets and shall not be of such brightness to cause glare hazardous to pedestrians or auto drivers or to create a nuisance to adjacent property owners or businesses. 
(Ord. No. 05-01-01, 2-15-05; Ord. No. 14-01-01, 2-18-14 ; Ord. No. 16-06-01 , 6-21-16) 
Sec. 34-1103. - Materials and style. 
(a)  All signs will be constructed of wood or a suitable substitute approved by the planning and design review board. An internally illuminated sign may also be approved by the planning and design review board as authorized in the code. 
(b)  Signs shall not be light-reflecting. 
(c)  Any double-faced sign shall be identical on both faces. 
(d)  Colors shall comply with the applicable city color chart. 
(e)  Business signs shall utilize those fonts approved on the chart shown on City of Helen Font Chart. A copy of this font chart is maintained in Helen City Hall. Due to the physical nature of internally illuminated signage, this font requirement shall not be imposed thereon. 
(Ord. No. 05-01-01, 2-15-05; Ord. No. 12-08-01, 9-18-12; Ord. No. 14-01-01, 2-18-14 ) 
Sec. 34-1104. - Dimensions and quantity. 
The dimensions and quantity of any sign face shall conform with the following: 
(1)  Each individual business in the non-residential zoning districts of the city will be authorized two non-illuminated commercial signs in the following dimensions: Signs in the walking area of the city (as defined in Code section 34-1001) shall not exceed six square feet. Signs in the driving area shall not exceed 24 square feet. 
(2)  Residential developments shall be permitted one freestanding sign, of not more than 32 square feet, at primary vehicle entrance plus one additional sign, of not more than 16 square feet, at any secondary vehicle entrance. 
(3)  Commercial developments, which contain at least 2,500 square feet of heated floor space shall be permitted one freestanding sign per vehicle entrance, with not more than 24 square feet of sign face per sign. 
(4)  Regardless of the permitted square footage for a sign, no sign shall be permitted which has a ratio of height to width; or a ratio of width to height; on the sign face that is greater than 4:1. 
(5)  The area of the "sign face" shall be computed as the area within the smallest rectangle which would enclose the limits of the sign face, regardless of the shape of the sign, and specifically including any material or portions of the sign which form an integral component of the sign face. 
(Ord. 05-01-01, 2-15-05; Ord. No. 09-09-01, 9-15-09; Ord. No. 10-01-01, 1-19-10; Ord. No. 12-05-01, 6-5-12; Ord. No. 14-01-01, 2-18-14 ; Ord. No. 16-06-01 , 6-21-16) 
Sec. 34-1105. - Height. 
The maximum height of any freestanding sign shall not exceed ten feet above the average elevation, (measured along the distance of the road frontage), of the nearest public right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 05-01-01, 2-15-05) 
Sec. 34-1106. - Width. 
The maximum width of the entire sign structure shall not exceed ten feet. 
(Ord. No. 05-01-01, 2-15-05) 
Sec. 34-1107. - Structure size. 
The size of the support structure for any freestanding sign shall not exceed the sign face by more than 100 percent. 
(Ord. No. 05-01-01, 2-15-05) 
Sec. 34-1108. - Freestanding signs; location identified. 
Prior to permitting, the location for a new freestanding sign shall be clearly identified by a white stake extending at least six inches above ground level at each location at which a support footing will be embedded in the ground. 
(Ord. No. 05-01-01, 2-15-05) 
Sec. 34-1109. - Window and wall graphics. 
(a)  Window signs are considered signs for the purposes of this article and must be approved by the planning design and review board. An applicant seeking to utilize window signage shall file a regular permit application with the planning design and review board. Applications shall include a description and/or sketch of the proposed sign and a sketch of the area of the window or door to be used in conjunction with the sign. 
(b)  Window and Wall graphics are not considered signs for the purpose of numerical limitation, but are considered signs for all other purposes within this article, and must also be approved by the planning and design review board. 
(Ord. No. 05-01-01, 2-15-05; Ord. No. 14-01-01, 2-18-14 ) 
Sec. 34-1110. - Off-premises and on-premises directional signs. 
(a)  Off-premises signs, limited to two, not to exceed nine square feet each, are permitted for direction to a business or development where the on-premises signage is not clearly visible to the general public from Main Street or Edelweiss Strasse. 
(b)  On-premises directional signs are permitted where necessary and prudent for reasonable business operations. Such signs are presumed reasonable, necessary, and prudent unless determined otherwise by the planning design and review board, in writing and specifying each incident of unreasonableness or lack of necessity or prudence, with a full narrative explanation supporting such findings. Such signs are absolutely permitted when required by a federal or state agency or the business' insurance carrier. Unless some other criteria is required, then each such sign: 
(1)  Shall not exceed one square foot in size; 
(2)  Lettering not to exceed two inches in height; 
(3)  Lettering color shall contrast with background color; and 
(4)  All sign color shall be compatible with building colors. 
(Ord. No. 05-01-01, 2-15-05; Ord. No. 16-06-01 , 6-21-16) 
Sec. 34-1111. - Temporary commercial signs. 
(a)  Temporary commercial signs as regulated herein means any sign or information transmitting device intended to be erected or displayed for a limited period of time for conveyance of a commercial message. The intent of this section is not to limit or regulate the content of a permitted temporary commercial signs, however, by way of illustrative example, temporary commercial signs could be those related to the initial opening or final closing of a business, signs related to a to a sale or markdown of merchandise or services, or signs related to services or goods offered, as examples thereof. However, these examples are illustrative, rather than required, and the contents and messages contained therein are in no way regulated in this article. All temporary commercial signs will be subject to the permit requirements of this article, unless specifically exempted by Code section 34-1051; and may be permitted in accordance with the following standards. 
(1)  Size requirements. Temporary commercial signs in the "walking area" of the city, as that term is defined in Code section 34-1001, shall not exceed four square feet in size, with the calculation of the size of said sign calculated in the same matter as provided for in Code section 34-1104(5). Temporary signs in the "driving area" of the city, as that term is defined in Code section 34-1001, shall not exceed six square feet in size, with the calculation of the size of said sign calculated in the same matter as provided for in Code section 34-1104(5). 
(2)  Location requirements. Temporary commercial signs shall only be permitted to be located only in the interior of premises and affixed either to the windows or doors of those premises. 
(3)  Time Limits and number of signs. Temporary commercial signs shall be authorized for a maximum of seven days, with no more than two temporary commercial signs permitted at any given time. Such authorized signs shall be removed upon expiration of the approved time. A business must have an interval of 21 days between the uses of temporary commercial signs. No business shall receive more than four permits in any one calendar year under this subsection. 
(b)  Temporary real estate development signs are signs related to the commercial development of, or for the sale of real property. Unless specifically exempted by section 34-1051, a temporary sign is subject to the permit requirements of this article. 
(1)  Temporary Project signs. Signs for work under construction may be erected upon the issuance of a building permit for the construction site and remain during construction. It shall be removed within seven days following the issuance of the certificate of occupancy. 
(2)  Temporary signs announcing the subdivision of land. Temporary signs announcing the subdivision of land may be erected on the land being developed and shall be removed when 100 percent of the development lots are conveyed, or for a term not to exceed six months, whichever comes first. A single equal extension may be permitted by the planning and design review board upon application. 
(3)  Temporary signs advertising sale, rental or lease of property exceeding in size those exempted by Code section 34-1051. Signs permitted and exceeding nine square feet, advertising the sale, rental, or lease of property shall be removed within 30 days following the completion of the transaction advertised, or upon the expiration of six months, whichever comes first. Equal extensions, if necessary, may be permitted by the planning and design review board upon application. 
(Ord. No. 16-06-01 , 6-21-16) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 16-06-01 , adopted June 21, 2016, repealed the former § 34-1111 and enacted a new 34-1111 as set out herein. The former 34-1111 pertained to temporary signs and derived from Ord. No. 05-01-01, adopted Feb. 15, 2005. 
Sec. 34-1112. - Multiple-use shopping, business, office and professional centers; directory signs. 
Directories. Any multiple-use shopping, business, office and professional center or mall shall be allowed to have not more than two directories for individual businesses, provided they meet the following requirements: 
(1)  Information. Signs shall be for directory information purposes only, and shall contain only the businesses located within the multi-use center names designated upon the city occupation tax certificate, with the sign containing the name of the multi-use center atop the pylon with an area not to exceed four times the area of the individual pylon signs. All such signs shall be subject to the permit provisions of this article, however, such individual pylon signs shall not apply to any numerical limitation on signs. 
(2)  Size. The area of the directory shall be proportional to the property business list as determined by the planning design and review board. However, the businesses listed upon such directory must be readable by a person of normal vision from the far traffic lane of the nearest public road or street, and the lettering may not exceed 1 1/3 times readable. 
(3)  Location. Not more than one directory shall be permitted upon any street upon which the multi-use center fronts. 
(4)  Type. All such directories shall be freestanding pylon type signs. 
(Ord. No. 05-01-01, 2-15-05) 
Sec. 34-1113. - Gasoline filling stations. 
(a)  Petroleum products pumps and dispensers shall be permitted to display information required by law and, in addition, the brand name and type of product being dispensed. 
(b)  Premises which dispense retail bulk petroleum products by pump shall display the price per gallon on each pump structure with characters not exceeding six inches in height. 
(c)  Signs permitted under this section shall not apply to any numerical limitation on signs. 
(Ord. No. 05-01-01, 2-15-05) 
Sec. 34-1114. - Display/dispensing machines and apparatuses. 
The location, design and use of outside machines and apparatuses for the display or dispensing of advertising, newspapers, soft drinks, ice, food or other products shall be permitted by the planning and design review board in the same manner as for signs. 
(Ord. No. 05-01-01, 2-15-05) 
Sec. 34-1115. - Other Code required signage criteria. 
Other provisions of the Municipal Code of the city may also address signage criteria and requirements, (i.e. pay parking lots under section 14-165), and the requirements of those provisions are in addition to the requirements of this article, unless those other provisions are inconsistent or contradictory to the provisions of this article. In the event those other provisions are inconsistent or contradictory, those other provision shall apply and prevail only to the extent that they are inconsistent or contradictory. 
(Ord. No. 05-01-01, 2-15-05) 
Sec. 34-1116. - Signs allowed in zoning districts. 
If not otherwise stated, any sign not specifically allowed in a zoning district as provided under this section shall be prohibited in that district, except as otherwise provided for under this article. 
(a)  No signage other than house number, original house designation, street identification number, real estate sign (allowed under section 34-1051), security identification sign, or sign containing a non-commercial message shall be allowed on any residential property in the residential zoning districts in the city. No sign shall be taller than three feet in residential zoning districts. The sign height shall be measured in a vertical plane from ground level to the top of the sign. The level of the ground shall not be altered solely to provide additional sign height. No sign with the total area of each sign face greater than four square feet shall be allowed on any residential property in the city. No signs containing commercial messages shall be allowed on any residential property in the city other than temporary real estate signs as authorized under section 34-1051 and temporary commercial signs as described in paragraph (2) below. 
(1)  For all property located in a residential district, there shall be a total maximum of 12 square feet of sign face per lot. For projecting or double-faced signs each display face shall not be added together in computing the area of the sign face for that sign. 
(2)  A temporary commercial sign utilized by a private owner, with examples of such commerce including yard sale, estate sale, garage sale signs (but with the content to be utilized therein not dictated by this article); and subject to the size, height, and setback restrictions provided elsewhere for signs on residential lots, may be displayed on residential premises where a sale is to be conducted beginning five days before the date of the sale. Said signs must be removed when the sale is terminated. The governing authority considers such sales to be a part of the incidental occupation of the residential property and permissible limited commercial sign activity under this section. 
(b)  The following signs shall be allowed within the nonresidential zoning districts in the city: 
(1)  Signs allowed in a residential district. 
(2)  Commercial signs which have met the size requirements of sections 34-1104—34-1106 of this chapter, as well as all other requirements contained herein. 
(3)  Temporary on-premises signs, including banners, when said signs are related to a special event of a noncommercial nature, provided the area of each sign face shall not exceed 16 square feet. Such signs shall be permitted for a maximum of ten days, and such sign shall be removed upon expiration of the approved time, or the business or person displaying such sign shall be subject to citation under this article. No business may display more than one of these signs at any given time. 
(Ord. No. 11-06-02, 7-19-11; Ord. No. 16-06-01 , 6-21-16) 
Sec. 34-1117. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 16-06-01 , adopted June 21, 2016, repealed § 34-1117, which pertained to restaurant outdoor banners and derived from Ord. No. 12-09-02, adopted Sept. 18, 2012. 
Sec. 34-1118. - Standards and requirements for shadow box signs. 
(a)  Purpose. As defined in section 34-1001 of the code, shadow box means a sign utilized for menus by restaurants who offer prepared food on site and beverage as their primary business purpose. Shadow box signage under section 34-1118 is limited to these establishments. This type of shadow box signage is in addition to other types of signage permitted under this chapter. 
(b)  Shadow box structure. The shadow box structure must be approved in the same manner proscribed in this chapter for all other signage. The maximum size of the shadow box shall have a maximum content area of 24 inches wide by 24-inch height and constructed of a material approved by the planning design and review board. Decorative trim with a maximum width of four inches shall be required. A roof shall be required for the shadow box with a 12/12 pitch. The face of the shadow box shall have an impact resistant (Plexiglass; lexan, or other approved material); with a hinged and lockable door. The shadow box must be located on the property in such a manner that it does not impede foot or vehicular traffic. Once the structure is approved, the menu contained within the shadow box may be changed as the establishment may desire. However, the menu displayed within the shadow box shall be of white or a neutral color, and the content therein shall be maintained by the establishment. 
(c)  Quantity. Each business shall be allowed one shadow box sign per entrance to the licensed restaurant, with a maximum of two. 
(Ord. No. 13-06-03, 7-16-13; Ord. No. 14-07-01, 7-15-14 ) 
Secs. 34-1119—34-1200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - UNSAFE BUILDINGS[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 96-08-02, adopted September 17, 1996, amended the Code by repealing former §§ 34-1202—34-1207, and amended § 34-1201. Former §§ 34-1202—34-1207 pertained to unsafe buildings, and derived from Ord. No. 87-8, adopted December 8, 1987. 
Cross reference— Nuisances, § 26-51 et seq. 
State Law reference— Unfit buildings or structures, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-7 et seq. 

Sec. 34-1201. - Authority to enforce provisions. 
Pursuant to the provisions of O.C.G.A. 41-2-9(b), the city is hereby authorized to adopt ordinances relating to the dwellings, buildings, or structures within such municipality which are unfit for human habitation or commercial, industrial, or business uses, in accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. 41-2-7 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 96-08-02, 9-17-96) 
Sec. 34-1202. - Incorporation of provisions of O.C.G.A. 
Any and all definitions applicable to, and any and all authority granted to municipalities, pursuant to the provisions of O.C.G.A. 41-2-7 through 41-2-17, (as same may be amended by Georgia Laws), are incorporated herein by reference verbatim, and such authority may be exercised by the city or its designated official pursuant to the provisions thereof. In the event any provisions of the ordinances of the city conflict with the provisions of O.C.G.A. 41-2-7 et seq., such ordinances shall not be deemed unenforceable in their entirety, but any such ordinance, (or applicable part[s] thereof), shall yield to provisions of O.C.G.A. 41-2-7 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 96-08-03, 9-17-96) 
Sec. 34-1203. - Designation of building inspector to exercise powers. 
The building inspector of the city and his/her successors in office shall be the public officer designated and appointed to exercise the powers prescribed by this article. 
(Ord. No. 96-08-03, 9-17-96) 
Sec. 34-1204. - Complaint, notices, hearings, orders, costs, liens and collections. 
(a)  Whenever a request is filed with the building inspector by a public authority or by at least five residents of the city charging that any dwelling, building, or structure is unfit for human habitation or for commercial, industrial, or business use or whenever it appears to the building inspector, (from his own motion), that any dwelling, building, or structure is unfit for human habitation or is unfit for its current commercial, industrial, or business use or is vacant, dilapidated, and being used in connection with the commission of drug crimes, the building inspector shall, if his preliminary investigation discloses a basis for such charges, issue and cause to be served upon the owner of and any parties in interest in such dwelling, buildings, or structure a complaint stating the charges in that respect and containing a notice that a hearing will be held before the building inspector, (or his designated agent), at a place within the city, fixed not less than ten days nor more than 30 days after the serving of said complaint; that the owner and any parties in interest shall be given the right to file an answer to the complaint and to appear in person, or otherwise, and give testimony at the place and time fixed in the complaint; and that the rules of evidence prevailing in courts of law or equity shall not be controlling in hearings before the building inspector. 
(b)  If, after such notice and hearing, the building inspector determines that the dwelling, building, or structure under consideration is unfit for human habitation or is unfit for its current commercial, industrial, or business use or is vacant, dilapidated, and being used in connection with the commission of drug crimes, he shall state in writing his findings of fact in support of such determination and shall issue and caused to be served upon the owner and parties in interest thereof an order: 
(1)  If the repair, alteration, or improvement of the said dwelling, building, or structure can be made at a reasonable cost in relation to the value of the dwelling, building, or structure, requiring the owner or parties in interest, within the time specified in the order, to repair, alter, or improve such dwelling, building, or structure so as to render it fit for human habitation or for current commercial, industrial, or business use or to vacate and close the dwelling, building, or structure as a human habitation; or 
(2)  If the repair, alteration, or improvement of the said dwelling, building, or structure cannot be made at a reasonable cost in relation to the value of the dwelling, building, or structure, requiring the owner or parties in interest, within the time specified in the order, to remove or demolish dwelling, building, or structure. 
In no event shall the city commission require removal or demolition of any dwelling, building, or structure except upon a finding that the cost of repair, alteration, or improvement thereof exceeds one- half the value such dwelling, building, or structure will have when repaired to satisfy the minimum requirements of this article. 
(c)  If the owner or parties in interest fail to comply with an order to vacate and close or demolish the dwelling, building, or structure, the building inspector may cause such dwelling, building, or structure to be repaired, altered, or improved or the [dwelling, building or structure] be vacated and closed or demolished; and that building inspector may cause to be posted on the main entrance of any building, dwelling, or structure so closed a placard with the following words: 
"This building is unfit for human habitation or commercial, industrial, or business use; the use or occupation of this building for human habitation or for commercial, industrial, or business use is prohibited and unlawful. 
(d)  If the owner or parties in interest fail to comply with an order to remove or demolish the dwelling, building, or structure, the building inspector may cause such dwelling, building, or structure to be removed or demolished; provided, however, that the duties of the building inspector, set forth in paragraph (c) and this paragraph, shall not be exercised until the city commission shall have by ordinance ordered the building inspector to proceed to effectuate the purpose of Article VIII with respect to the particular property or properties which the building inspector shall have found to be unfit for human habitation or unfit for its current commercial, industrial, or business use, which property or properties shall be described in the ordinance; 
(e)  The amount of the cost of such vacating and closing or removal or demolition by the building inspector shall be a lien against the real property upon which such cost was incurred. Said lien shall attach to the real property upon the payment of all costs of demolition by the city and the filing of an itemized statement of the total sum of said costs by the building inspector in the office of the clerk of the city upon a lien docket maintained by the clerk for such purposes. If the dwelling, building, or structure is removed or demolished by the building inspector, he shall sell the materials of such dwellings, buildings, or structures and shall credit the proceeds of such sale against the cost of the removal or demolition and any balance remaining shall be deposited in the superior court by the building inspector, shall be secured in such manner as may be directed by such court, and shall be disbursed by such court to the persons found to be entitled thereto by final order or decree of such court. Nothing herein shall be construed to impair or limit in any way the power of the city to define and declare nuisances and to cause the removal or abatement by summary proceedings or otherwise. 
(f)  The city may enforce the collection of any amount due on such lien for removal or demolition of dwellings, buildings, or structures only in the following manner: 
(1)  The owner or parties in interest shall be allowed to satisfy the amount due on such lien by paying to the city, within 30 days after the perfection of said lien, a sum of money equal to 25 percent of the total amount due and by further paying to the city the remaining balance due on such lien, together with interest at the rate of seven percent per annum, in three equal annual payments, each of which shall become due and payable on the anniversary date of the initial payment made as hereinabove prescribed; 
(2)  Should the property upon which such lien is perfected be sold, transferred, or conveyed by the owner or parties in interest at any time prior to the termination of the said three-year period, then the entire balance due on such lien shall be due and payable to the city; and 
(3)  Should the amount due on such lien, or any portion thereof, be unpaid after the passage of said 3 year period, or upon the occurrence of the contingency provided for in subparagraph (2) above, the City may enforce the collection of any amount due on such lien for alteration, repair, removal, or demolition of dwellings, buildings, or structures in the same manner as provided in O.C.G.A. 48-5-358 and other applicable state statutes. This procedure shall be subject to the right of redemption by any person having and right, title, or interest in or lien upon said property, all as provided by Article 3 of Chapter 4 of Title 48, Official Code of Georgia. 
(Ord. No. 96-08-03, 9-17-96) 
Sec. 34-1205. - Determination by building inspector. 
(a)  The building inspector may determine, under existing ordinances, that a dwelling, building, or structure is unfit for human habitation or is unfit for its current commercial, industrial, or business use if he finds that conditions exist in such building, dwelling, or structure which are dangerous or injurious to the health, safety, or morals of the occupants of such dwelling, building, or structure; of the occupants of neighborhood dwellings, buildings, or structures; or of other residents of the city. Such conditions may include the following (without limiting the generality of the foregoing): 
(1)  Defects therein increasing the hazards of fire, accidents, or other calamities; 
(2)  Lack of adequate ventilation, light, or sanitary facilities; 
(3)  Dilapidation; 
(4)  Disrepair; 
(5)  Structural defects; and 
(6)  Uncleanliness. 
(b)  The building inspector may determine, under existing ordinances, that a dwelling, building, or structure is vacant, dilapidated, and being used in connection with the commission of drug crimes upon the personal observation or report of a law enforcement agency and evidence of drug crimes being committed. 
(Ord. No. 96-08-03, 9-17-96) 
Sec. 34-1206. - Additional powers of building inspector. 
The building inspector is authorized to exercise such powers as may be necessary or convenient to carry out and effectuate the purpose and provisions of this article, including, without limitation, the following: 
(1)  To investigate the dwelling conditions in the city in order to determine which dwellings, buildings, or structures therein are unfit for human habitation or are unfit for current commercial, industrial, or business use or are vacant, dilapidated, and being used in connection with the commission of drug crimes; 
(2)  To administer oaths and affirmations, to examine witnesses, and to receive evidence; 
(3)  To enter upon premises for the purpose of making examinations; provided, however, that such entries shall be made in such manner as to cause the least possible inconvenience to the persons in possession; 
(4)  To appoint and fix the duties of such officer, agents, and employees as he deems necessary to carry out the purposes of the ordinances; and 
(5)  To delegate any of his functions and powers under this article to such officers and agents as he may designate. 
(Ord. No. 96-08-03, 9-17-96) 
Sec. 34-1207. - Service of complaint or orders. 
(a)  Complaints or orders issued by the building inspector pursuant to this article shall, in all cases, be served upon each person in possession of said property, each owner, and each party in interest; and the return of service signed by the building inspector or his agent or an affidavit of service executed by any citizen of this state, reciting that a copy of such complaint or orders was served upon each person in possession of said property, each owner, and each party in interest personally or by leaving such copy at the place of his residence, shall be sufficient evidence as to the service of such person in possession, owner, and party in interest. 
(b)  If any of the owners and parties in interest shall reside out of the city, service shall be perfected by causing a copy of such complaint or orders to be served upon such party or parties by the sheriff or any lawful deputy of the county of the residence of such party or parties or such service may be made by any citizen; and the return of such sheriff or lawful deputy or the affidavit of such citizen that such party or parties were served either personally or by leaving a copy of the complaint or orders at the residence shall be conclusive as to such service. 
(c)  Nonresidents of the state shall be served by posting a copy of such complaint or orders in a conspicuous place on premises affected by the complaint or orders. Where the address of such nonresidents is known, a copy of such complaint or orders shall be mailed to them by registered or certified mail. 
(d)  In the event either the owner or any party in interest is a minor or an insane person or person laboring under disabilities, the guardian or other personal representative of such person shall be served and if such guardian or personal representative resides outside the city or is a nonresident, he shall be served as provided for in subsection (c) above. If such minor or insane person or persons laboring under disabilities has no guardian or personal representative or in the event such minor or insane person lives outside the city or is a nonresident, service shall be perfected by serving such minor or insane person personally or by leaving a copy at the place of his residence which shall be sufficient evidence as to the service of such person or persons; in the case of other persons who live outside of the city, or are nonresidents, service shall be perfected by serving the judge of the probate court of the county wherein such property is located who shall stand in the place of and protect the rights of such minor or insane person or appoint a guardian ad litem for such person. 
(e)  In the event the whereabouts of any owner or party in interest is unknown and the same cannot be ascertained by the building inspector in the exercise of reasonable diligence and the building inspector shall make an affidavit to that effect, then the service of such complaint or order upon such persons shall be made in the same manner as provided in subsection (c) above or service may be perfected upon any person, firm, or corporation holding itself out as an agent for the property involved. 
(f)  A copy of such complaint or orders shall also be filed in the proper office or offices for the filing of lis pendens notice in the county in which the dwelling, building, or structure is located and such filing of the complaint or orders shall have the same force and effect as other lis pendens notices provided by law. Any such complaint or orders or an appropriate lis pendens notice may contain a statement that a lien may arise against the describe property and that an itemized statement of such lien is maintained on a lien docket maintained by the clerk of the city. 
(Ord. No. 96-08-03, 9-17-96) 
Sec. 34-1208. - Injunctions. 
Any person affected by an order issued by the building inspector may petition to the superior court for an injunction restraining the building inspector from carrying out the provisions of the order and the court may, upon such petition, issue a temporary injunction restraining the building inspector pending the final disposition of the cause; provided, however, that such person shall present such petition to the court within 15 days of the posting and service of the order of the building inspector. De novo hearings shall be had by the court on petitions within 20 days. The court shall hear and determine the issues raised and shall enter such final order or decree as law and justice may require; provided, however, that it shall not be necessary to file bond in any amount before obtaining a temporary injunction under this article. 
(Ord. No. 96-08-03, 9-17-96) 
Sec. 34-1209. - Eminent domain; police power. 
Nothing herein shall be construed as preventing the owner or owners of any property from receiving just compensation for the taking of such property by the poser of eminent domain under the laws of this state nor as permitting any property to be condemned or destroyed except in accordance with the police power of this state. 
(Ord. No. 96-08-03, 9-17-96) 
Sec. 34-1210. - Use of revenues, grants and donations. 
The city is authorized to make such appropriations from its revenues as it may deem necessary and may accept and apply grants or donations to assist it in carrying out the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 96-08-03, 9-17-96) 
Sec. 34-1211. - Construction. 
Nothing herein shall be construed to abrogate or impair the powers of the courts or of any department of the city to enforce any provisions of its local enabling act, its Charter, or its ordinances or regulations nor to prevent or punish violations thereof; and the powers conferred by this article shall be in addition to and supplemental to the powers conferred by any other law or ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 96-08-03, 9-17-96) 
Chapter 35 - STANDARDS FOR TELECOMMUNICATIONS ANTENNAE AND TOWERS 

Sec. 35-1. - Short title. 
This chapter will be known as the "Standards for Telecommunications Antennae and Towers" 
( Ord. No. 13-11-01, 11-19-13 ) 
Sec. 35-2. - Definitions. 
As used in this article, the following terms shall have the meanings indicated: 
Antenna means any exterior apparatus designed for the sending and/or receiving of electromagnetic waves for telephonic, radio, television, or personal wireless services. For the purposes of this article the term "antenna" does not include any tower and antenna under 70 feet in total height which is owned and operated by an amateur radio operator licensed by the Federal Communications Commission, any device designed for over-the-air reception of radio or television broadcast signals, multi-channel multi-point distribution service or direct broadcast satellite service, or any cable television head end or hub towers and antennae used solely for cable television services. 
Director means the city manager or his/her designee. 
Governing body means the board of commissioners of the City of Helen. For the purpose of this chapter, the words "city" and "governing body" are one and the same. 
Microtelecommunications facilities are those which are located on existing buildings, poles or other existing support structures where antennae do not project more than 20 feet above the top of the structure and there are no more than six antennae per site. 
Monopole tower means a telecommunications tower consisting of a single pole, constructed without guy wires or ground anchors. 
Telecommunications facilities refers to antennae and towers, either individually or together. 
Tower means a structure, such as a lattice tower, guy tower, or monopole constructed as a free-standing structure or in association with a building, other permanent structure or equipment, on which is located one or more antennae intended for transmitting or receiving analog, digital, microwave, cellular, telephone, personal wireless service or similar forms of electronic communication. The term includes microwave towers, common carrier towers, and cellular telephone towers. 
Whip antenna means a flexible, vertical rod, or radio antenna that would bend without breaking. 
( Ord. No. 13-11-01, 11-19-13 ) 
Sec. 35-3. - Scope and exclusions. 
This article shall apply to any telecommunications facility construction, erection, maintenance/renovation, or upgrade activity undertaken in the City of Helen by any person(s) or entity except for the following: 
(1)  Any tower and antenna under 70 feet in total height which is owned and operated by an amateur radio operator licensed by the Federal Communications Commission, provided, however, that the construction of any tower is not located within 200 feet of any waterway. 
(2)  Any tower or antennae owned and operated by the city for the safety of its citizens. 
( Ord. No. 13-11-01, 11-19-13 ) 
Sec. 35-4. - Design requirements. 
General requirements for all telecommunications facilities set forth in this section shall govern the location and construction of all telecommunications facilities addressed by this article. 
(1)  Height. No telecommunications facility shall exceed 200 feet in total height. 
(2)  Building codes and safety standards. To ensure the structural integrity of telecommunications facilities, the owner of a telecommunications facility shall ensure that it is designed, constructed, and maintained in compliance with standards contained in applicable building codes and the applicable standards for such telecommunications facilities, as amended from time to time. Owners of telecommunications facilities shall conduct periodic inspections of such facilities at least once every year to ensure structural integrity. Inspections shall be conducted by a qualified, independent engineer licensed to practice in the state. The results of such inspection shall be provided to the director. 
(3)  Regulatory compliance. 
a.  All telecommunications facilities must meet or exceed current standards and regulations of the FAA, the FCC and any other agency of the state or federal government with the authority to regulate telecommunications facilities. If such standards and regulations are changed then the owners of the telecommunications facilities governed by this article shall bring such telecommunications facilities into compliance with such revised standards and regulations within the date established by the agency promulgating the standards or regulations. 
b.  Owners of telecommunications facilities shall provide documentation showing that each telecommunications facility is in compliance with all applicable federal and state requirements. Evidence of compliance must be submitted every 12 months. 
(4)  Security. All telecommunications facilities shall be equipped with an appropriate anti-climbing device or other similar protective device to prevent unauthorized access to the telecommunications facility. 
(5)  Lighting. No illumination is permitted on telecommunications facilities unless required by the FCC, FAA or other state or federal agency of competent jurisdiction or unless necessary for air traffic safety. If lighting is required or necessary, the director may review the available lighting alternatives and approve the design that would cause the least disturbance to the surrounding uses and views. 
(6)  Advertising. No advertising is permitted on telecommunications facilities. 
(7)  Visual impact. 
a.  Telecommunications facilities shall either maintain a galvanized steel finish or, subject to any applicable standards of the FAA or other applicable federal or state agency, be painted a neutral color or painted and/or textured to match the existing structure so as to reduce visual obtrusiveness. 
b.  If an antenna is installed on a structure other than a tower, the antenna and associated electrical and mechanical equipment must be of a neutral color that is identical to, or closely compatible with, the color of the supporting structure so as to make the antenna and related equipment as visually unobtrusive as possible. Roof-mounted antennas shall be made visually unobtrusive by screening to match existing air conditioning units, stairs, elevator towers or other background. 
c.  Where feasible, telecommunications facilities should be placed directly above, below or incorporated with vertical design elements of a building to help in camouflaging. 
d.  Telecommunications facilities shall not be placed in a direct line of sight with historic or scenic view corridors as designated by the governing body or by any state or federal law or agency. 
e.  Any equipment shelter or cabinet that supports telecommunications facilities must be concealed from public view or made compatible with the architecture of the surrounding structures or placed underground. Equipment shelters or cabinets shall be screened from public view by using landscaping or materials and colors consistent with the surrounding backdrop. The shelter or cabinet must be regularly maintained. 
(8)  Landscaping. 
a.  Landscaping shall be used to effectively screen the view of the telecommunications facility from adjacent public way, public property and residential property. 
b.  Native vegetation on the site shall be preserved to the greatest practical extent and disturbance of the existing topography shall be minimized. The applicant shall provide a site plan showing existing significant vegetation to be removed and vegetation to be replanted to replace that lost. 
c.  The director may waive or modify the landscaping requirement where lesser requirements are desirable for adequate visibility for security purposes, for continued operation of existing bona fide agricultural or forest uses such as farms, nurseries and tree farms or where an antenna is placed on an existing structure. In certain locations where the visual impact of the tower would be minimal, the landscaping requirement may be modified or waived by the director. 
(9)  Maintenance impacts. Equipment at a transmission facility shall be automated to the greatest extent possible to reduce traffic and congestion. Where the site abuts or has access to a collector or local street, access for maintenance vehicles shall be exclusively by means of the collector or local street. 
(10)  Principal, accessory and joint uses. 
a.  Accessory structures used in direct support of a telecommunications facility shall be allowed but may not be used for offices, vehicle storage or other outdoor storage. Mobile or immobile equipment not used in direct support of a telecommunications facility shall not be stored or parked on the site of the telecommunications facility. 
b.  Telecommunications facilities may be located on sites containing another principal use in the same buildable area providing all other requirements of these regulations are met. 
(11)  Lot size and setbacks. 
a.  All property necessary to satisfy setback requirements covering the total height of the tower shall be under the ownership or control of the applicant. The requirements for control may be satisfied by lease or rent. 
b.  Telecommunication towers must be set back a distance equal to the total height of the tower from any adjacent property line as measured radially from the base of the tower to the property line of the subject property. 
c.  The following setback requirements shall apply to all telecommunications facilities, provided, however, that the director may reduce the standard setback requirements of this section if the goals of this article would be better served thereby. 
1.  Telecommunications towers must be set back a distance equal to the height of the tower from any off-site residential and non-residential structures. 
2.  Towers, guy wires and accessory facilities must satisfy the minimum building setback requirements. 
d.  For antennas attached to the roof or a supporting structure on a rooftop, a 1:1 setback ration (example: ten-foot high antenna and supporting structure requires ten-foot setback from edge of roof) shall be maintained unless an alternative placement is shown to reduce visual impact. 
(12)  Additional requirements for towers. 
a.  Site location and development shall preserve the preexisting character of the surrounding buildings and land as much as possible. Personal wireless telecommunication towers shall be integrated through location and design to blend in with existing characteristics of the site to the extent practical. 
b.  At a tower site the design of the buildings and related structures shall, to the extent possible, use materials, colors, textures, screening, and landscaping that will blend the tower and related facilities to the natural setting and built environment. 
c.  Towers shall not be sited where they will negatively affect any historic or scenic view corridors as designated by the governing body or any state or federal law or agency or where they will create visual clutter. 
d.  Towers shall be enclosed by decay-resistant security fencing not less than six feet in height and shall be equipped with an appropriate anti-climbing device or other similar protective device designed to prevent tower access. 
e.  Placement of more than one tower on a lot shall be permitted, provided all setback, design and landscape requirements are met as to each tower. Structures may be located as close to each other as technically feasible, provided tower failure characteristics of the towers on the site will not lead to multiple failures in the event that one fails. 
( Ord. No. 13-11-01, 11-19-13 ) 
Sec. 35-5. - Application procedure and compliance with conditional use process. 
(a)  General application requirements for all building and other use permits. Application for a building, erection, maintenance/renovation, or upgrade activity permit for any telecommunications facility shall be made to the City of Helen by the person, company or organization that will own and operate the telecommunications facility. An application will not be considered until it is complete. Each application will be made as part of a conditional use application in compliance with chapter 34 of this Code. The following information shall also be submitted when applying for any telecommunications tower permit or variance included in this article and must be submitted for an application to be considered complete: 
(1)  Site plan or plans to scale specifying the location of telecommunications facilities, transmission building and/or other accessory uses, access, parking, fences, landscaped areas, and adjacent land uses. 
(2)  A full description of the environment surrounding the proposed telecommunications facility, including but not limited to any adjacent residential or commercial structures, roadways, and waterways. 
(3)  Report from a qualified, independent engineer licensed in the state, documenting the following: 
a.  Telecommunications facility height and design, including technical and engineering data; 
b.  Total anticipated capacity of the telecommunications facility, including number and types of antennae which can be accommodated; 
c.  Evidence of structural integrity of the tower; 
d.  Structural failure characteristics of the telecommunication facility and demonstration that site and setbacks are of adequate size to contain debris should failure occur. 
(4)  A definition of the area of service to be served by the antenna or tower and whether such antenna or tower is needed for coverage or capacity. 
(5)  Information showing the proposed facility would provide the needed coverage or capacity. 
(6)  The identity of a community liaison officer appointed by the applicant to resolve issues of concern to neighbors and residents relating to the construction and operation of the facility. Include name, address, telephone number, facsimile number and electronic mail address, if applicable. 
(7)  Identification of the geographic service areas for the subject installation, including a map showing the site and the nearest or associated telecommunications facility sites within and outside of the proposed network. Describe the distance between the telecommunications facility sites. Describe how this service area fits into and is necessary for the service network. 
( Ord. No. 13-11-01, 11-19-13 ) 
Sec. 35-6. - Future development. 
(a)  Two-year plan and site inventory. Each application shall include a two-year facilities plan and site inventory including the following: 
(1)  A list of all existing, existing to be upgraded or replaced, and proposed telecommunications facility sites within the city. The list must include the following information for each site: 
a.  Land lot and district; 
b.  Address if available; 
c.  Type of building (commercial, residential, mixed use) and number of stories; 
d.  The number of antennas and base transceiver stations per site and the location and type of antenna installation (stand alone rooftop, building facade, etc.) and location of the base transceiver station installation(s); 
e.  The height from grade to the top of the antenna installation; and 
f.  The radio frequency range in megahertz, the wattage output of the equipment and effective radiated power. 
(2)  If the applicant does not know specific future tower and antenna site locations but does know of area where telecommunications facilities will be needed within the next two years to provide service, the applicant shall list the assessor's blocks contained within the anticipated geographic service area and identify each geographic service area with a number that will correspond to the future telecommunication facility site. 
(b)  Additional information requirements for towers. 
(1)  Applicants must identify all existing towers and all towers for which there are applications currently on file with the director. Applicants must provide evidence of the lack of space on all suitable existing towers to locate the proposed antenna and of the lack of space on existing tower sites to construct a tower for the proposed antenna. If co-location on any such towers would result in less visual impact than the visual impact of the proposed tower, applicants must justify why such co-location is not being proposed. If co-location on any such tower would increase negative visual impact, then the applicant must so state and demonstrate. The director will review with special care justifications that appeal only to undue expense and/or to undue difficulties in entering into a lease agreement. The director shall carefully weigh such claims and the evidence presented in favor of them against a project's negative impacts at the proposed site. 
(2)  Applicants must demonstrate that they cannot provide personal wireless communication service without the use of a telecommunications tower. 
(3)  The applicant shall quantify the additional tower capacity anticipated, including the approximate number and types of antennae. The applicant shall provide a drawing for each tower showing existing and proposed antennae locations. The applicant shall also describe any limitations on the ability of the tower to accommodate other uses, e.g., radio frequency interference, mass height, frequency or other characteristics. The applicant shall describe the technical options available to overcome those limitations and reasons why the technical options considered were not chosen to be incorporated. The director shall approve those limitations if they cannot be overcome by reasonable technical means. 
(4)  The applicant must provide a utilities inventory showing the locations of all water, sewage, drainage and power lines impacting the proposed tower site. 
(c)  The applicant must provide any other information which may be requested by the director to fully evaluate and review the application and the potential impact of a proposed telecommunications facility. 
( Ord. No. 13-11-01, 11-19-13 ) 
Sec. 35-7. - Permits. 
(a)  Permits. 
(1)  A request for a telecommunication tower permit under this article shall be initiated by application to the city with the permit provision of section 35-5 of this article. All applications for telecommunications antenna and towers are to be approved only as conditional uses under chapter 34 of the Helen Municipal Code, and as such, shall follow the conditional use process as described in chapter 34, together with the requirements provided for in this chapter. If approved in accordance with chapters 34 and 35 of this Code, the city may issue a permit provided it shall have determined that all of the requirements of the Code have been satisfied and, further, that the benefits of and need for the proposed tower are greater than any possible depreciating effects and damage to the neighboring properties. Applications shall be denied where it is determined that sufficient information has not been presented or where requirements of the aforementioned sections have not been sufficiently satisfied. 
(2)  In granting a permit, the city may impose additional conditions to the extent determined necessary to buffer or otherwise minimize adverse effects of the proposed tower or antenna on surrounding properties. 
(b)  Permit fees. 
(1)  A fee in the amount of $1,000.00 shall be charged for each application. 
( Ord. No. 13-11-01, 11-19-13 ) 
Sec. 35-8. - Co-locations. 
Applicant and owner shall allow the city government as well as other future personal wireless service companies, including public and quasi-public agencies, using functionally equivalent personal wireless technology to co-locate antennae, equipment and facilities on a telecommunications facility unless specific technical constraints prohibit said co-location. Applicant and other personal wireless carriers shall provide a mechanism for the construction and maintenance of shared facilities and infrastructure and shall provide for equitable sharing of cost in accordance with industry standards. 
( Ord. No. 13-11-01, 11-19-13 ) 
Sec. 35-9. - Nuisances. 
Telecommunications facilities, including, without limitation, power source, ventilation and cooling, shall be operated at all times within the limits of, local, state, and federal regulations and shall not be operated so as to cause the generation of heat that adversely affects a building occupant and shall not be maintained or operated in such a manner as to be a nuisance. 
( Ord. No. 13-11-01, 11-19-13 ) 
Sec. 35-10. - Removal of antennae and towers. 
All telecommunications facilities shall be maintained in compliance with standards contained in applicable building and technical codes so as to ensure the structural integrity of such facilities. If upon inspection by the director, or his/her designee, of any telecommunications facility it is determined not to comply with the code standards or to constitute a danger to persons or property, then upon notice being provided to the owner of the facility and the owner of the property if such owner is different, such owners shall have 30 days to bring such facility into compliance. In the event such telecommunications facility is not brought into compliance within 30 days, the city may provide notice to the owners requiring the telecommunications facility to be removed. In the event such telecommunications facility is not removed within 30 days of receipt of such notice, the city may remove such facility and place a lien upon the property for the costs of removal. Delay by the city in taking action shall not in any way waive the city's right to take action. The city may pursue all legal remedies available to it to insure that telecommunications facilities not in compliance with the city standards or which constitute a danger to persons or property are brought into compliance or removed. The city may seek to have the telecommunications facility removed regardless of the owner's or operator's intent to operate the tower or antenna and regardless of any permits, federal, state or otherwise, which may have been granted. 
( Ord. No. 13-11-01, 11-19-13 ) 
Sec. 35-11. - Abandoned towers. 
(a)  Any telecommunications facility that is not operated for a continuous period of 12 months shall be considered abandoned, whether or not the owner or operator intends to make use of it or any part of it. The owner of a telecommunications facility and the owner of the property where the facility is located shall be under a duty to remove the abandoned telecommunications facility. If such antenna and/or tower is not removed within 60 days of receipt of notice from the city notifying the owner(s) of such abandonment, the city may remove such tower and/or antenna and place a lien upon the property for the costs of removal. The city may pursue all legal remedies available to it to insure that abandoned telecommunications facilities are removed. Delay by the city in taking action shall not in any way waive the city's right to take action. The city may seek to have the telecommunications facility removed regardless of the owner's or operator's intent to operate the tower or antenna and regardless of any permits, federal, state or otherwise, which may have been granted. 
(b)  If the owner of an abandoned tower or antenna wishes to use such abandoned tower or antenna, the owner first must apply for and receive all applicable permits and meet all of the conditions of this article as if such tower or antenna were a new tower or antenna. 
( Ord. No. 13-11-01, 11-19-13 ) 
Sec. 35-12. - Penalty for violations of chapter. 
(a)  Any person who attempts to erect or erects a telecommunications facility covered by this chapter without having first obtained the necessary building permit, special use permit or variance in the manner provided in this article shall be deemed in violation of this article. Any responsible party or other persons convicted by a court of competent jurisdiction of violating any provision of this article shall be guilty of violating a duly adopted ordinance of this city and shall be punished either by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 per day. Each day during which the violation or failure or refusal to comply continues, shall constitute a separate violation. 
(b)  If any structure is erected, constructed, reconstructed, altered, repaired, converted or maintained in violation of this article or without obtaining that required permits, or if any building, structure or land is used in violation of this article, the city attorney, in addition to any other remedies, may institute proceedings to prevent such unlawful erection, construction, reconstruction, alteration, conversion, maintenance or use or to correct or abate such violations. Each and every day such unlawful erection, construction, reconstruction, alteration, conversion, maintenance or use continues may be deemed a separate offense. 
( Ord. No. 13-11-01, 11-19-13 ) 
Chapter 36 - OUTDOOR MERCHANDISING 

Sec. 36-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall mean: 
Goods mean objects or materials for sale. 
Merchandise means all goods or services for sale by the business or goods or services used to draw attention to the business, or support structures used to display these. 
Perimeter means the outermost walls of the business. 
Premises means the building, or portion of the building, which occupies the business. 
Public walkway means any sidewalk, alley, corridor, or path open to pedestrian foot traffic. 
Shop means the leased or owned area occupying a place of business. 
(Ord. No. 05-09-01, 9-20-05) 
Sec. 36-2. - Application. 
This article applies to all businesses, active or inactive, within the city limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 05-09-01, 9-20-05) 
Sec. 36-3. - Regulation, outdoor display for merchandise prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any business to display goods or merchandise outside. This means standing on the ground outside the shop, hung or fastened to the exterior wall, or hung or fastened to any door which, whether in the open or closed position, puts the goods or merchandise on any face of the door which is then outside the perimeter, except for goods or merchandise contemplated by section 34-1114, or which is of such a nature that it ordinarily remains out of doors after business hours such as produce, firewood, fertilizers, outdoor furniture, or garden plants. Such goods or merchandise shall in no way obstruct a public walkway except as provided in section 34-1114. 
(Ord. No. 05-09-01, 9-20-05) 
Sec. 36-4. - Open decks. 
Should an open deck be used to display merchandise, the perimeter of the deck must have a rail constructed with a material and style consistent with the architectural and design requirements of the City Code, and permitted by the planning design and review board. Any merchandise displayed thereon is limited to goods or merchandise which is of such a nature that it ordinarily remains out of doors after business hours such as produce, firewood, fertilizers, outdoor furniture, or garden plants. 
(Ord. No. 05-09-01, 9-20-05) 
Sec. 36-5. - Exceptions. 
Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, and in order to provide opportunities for seasonal closeout and other sales, for a ten-day period beginning on the last Saturday of March, June, September, and December, each shop may display outdoors, on private property, without restrictions imposed by this chapter, goods and merchandise usually and customarily offered for sale by such shop. 
(Ord. No. 05-09-01, 9-20-05) 
Sec. 36-6. - Penalty. 
Any person who violates the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be punished as provided in section 1-7. 
(Ord. No. 05-09-01, 9-20-05) 
Chapter 38 - LAW ENFORCEMENT 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 38-1—38-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - POLICE DEPARTMENT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Police department authorized, § 1.13(36). 
Cross reference— Departments generally, § 2-101 et seq. 
State Law reference— Authority to provide for police protection, Ga. Const. art. IX, § 2, par. III(a)(1); Georgia Peace Officer Standards and Training Act, O.C.G.A. § 35-8-1 et seq. 

Sec. 38-26. - Composition. 
The police department shall consist of the chief of police and such other officers and personnel as the city manager shall prescribe following budgetary approval by the commission. 
(Code 1987, § 3-703(1)) 
Sec. 38-27. - Rank. 
Following the police chief in rank shall be the captain, the lieutenants, the sergeants, and the police officers, in order of seniority in each group. 
(Code 1987, § 3-703(2)) 
Sec. 38-28. - Police chief. 
(a)  Qualifications, appointment and powers. The police chief shall comply with O.C.G.A. § 35-8-1 et seq. The police chief shall be appointed by the city manager and shall be the chief executive officer of the police department, subject always to the orders of the city manager in keeping with the adopted policies of the city commission. In the exercise of official duties, the police chief shall have the power to establish and enforce rules and regulations for the government of the members and employees of the department, which rules shall, however, be consistent with the ordinances of the city and the laws of the state. 
(b)  Bond and oath. Prior to entering upon the discharge of his duties, the police chief of the city and such other officers who receive initial payments of cash bonds shall execute a bond in the amount of $1,500.00. The police chief shall take and subscribe the oath prescribed by section 2-76 of this Code. 
(c)  Duties. The police chief shall have the following duties: 
(1)  To attend all meetings of the city commission and all trials before the municipal court. 
(2)  To see to the proper service of all summonses, subpoenas, citations, executions, attachments, and rules of the city commission as may be directed by the city manager. 
(3)  To see to the collection of all fines and costs imposed by the municipal court. 
(4)  To see that the ordinances, rules and regulations of the city and all statutes applicable therein are faithfully enforced. 
(5)  To preserve the public peace, prevent infractions of the law, and arrest violators thereof. 
(6)  To protect the rights of persons and property. 
(7)  To oversee the conduct of the officers and other employees in the police force, and to be held strictly responsible for such conduct and for the general good order of the department. 
(8)  To keep adequate records of all personnel and equipment of the department including a log of all questions, activities and investigations. 
(9)  To make a monthly report available to the city manager on the number and type of arrests for state offenses, the number and type of cases involving violations of municipal ordinances, and the number of arrests made and cases reported by each police officer. 
(10)  To discharge such other duties as may be required of him by the manager or commission.
