(d)  Resignation, removal, death, disability. In the event of resignation, removal, death or disability of the police chief, the officer next in rank shall perform the duties of the chief until removal of such disability or until a successor has been duly appointed. 
(Code 1987, § 3-703(3)) 
Sec. 38-29. - Police officers. 
(a)  Qualifications. Any person employed by the city as a police officer shall comply with the qualifications in O.C.G.A. § 35-8-1 et seq. 
(b)  Bond and oath. Prior to entering upon the duties of their respective offices, all officers of the police department including nonuniformed employees in the police department shall execute a bond in the amount of $1,500.00. All officers of the police department shall take and subscribe the oath prescribed by section 2-76 of this Code. 
(c)  Duties. It shall be the duty of the officers of the police department to acquire a full knowledge of and to enforce all of the ordinances of the city and all statutes applicable therein; to become familiar with the rules and regulations established by the police chief concerning the discipline, good order, proper conduct, care and management of the police department; and to respect and obey all orders of the police chief not in conflict with the law or ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1987, § 3-703(4)) 
Sec. 38-30. - Arms and uniforms. 
Each officer and member of the police department shall be furnished with such uniform, arms and police equipment as provided for by the city commission. Uniforms shall be kept clean and pressed and shall be worn on duty at all times, unless otherwise ordered by a superior officer. The equipment, arms and uniforms furnished by the city shall be and always remain the property of the city and shall be, when a change is ordered or on retirement from office, returned to the city. The members of the department shall be liable on their bonds for any loss or careless destruction of or damage to their arms and uniforms. 
(Code 1987, § 3-703(5)) 
Sec. 38-31. - Arrests. 
Police officers of the city may make arrests for violations of municipal ordinances and state laws. 
(Code 1987, § 3-703(6)) 
Sec. 38-32. - Entering private dwellings. 
No police officer shall enter a private dwelling without a search or arrest warrant unless in pursuit of a fugitive of whom the officer has personal knowledge or if the officer has probable cause to believe the suspected offender has committed or attempted to commit a felony, or under such other facts and circumstances authorized by the laws of the State of Georgia and the United States. 
(Ord. No. 94-03-01, § 7(3), 7-19-94) 
Chapter 42 - MISCELLANEOUS OFFENSES AND PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Police power, § 1.13(16). 
State Law reference— Constitutional grant of home rule powers, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II; statutory grant of home rule powers, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 42-1. - Penalty. 
Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as provided in section 1-7. 
(Code 1987, § 13-104) 
Sec. 42-2. - Alcoholic beverages in open containers prohibited on public rights-of-way and property. 
It shall be unlawful to carry or drink any alcoholic beverages in or from an open container upon the public rights-of way or other public property. However, a bottle of wine that has been resealed and is carried pursuant to section 6-7 of the Official Code of the City of Helen, Georgia and O.C.G.A. section 3-6-4 shall not constitute an open container for purposes of this section. Further, the consumption of beer or wine in an area designated as an outdoor cafe area, at and during a duly authorized special city event, shall not constitute an open container violation for purposes of this section. 
State Law reference— Possession of open container of alcohol beverage while operating vehicle, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-253; removal of wine from restaurant by patron, O.C.G.A. § 3-6-4. 
(Ord. No. 89-8, 7-18-89; Ord. No. 09-12-01, 1-5-10; Ord. No. 13-05-01, 5-21-13) 
Sec. 42-3. - Camping prohibited within city limits. 
(a)  Definitions. 
Camp or camping means to use property within the city for the purposes of habitation, as evidenced by the use of camp facilities or paraphernalia. 
Camp facilities include, but are not limited to, temporary shelters, tents, huts, lean-tos, shacks, trailer campers, motor homes or any other type vehicle, trailer, or any other type shelter or structure. 
Camp paraphernalia includes, but is not limited to, tarpaulins, cots, beds, sleeping bags, blankets, mattresses, hammocks, lanterns, stove, or other cooking facilities and similar equipment. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to camp within the municipal limits of the City of Helen. This shall exclude security personnel for special events approved by the planning design and review board and the city commission. It shall also exclude residents of the City of Helen or their guest located in a residential zoning who are camping on their property overnight for recreational purposes. 
(Code 1987, §§ 32-101, 32-102; Ord. No. 13-07-02, 7-16-13) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 13-07-02, adopted July 16, 2013, deleted the former § 42-3, and enacted a § 42-3 as set out herein. The former § 42-3 pertained to Camping within city; permit and derived from Code 1987, §§ 32-101 and 32-102. 
Sec. 42-4. - Criminal trespass. 
The provisions of O.C.G.A. section 16-7-21, (as same may be hereafter amended), are incorporated herein, verbatim, by reference. 
(Ord. No. 97-08-01, 9-16-97) 
Sec. 42-5. - Furnishing alcoholic beverages to and purchase and possession of alcoholic beverages by underage persons. 
The provisions of O.G.C.A. 3-3-23 relating to furnishing alcoholic beverages to, and purchase and possession of alcoholic beverages by, a person under 21 years of age, (as same may be hereafter amended), are incorporated herein, verbatim, by reference. 
(Ord. No. 97-08-01, 9-16-97) 
Sec. 42-6. - Operation of unregistered motor vehicles, vehicles without license plates, decals, etc. 
The provisions of O.C.G.A. section 40-2-8, (as same may be hereafter amended), are incorporated herein, verbatim, by reference. 
(Ord. No. 97-08-01, 9-16-97) 
Sec. 42-7. - Possession of less than one ounce of marijuana. 
The possession of one ounce or less of marijuana within the corporate limits of the city is determined to be an illegal act. 
(Ord. No. 97-08-01, 9-16-97) 
Sec. 42-8. - Shoplifting. 
The first or second offense of shoplifting of $100.00 or less within the corporate limits of the City of Helen, Georgia, is determined to be an illegal act. A person convicted in a municipal court of a first or second offense of theft by shoplifting property valued at $100.00 or less shall be punished as provided in paragraph (1) of subsection (b) of O.C.G.A. section 16-8-14, provided that nothing in this section or O.C.G.A. section 16-8-14 shall be construed to give this city the right to impose a fine or punishment by imprisonment in excess of the limits as set forth in the Charter of the city. 
(Ord. No. 97-08-01, 9-16-97) 
Sec. 42-9. - Disorderly conduct. 
The provisions of O.C.G.A. Section 16-11-39, (as same may be hereafter amended), are incorporated herein, verbatim, by reference. 
(Ord. No. 97-08-01, 9-16-97)

The provisions of O.C.G.A. section 16-11-41, (as same may be hereafter amended), are incorporated herein, verbatim, by reference. 
(Ord. No. 97-08-01, 9-16-97) 
Sec. 42-11. - Littering public or private property or waters. 
The provisions of O.C.G.A. section 16-7-43, (as same may be hereafter amended), are incorporated herein, verbatim, by reference. 
(Ord. No. 97-08-01, 9-16-97) 
Sec. 42-12. - Designation of containers for household garbage; misuse or vandalization of container. 
The provisions of O.C.G.A. section 16-7-47, (except that each reference therein to "county" shall be deemed to refer herein to "city," and as same may be hereafter amended), are incorporated herein, verbatim, by reference. 
(Ord. No. 97-08-01, 9-16-97) 
Sec. 42-13. - Preventing or disrupting lawful meetings, gatherings, or processions. 
A person who recklessly or knowingly commits any act which may reasonably be expected to prevent or disrupt a lawful meeting, gathering, or procession is guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 97-08-01, 9-16-97) 
Sec. 42-14. - Loitering or prowling. 
The provisions of O.C.G.A. section 16-11-36, (as same may be hereafter amended), are incorporated herein, verbatim, by reference. 
(Ord. No. 97-08-01, 9-16-97) 
Sec. 42-15. - Use of machine guns, sawed-off rifles, sawed-off shotguns, or firearms with silencers during commission of certain offenses. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to possess or to use a machine gun, sawed-off rifle, sawed-off shotgun, or a firearm equipped with a silencer, as those terms are defined in O.C.G.A. section 16-11-121, during the participation in criminal gang activity as defined in O.C.G.A. section 16-15-4. 
(Ord. No. 97-08-01, 9-16-97) 
Sec. 42-16. - Participation in criminal gang activity prohibited. 
Any person who actively participates in any criminal street gang with knowledge that its members engage in or have engaged in a pattern of criminal gang activity and who willfully promotes, furthers, or assists in any felonious criminal conduct by members of that gang shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 97-08-01, 9-16-97) 
Sec. 42-17. - Public indecency. 
(a)  A person commits the offense of public indecency when he or she performs any of the following acts in a public place: 
(1)  An act of sexual intercourse; 
(2)  A lewd exposure of the sexual organs; 
(3)  A lewd appearance in a state of partial or complete nudity; or 
(4)  A lewd caress or indecent fondling of the body of another person. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall apply only to a first or second offense, and shall be punished as for a misdemeanor. 
(c)  For the purposes of this section only, "public place" shall include jails and penal and correctional institutions of the state and its political subdivisions. 
(Ord. No. 97-08-01, 9-16-97) 
Sec. 42-18. - Damaging, injuring, or interfering with property of public utility companies, municipalities, or political subdivisions. 
The provisions of O.C.G.A. section 16-7-25, (as same may be hereafter amended), are incorporated herein, verbatim, by reference. 
(Ord. No. 97-08-01, 9-16-97) 
Sec. 42-19. - Smoking in public places. 
The provisions of O.C.G.A. section 16-12-2, (as same may be hereafter amended), are incorporated herein, verbatim, by reference. 
(Ord. No. 97-08-01, 9-16-97) 
Sec. 42-20. - Certain acts in public transit buses, public transit vehicles, cable cars, trolleys, rail cars, or stations. 
(a)  A person who commits any of the following acts in a public transit bus, a public transit vehicle, a cable car, a trolley, a rail car, or a station shall be guilty of a misdemeanor: 
(1)  Spits; 
(2)  Discards litter, except into receptacles designated for that purpose; 
(3)  Plays any radio; cassette, cartridge, or tape player; or similar device unless such device is connected to an earphone that limits the sound to the hearing of the individual user; 
(4)  Carries or possesses any explosives, acids, other dangerous articles, or live animals, except for seeing eye dogs properly harnessed and accompanied by a blind person and small animals properly packaged; 
(5)  Obstructs, hinders, interferes with, or otherwise disrupts or disturbs the operation or operator of a public transit bus, a public transit vehicle, a cable car, a trolley, or a rail car; or 
(6)  Boards any public transit bus, a public transit vehicle, a cable car, a trolley, or a rail car through an exit door, unless so directed by an employee or agent of the carrier. 
(b)  A person convicted of a first offense of violating subsection (a) of this Code section shall be punished by a fine of not less than $50.00 and not more than $100.00. Upon a second or subsequent conviction, a person shall be punished by a fine of not less than $100.00 and not more than $250.00 or by imprisonment for not more than ten days, or both. 
(Ord. No. 97-08-01, 9-16-97) 
Sec. 42-21. - Bicycles, tricycles, roller skates, roller blades, and skateboards, on public street, public sidewalks, and Market Platz. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to rollerskate, rollerblade, ride a skateboard, ride a bicycle, or ride a tricycle on any public sidewalk within the city, or upon the Market Platz within the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person upon rollerskates, rollerblades, a skateboard, a bicycle, or a tricycle on any public sidewalk within the city, or upon the Market Platz within the city, to fail to yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian, and any such act shall constitute a separate offense under this section. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person upon rollerskates, rollerblades, or skateboard, on any public street within the city, to fail to yield the right-of-way to any vehicle or pedestrian, and any such act shall constitute a separate offense under this section. 
(Ord. 04-08-05, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 42-22. - Coolers and drink containers prohibited in Chattahoochee River. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to use or possess any cooler or drink container either in, or upon, the Chattahoochee River and within the city limits. Such containers shall include, without limitation, containers made of glass, plastic, paper, or metal, and shall include, without limitation, containers known as cups, bottles, or cans. An exception to this section is permitted for one plastic bottle per person, per tube, not to exceed 32 ounces. 
(Ord. No. 06-07-02, 8-1-06; Ord. No. 06-11-01, 12-19-06; Ord. No. 08-06-03, 7-15-08) 
Sec. 42-23. - Requirements for companies providing flotation devices for use in Chattahoochee River. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any company within the city limits, providing flotation devices for use in the Chattahoochee River, to permit any customer to use or possess any cooler or drink either in, or upon, the Chattahoochee River and within the city limits. Such containers shall include, without limitation, containers made of glass, plastic, paper, or metal, and shall include, without limitation, containers known as cups, bottles, or cans. An exception to this section is permitted for one plastic bottle per person, per tube, not to exceed 32 ounces. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any company within the city limits, providing flotation devices for use in the Chattahoochee River, to provide any such flotation device unless they have a sign posted at the ticket sale area, and at all entrances to the river, upon which is clearly printed the following: 
(1)  It is unlawful, pursuant to City Code 46-22, for any person to use or possess any cooler or drink container with the exception of one plastic bottle of water per tube not to exceed 32 ounces, either in, or upon, the Chattahoochee River and within the City Limits of Helen, Georgia; 
(2)  No glass allowed; 
(3)  No littering - Georgia State Law; 
(4)  No coolers; 
(5)  Respect other river users, [i.e., fishermen, kayakers, waders, etc.]; 
(6)  Respect private property; 
(7)  No nudity; 
(8)  No alcohol; and 
(9)  It shall be unlawful to leave the river by way of the river bank except at the designated area. The sign posted at the ticket sales counter shall be at least 16 inches × 16 inches, and the sign posted at the entrances to the river shall be at least 24 inches × 36 inches. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any company within the city limits, providing flotation devices for use in the Chattahoochee River, to provide any such flotation device unless they also provide, on a daily basis, company employee(s) in such number as is reasonable necessary, to clean up the Chattahoochee River and riverbank, from city limit to city limit. River cleanup shall be performed daily and shall be performed on a weekly rotation basis by each tubing company providing floatation devices. The city shall designate the company for the first week of cleanup and the companies shall rotate weekly cleaning the river until the season has concluded. 
(Ord. No. 06-07-02, 8-1-06; Ord. No. 06-11-01, 12-19-06; Ord. No. 08-06-03, 7-15-08) 
Secs. 42-24, 42-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OFFENSES INVOLVING PUBLIC PEACE AND ORDER[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Offenses involving public order and safety, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 42-26—42-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - NOISE 

Sec. 42-41. - Prohibited generally. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully make, continue, or cause to be made or continued any excessive, unnecessary or unusually loud noise which disturbs the peace or quiet of any neighborhood or which causes discomfort or annoyance to any reasonable person of normal sensitiveness residing within the city limits. 
(Code 1987, § 13-101) 
Sec. 42-42. - Unlawful noises enumerated. 
The following acts are declared to be a loud, disturbing and unnecessary noise in violation of this article, but this enumeration shall not be deemed to be exhaustive: 
(1)  Motor vehicle horns. The sounding of any horn on any automobile, motorcycle, or other motor vehicle on any street or public place of the city except as a warning signal. 
(2)  Radios, television sets, similar devices. The using, operating or permitting to be played, used or operated, any radio receiving set, musical instrument, phonograph, television set or other machine or device for the production or reproduction of sound between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. in such manner as to disturb the peace, quiet, and comfort of neighboring residents, unless a permit for such sound amplification has been obtained from the manager or chief of police. 
(3)  Loudspeakers and amplifiers. The using or operating of any loudspeaker, or sound-amplifying, or broadcasting device mounted upon any vehicle, upon any building, or set outside upon the premises of any property within the city, for the purpose of broadcasting or advertising any information about any business or activity, amplifying the sound of any entertainment thereon or therein, or for any other purpose, when, at a distance of 50 feet from the source of any such broadcast or amplification, the noise level, six (6) feet above the ground level, exceeds 70 decibels. 
(4)  Equipment and activities. The operating of any equipment for the loading or unloading of solid waste dumpsters (or any similar contrivance), either private or commercial, and the act of loading or unloading of solid waste dumpsters (or any similar contrivance), either private or commercial, and the act of connecting road tractors to freight trailers, and the operating of any equipment or the performing of any outside construction or repair work on buildings, structures, roads, or projects within the city between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. 
(5)  Exhausts. The discharging into the open air of the exhaust of any internal combustion engine, motor boat, or motor vehicle except through a muffler or other device which will effectively prevent loud or explosive noises therefrom. 
(6)  Animals and birds. The keeping of any animal or bird which by frequent or continuous barking, chirping or other means of communication disturbs the comfort or repose of the residents of any residential neighborhood. 
(7)  Vehicle repair in residential areas. The repairing, rebuilding, or testing of any motor vehicle between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. within any residential area in such a manner as to disturb the peace, quiet and comfort of the residents of the area. 
(8)  Schools, courts, churches, hospitals. The creating of any excessive noise on any street adjacent to any school, institution of learning, church or court while the same are in use, or adjacent to any hospital, which unreasonably interferes with the workings of such institution, or which disturbs or unduly annoys patients in the hospital, provided conspicuous signs are displayed in such streets indicating that the same is a school, hospital or court street. 
(9)  Hawkers and peddlers. The selling of anything by outcry within the city, except at licensed sporting events, parades, fairs, circuses and other similarly licensed public entertainment events. 
(10)  Drums. The using of any drum or other instrument or device for the purpose of attracting attention by the creation of noise within the city, unless a permit for such use has been obtained from the city manager or chief of police. 
(Code 1987, § 13-102; Ord. No. 97-09-01, 10-21-97; Ord. No. 97-10-01, 11-8-97) 
Sec. 42-43. - Exemptions. 
The following uses and activities shall be exempt from the noise regulations set forth in this article: 
(1)  Noises of safety signals and warning devices. 
(2)  Noises resulting from any authorized emergency vehicle, when responding to an emergency call or acting in time of emergency. 
(3)  Noises resulting from emergency work, to be construed as work made necessary to restore property to a safe condition following a public calamity, or work required to protect persons or property from an imminent exposure to danger. 
(Code 1987, § 13-103) 
Sec. 42-44. - Injunctions. 
The operation or maintenance of any device, vehicle or machinery in violation of any provision of this article which causes discomfort or annoyance to reasonable persons of normal sensitiveness or which endangers the comfort, repose, health or peace of residents of this city shall be deemed, and is declared to be, a public nuisance, and may be subject to abatement summarily by a restraining order or injunction issued by a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Code 1987, § 13-105) 
Sec. 42-45. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person violating any provision of this article shall be punished as provided in chapter 1, section 1-7, of this Code. 
(b)  Each day of violation of any provision of this article shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 97-09-01, 10-21-97) 
DIVISION 3. - CURFEW FOR MINORS 

Sec. 42-46. - Short title and definitions. 
(a)  Short title. This Division 3 of Article II shall be known and recited as "The Curfew for Minors Ordinance." 
(b)  Definitions. The following words and terms, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except when the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Curfew hours are the hours between 12:00 midnight of any day and 6:00 a.m. on the following day. 
Establishment is any privately owned place of business operating for a profit to which the public is invited, including, but not limited to, any place of amusement or entertainment. 
Minor is a person who has not yet reached his or her 18th birthday. 
Parent is the lawful father or mother of a minor, and for purposes of this division, a legal guardian or other adult person having responsibility for the lawful care and custody of the minor. 
Public place is defined as any place to which the public or a substantial group of the public has access, and includes streets, alleys, highways, and the common areas of schools, hospitals, apartment houses, condominiums, common properties, office buildings, transportation facilities, open business establishments, municipal, state, and federal buildings and grounds, and for purposes of this division, includes privately owned vehicles, carriages, and any mode of public transportation while upon the streets, roads, alleys, and other public ways in the city. 
(Ord. No. 95-02-01, 7-18-95) 
Sec. 42-47. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this division is to promote juvenile safety and well being, while reducing juvenile crimes, juvenile violence, and juvenile victimization. 
(Ord. No. 95-02-01, 7-18-95) 
Sec. 42-48. - Penalty. 
Anyone found guilty of violating any provision of this division shall be punished as provided in Section 1-7 of the Code of the City of Helen and/or as otherwise provided for juveniles and juvenile proceedings allowable under applicable sections of the laws of the State of Georgia. 
(Ord. No. 95-02-01, 7-18-95) 
Sec. 42-49. - Violation. 
(a)  Any minor who remains in a public place or on the premises of any establishment as herein defined during curfew hours, and whose activities are not excepted or exempted from coverage as enumerated in section 42-50, shall be in violation of this division. 
(b)  A parent, guardian, or other adult having responsibility for the lawful care and custody of a minor, shall be in violation of this division if he or she or they knowingly permit, or by insufficient control, allow a minor or minors in his, her, or their charge to remain on a public place or on the premises of any establishment herein defined during curfew hours. 
(c)  Any business owner or licensee or authorized agent of a business owner or licensee who allows a minor to remain on the premises of a defined place or establishment during curfew hours shall be in violation of this division except as otherwise set out hereinafter in section 42-50(b) thereof. 
(Ord. No. 95-02-01, 7-18-95) 
Sec. 42-50. - Exceptions and exemptions enumerated. 
(a)  This division shall not apply to any person under 18 years of age who: 
(1)  Is or has been emancipated by marriage; 
(2)  Is accompanied by his/her parent, parents, legal guardian or other adult having responsibility for lawful custody and care of the minor; 
(3)  Is engaged in employment or employment-related activities; 
(4)  Is engaged in interstate or intrastate travel; 
(5)  Is attending school, a religious or civic organization function that is supervised; 
(6)  Is attending or traveling directly to or from an activity involving the exercise of First Amendment rights of free speech, freedom of assembly, or free exercise of religion; 
(7)  Is in a public place because of an emergency; 
(8)  Is on the sidewalk in front of his or her home or an adjacent dwelling; and 
(9)  Is on an errand directed by his or her parent, parents, legal guardian or other adult person having responsibility for the lawful care and custody of the minor. 
(b)  Business owners also commit a violation of this division if they allow a minor to remain on the premises of an establishment defined herein during curfew hours. It shall be a defense or an exception for the business owner if the business owner, the agent, or employee of the business owner, notified the city police about the minor remaining on the business premises after he or she had been requested to leave. 
(Ord. No. 95-02-01, 7-18-95) 
Sec. 42-51. - Conflicts. 
All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are hereby expressly repealed. 
(Ord. No. 95-02-01, 7-18-95) 
Chapter 43 - SPECIAL EVENTS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 15-02-01, adopted Mar. 17, 2015, amended Ch. 43 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 43, §§ 43-1—43-6, pertained to short term special events, and derived from Ord. No. 01-10-04, adopted Nov. 20, 2001; Ord. No. 08-02-01, adopted Mar. 18, 2008; and Ord. No. 14-05-01, adopted May 20, 2014. 

Sec. 43-1. - Purpose and definitions. 
Preamble: The City of Helen encourages special events. The intent of this chapter is to set procedures for approval by the regulating authorities of the city for the special event and the apparatus required to efficiently bring special events to a successful conclusion, while encouraging special events which are compatible with the tourism industry, as well as the public safety and welfare of the city's residents, visitors, and merchants. The following definitions shall apply to the interpretation and enforcement of this chapter. 
Special event: The term "special event" shall mean any organized activity having as its purpose, entertainment, recreation and/or education, such as a festival or celebration, foot or vehicle race, parade or march, rally or assembly which takes place on a public street, sidewalk, right-of-way, city property, or occurs on private property and impacts government services. 
City Manager: The city manager of the government of the City of Helen, or his designee for the administration of this chapter. 
Producer: Any person, group of persons, organization, association, club, or other entity responsible for planning, producing and conducting a special event. 
Vendor: Any person or persons who engage in the sale to the public of any food or food products, goods, services, or merchandise of whatever nature from any location, either mobile or stationary, on a temporary itinerant basis on any public street, sidewalk, right-of-way or other city owned property. 
( Ord. No. 15-02-01, 3-17-15 ) 
Sec. 43-2. - Permits required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, group, organization, association, club or other entity to conduct or cause to be conducted any special event within the city limits of Helen without having obtained a valid permit as required prior to such special event. All permit and application fees are non-refundable. 
( Ord. No. 15-02-01, 3-17-15 ) 
Sec. 43-3. - Application requirements and fees. 
(a)  Application. An application package shall be submitted to the city manager, a minimum of two months prior to the intended date of the special event (but no more than one year in advance thereof) and shall include the following: 
(1)  Request letter on organization letterhead providing a description of the special event and listing all persons in charge of the special event along with a principal designated agent for the special event. A photo identification card of the designated agent must be provided, and the designated agent shall be fully responsible for the compliance with all provisions, including all financial requirements of this chapter, and other applicable laws. 
(2)  Photos or renderings of all apparatus required to hold the special event such as signs, banners, inflatables, tents, offices and structures. 
(3)  The time frame of the proposed special event should be clearly specified. Except for clearing of the area. no special event shall be allowed to continue beyond the time approved on the permit for the special event. 
(4)  Identify what is needed from the city related to safety, law enforcement and clean up. A special event shall be limited to the specific geographic area(s) within which the special event is to take place and the producer of a special event shall be responsible for the provision of police and sanitation services within the boundaries of the special event for a period of two hours past the conclusion of the special event or until the area is cleared of all activities and structures related to such special event. 
(5)  Identify by sketch or map all locations in the city which will be occupied by the special event. The outermost boundaries of the special event shall be fully and clearly delineated on a map, which shall be no smaller than eight and one-half by 11 inches in size, and attached to the application for a permit. All public streets and/or sidewalks within and adjacent to such area(s) shall be clearly identified. The manager, or designee, shall require, as part of the approval for the special event, that areas no less than five feet in width shall be designated and preserved for public circulation and access to adjoining business establishments outside the area(s) delineated for the special event. The producer of a special event such as a walk or run, as to which the above provisions would not be practicable, shall submit with the application for a permit, a map, which shall be no smaller than eight and one-half by 11 inches in size, showing the exact route of the course for the walk or run. 
(6)  Identify any amplification of sound and apparatus to be used for amplification of sound. 
(7)  A list of anticipated vendors sponsored by the special event with a description of the anticipated vendors and how their products and or services relate to the special event. Only vendors selling goods or services specific to the special event will be allowed. 
(b)  Fees. An application processing and permitting fee of up to $225.00 based on the approvals necessary will be required at the time of the initial application. The schedule of fees for approvals, processing and permitting are as follows: 
(1)  Standard application fees. 
Application ..... $50.00 
Approval by city commission [if required] ..... 50.00 
Parade permit for city regulated streets ..... 25.00 
Parade permit for Department of Transportation regulated streets ..... 75.00 
Signage approval and permitting ..... 25.00 
A deposit of $500.00 will be required at the time of application approval, all or a portion of which may refunded at the conclusion of the special event depending on the condition of city property used for the special event. 
(2)  Additional fees required: Additional fees to conduct a special event may be imposed which shall be based on all services to be provided by the government for such special event, and which fees shall be equal to the estimated actual cost to the government to provide such services. If, at the conclusion of the special event, the cost of government services is greater than the initial payment, the producer of the special event shall be billed for the difference. Failure to pay the outstanding amount within 30 days of the billing date shall be a violation of this chapter. Fees for the estimated costs of government services must be paid no later than 14 days prior to the date of the special event. 
( Ord. No. 15-02-01, 3-17-15 ) 
Sec. 43-4. - Approval process and requirements at time of approval. 
(a)  Administrative review. The city manager shall cause the application to be circulated to each government department and/or other agency whose services the manager determines would be affected by the nature and activities of the proposed special event. Each such department or agency shall review the application and note the services which it will be required to perform, the number of personnel to perform such services, the length of time to perform such services, the cost to perform such services, and any other information which would assist the manager in facilitating the special event and services required. A minimum of 30 days shall be allowed for the administrative review of the application. 
(b)  Special conditions. Each department of the government reviewing an application may recommend in writing certain conditions or restrictions as deemed necessary to facilitate the special event, to comply with other laws or regulations, and/or to ensure the safety, health and welfare of the community. In reviewing the recommendations of the departments, the city manager, planning design and review board, or city commission may impose such conditions or restrictions as a part of any permit issued and such special conditions so imposed shall be construed to have the full force and effect of law as a provision of this chapter. A violation of such conditions or restrictions shall be deemed a violation of this chapter. 
(c)  Review by planning design and review board. The application package will be reviewed by the city planning design and review board. The board will approve or disapprove the application if city commission approval is not required under this chapter: or shall recommend approval or disapproval is city commission approval is required under this chapter. The review of the planning design and review board shall be based upon the administrative review of the city manager and the city departments as described above: the compatibility and compliance of the application package with the requirements of this chapter: and the compatibility of the proposed special event with the city's tourism industry. Ordinances related to land development, as contained in the city code, are not applicable, and will not be the basis for the planning design and review board decision. However, all local and state regulations for public health and safety must be complied with by the special event producers. 
(d)  City commission approval required in certain circumstances. If a public right-of-way will be required to be closed for two hours or longer; or if the special event will require the use of city property for two hours or longer; or in the event that because of the nature of the special event, additional law enforcement personnel or public works personnel will be required to be on duty; or if the city manager determines that additional commission approval should be required because of potential impact of the special event on the public safety or infrastructure of the city; then, in those circumstances. City commission approval will be required. If city commission approval is required, the planning design and review board will recommend approval or disapproval of the application to the city commission following their review pursuant to subsection 43-4(c) supra , and the city commission shall make the final decision regarding approval or disapproval of the application. 
(e)  Final approval of permit. If the application is approved in accordance with the above, the city manager is authorized to issue a permit for a special event after the payment of all applicable fees and costs: together with such special conditions as are required by the city manager. City planning design and review board, and/or city commission. If the application is denied, the producer shall be notified in writing of the denial and the reasons for the denial. 
( Ord. No. 15-02-01, 3-17-15 ) 
Sec. 43-5. - Liability. 
The producer of any special event shall hold harmless the City of Helen, its officers, employees and agents from liability of damages arising from any acts or omissions emanating from a special event. Proof of such waiver shall be filed with, and made a part of, the application form. The producer shall be responsible for providing any and all other insurance that may be necessary for any special event and proof of such insurance may be required by the City of Helen prior to permit issuance. A City of Helen may require such insurance as a condition of the approval of the special event. 
( Ord. No. 15-02-01, 3-17-15 ) 
Sec. 43-6. - Vendors. 
(a)  Sales permitted. The sale of food or any merchandise or services of any type by a vendor shall be allowed as a component of a special event provided such vendor is approved and authorized in writing by the producer of the special event and shall be conducted in accordance with such conditions and limitations as shall be imposed in writing by the producer and submitted as part of the application for a permit. All vendors must be identified by the producer of the special event to the city prior to the special event. Vendors not identified to the city as part of the application process shall not be allowed to vend. 
(b)  Authorization of vendors. Upon meeting the requirements of subsection 43-6(a), the producer of a special event shall have sole responsibility and authority to allow or disallow vending as a component of an special event and to designate the location and activities of such vendors. It shall be unlawful for any vendor to engage in such business at any location or in any manner not authorized by the producer of the special event, or in violation of any local, state or federal law or regulation. 
(c)  Permit not required. Vendors authorized by the producer of a special event as a component of the special event shall not be required to obtain any separate vendors permit to operate during the period of the special event. 
(d)  Food sales. The vendor of any food, whether hot or cold, as a part of a special event shall be subject to all rules and regulations of the county health department. It shall be the responsibility of the producer of a special event to assure compliance with this section by any such vendors. 
( Ord. No. 15-02-01, 3-17-15 ) 
Sec. 43-7. - Additional rules and regulations for special events. 
(a)  Glass containers prohibited. The use of glass containers within the area of any special event shall be prohibited. 
(b)  Police services. Traffic and crowd control shall be provided by the Helen Police Department and the number of officers and/or special arrangements shall be determined by the chief of police. Costs shall be paid by the Special event permittee as determined above. 
(c)  Toilet facilities. The producer of a special event shall be required to provide temporary outdoor toilet facilities at any special event at which 100 or more persons are expected to be in attendance. The number of toilets and their locations shall be determined by the director of the building inspection department. 
(d)  Musical entertainment. Any musical entertainment shall be provided in a manner consistent with the peace and good order of the community. The producer of the special event shall be responsible for full compliance with the noise ordinance. 
(e)  Temporary facilities. Tents, arbors, stages, grandstands or other temporary facilities constructed or erected as a part of a special event shall be approved by the director of the building inspection department and the fire marshal at the time of review. 
(f)  Street closing. The complete or partial closure of any city street, sidewalk or other public way as a part of a special event shall be approved by the city commission in consultation with the chief of police. A request to close the state highway will also require the approval of the Georgia Department of Transportation. 
(g)  Banners, signs, etc. Temporary, noncommercial banners or signs may be permitted overhead across city public streets for the purpose of designating "starting" and "finish" lines for a race. Small banners, pennants, signs or other decorations which do not interfere with vehicular or pedestrian traffic, and which do not damage or deface any tree or public structure, may be allowed as part of a special event with approval by the planning design and review board. The producer of the special event shall be responsible for the removal of such banners, pennants or decorations within 24 hours after the close of the special event. 
(h)  Duration of permit. No permit issued under this chapter shall be valid prior to or past the date of the special event for which it is issued. 
(i)  Cessation of activities. The safety, health, welfare and good order of all citizens and the community shall be first and foremost and every special event shall be conducted in such manner. The chief of police may terminate any activity, whether a part of or the entire special event, which does not meet this community standard. Upon notification of the special event producer in person by the chief of police to cease any activity, it shall be unlawful for such producer and/or any participants to permit such activity to continue. 
( Ord. No. 15-02-01, 3-17-15 ) 
Chapter 46 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Parks, § 1.13(12). 
Cross reference— Department of public works, § 2-126 et seq. 
State Law reference— Parks authorized, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, par. III(a)(5). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 46-1. - Rules and regulations authorized. 
The city manager of the city is authorized and directed to develop and publish rules and regulations for the use of all city parks, and to supplement and amend same from time to time, so long as such rules and regulations are not inconsistent with the provisions of the Code of the city. Each such rule or regulation shall bear the effective date thereof, and the violation thereof shall be a misdemeanor under this Code. Any such rules and regulations shall be presented to the city commission at the meeting next following the development, publishing, implementation, and effective date of such rules and regulations, for review. Upon commission review, any or all of such rules and regulations may be overruled by the commission, and upon such action, such rule or regulation is immediately revoked and repealed ab initio, and no later rule or regulation substantially similar therewith shall be permitted without express approval by the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 04-08-03, 9-21-04) 
Secs. 46-2—46-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PARKS AND RECREATION BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Boards, commissions and authorities, § 2-301 et seq. 

Sec. 46-26. - Composition, appointment, tenure. 
The park and recreation board shall consist of five persons appointed by the commission for terms of five years each. 
(Code 1987, § 3-803(1)) 
Sec. 46-27. - Vacancies. 
Vacancies on the park and recreation board shall be filled by the commission for unexpired terms only. 
(Code 1987, § 3-803(2)) 
Sec. 46-28. - Compensation. 
The members of the park and recreation board shall serve without compensation. 
(Code 1987, § 3-803(3)) 
Sec. 46-29. - Officers, rules of procedure. 
Immediately after their appointment, the members of the park and recreation board shall meet and elect one of their members president and elect such other officers as may be necessary. The board shall recommend rules and regulations for adoption by the commission on the governance of its proceedings. Following any adoption, the park and recreation board members shall keep a correct record thereof. 
(Code 1987, § 3-803(4)) 
Sec. 46-30. - Powers and duties. 
The park and recreation board shall conduct and maintain recreation policies for the city in such a way as to employ the leisure of the people in a wholesome and constructive manner. In particular, it shall have the following responsibilities: 
(1)  To plan public playgrounds, indoor recreation centers, leisure activities, recreation programs, and other recreational facilities owned or controlled by the city. 
(2)  To recommend the setting aside, leasing or acquisition of lands or buildings within or without the city limits for use as parks, playgrounds, recreation centers, or for other recreational purposes, and to provide for the maintenance and improvement of such areas. 
(3)  To cooperate with the local school board in the establishment, conduct and maintenance of a recreation system. 
(4)  To submit a budget proposal annually to the city manager in the same manner as is required by department heads. 
(5)  To submit an annual report to the city manager which shall include a financial statement of money received and expended and a description of all activities sponsored by the board during the year. 
(6)  To exercise such other powers and duties as may be delegated to it from time to time by the manager following policy directives that may be adopted by the commission. 
(Code 1987, § 3-803(5)) 
Chapter 50 - PERSONNEL[1] 
  

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Personnel policies, § 3.14. 
Cross reference— Officers and employees, § 2-76 et seq.; personnel policies and procedures, app. A. 

Sec. 50-1. - Physical examination. 
Applicants seeking employment may be required to complete a standard application form as provided by the city and to pass a complete physical examination to be given by a licensed physician and paid for by the prospective employee. The physician shall enter his findings on a standard form to be provided by the city. This provision shall not apply to those employees hired in an emergency and for a period of less than ten working days. 
(Code 1987, § 3-604(2)) 
Sec. 50-2. - Strikes. 
No municipal employee shall participate in or encourage any form of sit down, slow down, work stoppage, or strike against the city. 
(Code 1987, § 3-604(7)) 
Sec. 50-3. - Accidents. 
Employees involved in, or having any knowledge of, any accident involving any other person employed by the city or any property or equipment owned or operated by the city shall immediately report the accident and pertinent information to their department head, who shall forward such information to the office of the city clerk. The city clerk shall record the information on three copies of the applicable accident form, one copy to be forwarded to the insurance carrier, one copy to the city attorney, and one copy retained on file in the city clerk's office. 
(Code 1987, § 3-604(3)) 
Chapter 54 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— General authority relative to solid waste, § 1.13(22), (23), (40). 
Cross reference— Department of public works, § 2-126 et seq.; environment, ch. 26; utilities, ch. 70. 
State Law reference— Authority to provide for solid waste collection and disposal, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, par. III(a)(2). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 54-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Collection means where a person who, under agreements, verbal or written, with or without compensation, does the work of collecting and/or transporting solid waste from industries, offices, retail outlets, businesses, institutions and/or similar locations, or from residential dwellings; provided, however, that this definition shall not include an individual collecting and/or transporting waste from his own single-family dwelling unit. 
Commercial premises means all commercial concerns within the city. 
Convenience center means a conveniently located site for collection of solid waste and/or recyclables, operated by or on behalf of the city, or by any private entity. 
Disposal facility means any facility or location where any treatment, utilization, processing or deposit of solid waste occurs. 
Disposal operation means the performance of solid waste disposal, including administration, personnel, land, equipment, design and other elements necessary or used in the work of solid waste disposal. 
Disposal site means the location or land area where the final deposition of solid waste occurs. 
Garbage means putrescible animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food. 
Hazardous waste means solid or liquid waste material resulting from the manufacture or use of pesticides and drugs (other than normal household use); pathological wastes; highly flammable or explosive wastes; toxic wastes; sewage sludges; and other waste material determined to be a likely hazard to the public health, safety, or environment, except radioactive waste materials as provided for in rules of the department of human resources. 
Industrial waste means waste materials generated in industrial operations. 
Open dump means a disposal site at which solid waste from one or more sources is consolidated and left to decompose, burn or to otherwise create environmental pollution or nuisance. 
Putrescible wastes means wastes that are capable of being decomposed by microorganisms, including kitchen wastes, manure, offal, hatchery and poultry wastes, and garbage. 
Reclamation means a controlled method of sorting and storing solid wastes for future use in accordance with an approved plan. 
Recycling means the collection of used glass, aluminum, corrugated cardboard, newspapers, plastic or other materials for processing into new products. 
Refuse means classes of refuse which are designated as follows: garbage, limbs, leaves, and trimmings. 
Residential class A premises means all single-family residential dwellings for which curbside service is feasible to provide in the collection of solid waste in the form of household garbage, excluding yard trash and rubbish, from a limit of three 30-gallon cans or a limit of three 30-gallon approved sealed plastic garbage bags, with a limit of three such containers; or any combination, not to exceed three cans or bags total. A residential class A premises shall normally have one pickup per week. 
Residential class B premises means all multifamily residential dwellings for which curbside service is feasible to provide and a commercial type container is provided and shared by all residential tenants or owners. 
Rubbish means nonputrescible solid wastes (excluding ashes), consisting of both combustible and noncombustible wastes, such as paper, cardboard, tin cans, yard clippings, wood, glass, bedding, crockery and similar materials. 
Sanitary landfilling means a method of disposing of putrescible waste and/or hazardous waste on land by placing an earth cover thereon. 
Scavenge means uncontrolled picking from discarded waste materials. 
Solid waste means putrescible and nonputrescible wastes, except water-carried body wastes, including garbage, trash, cans, bottles, rubbish, ashes, street refuse, dead animals, sewage sludges, animal manures, industrial wastes, residue from incineration, food-processing wastes, construction wastes, hazardous wastes, and any other waste material in a solid or semisolid state not otherwise defined in this chapter. 
Transfer station means a facility used to transfer solid wastes from one transportation vehicle to another for transportation to a disposal facility. 
(Code 1987, § 11-103; Ord. No. 96-06-01, 7-15-96; Ord. No. 98-03-01, 4-14-98) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 54-2. - Penalty. 
(a)  Except as hereinafter provided in (b) and (c) hereof, any person charged with a violation of any section or provision of this chapter shall be given a written notice and instructions from the city manager as to the required remedy for such violation and shall be given ten days to comply with the provisions of this chapter. Failure to comply with the requirements of such written notice and instructions of the city manager shall result in the termination of services of the sanitation department and shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-7. Reinstatement of city trash and garbage collection shall only be provided after the person, firm, institution or corporation has fully complied with all the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  The provisions of subsection (a) notwithstanding, any person detected to be in violation of the provisions of section 54-4 may be immediately charged with such violation and, upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in section 1-7. 
(c)  Any person convicted of a violation of subsection 54-34(a) and subsection 54-34(b), shall be punished by a fine of $100.00 for the first offense, and by a fine of not more than $1,000.00 for any subsequent offense, or imprisonment for not more than 30 days, or both. 
(Code 1987, § 11-116; Ord. No. 98-03-01, 4-14-98; Ord. No. 11-3-03, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 54-3. - Purpose. 
The purpose of the provisions contained in this chapter is to provide for the protection of the public health by prescribing the manner of storage, collection, transportation and disposal of residential and industrial waste, rubbish, garbage and refuse. 
(Code 1987, § 11-101) 
Sec. 54-4. - Depositing in street or public place. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to litter, throw, deposit, scatter or otherwise cause to be placed or left upon any vacant or unoccupied lot or lots, along any street or sidewalk or other public place within the city, any paper, wastes, rubbish, trimmings, limbs or garbage of any kind. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person utilizing any vehicle, moving or parked, to cause any paper, wastes, cartons, rubbish, feathers, gravel, earth, trimmings, limbs, or garbage of any kind to be littered, thrown, deposited or scattered upon any street, sidewalk or public place or any private property, occupied or unoccupied. Such precautions as are necessary to contain transported materials, including covering of open trucks, shall be utilized to prevent such littering and scattering. 
(Code 1987, § 11-112) 
Secs. 54-5—54-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MUNICIPAL COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL SERVICE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 54-26. - City responsibility for sanitation services. 
The city, by and through its proper departments, shall be responsible for sanitation services including the collection and disposal of all garbage, trash and other refuse within the city except as hereinafter set out in this chapter; provided, however, that residential or commercial classes may dispose of refuse from their premises. The city reserves the right to contract with its designee for commercial or residential solid waste pickup and removal service. 
(Code 1987, § 11-102; Ord. No. 98-03-01, 4-14-98) 
Sec. 54-27. - Deposit. 
If sanitation service is supplied to residential class A premises to which the city does not supply water service, a deposit equal to three times the applicable fee shall be made in advance of initiation of service. 
(Code 1987, § 11-110; Ord. No. 98-03-01, 4-14-98) 
Sec. 54-28. - Collection days designated. 
Garbage, trash and refuse shall be collected from residential class A premises by the proper departments of the city or as may be contracted by the city once per week. 
(Code 1987, § 11-104; Ord. No. 96-06-01, 7-15-96; Ord. No. 98-03-01, 4-14-98) 
Sec. 54-29. - Residential sanitary trash and garbage containers. 
(a)  Residential solid waste customers of the city shall provide sanitary containers in which trash, garbage or refuse shall be kept prior to collection by the sanitation department or designee. Such containers shall be constructed of rustproof, moistureproof material and shall be equipped with tight-fitting covers with handles. Such containers shall be restricted to a maximum capacity of 30 gallons in all residential areas and at any structure used for residential purposes, except as provided for in subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  Each Residential Class A customer shall provide at least one and not more than three such containers at a single collection point. 
(c)  Persons required to maintain such containers shall maintain them in a sanitary condition, tightly covered at all times except during filling, emptying and cleaning; free from odor; and such containers shall be filled in such manner as to allow pick up by one person, except when a standard hoist type container is used. Such container shall be further maintained so as to prevent the overflow or scattering of trash, garbage or refuse. 
(d)  Residential class B customers shall maintain containers in a sanitary condition, tightly covered at all times except during filling, emptying and cleaning; free from odor. Such container shall be further maintained so as to prevent the overflow or scattering of trash, garbage or refuse. 
(Code 1987, § 11-105; Ord. No. 98-03-01, 4-14-98) 
Sec. 54-30. - Commercial and industrial operations containers. 
All classes of commercial and industrial operations using containers shall maintain them in a sanitary condition, free from odor and shall prevent the overflow or scattering of trash, garbage or refuse on the premises, nearby properties or public streets and places. 
(Code 1987, § 11-106; Ord. No. 96-06-01, 7-15-96; Ord. No. 98-03-01, 4-14-98) 
Sec. 54-31. - Placement of refuse for pickup. 
(a)  All persons utilizing city pickup of trash or cuttings shall be required to place such cuttings, trimmings, leaves and tree limbs on their premises located as to be easily accessible to street pickup, but not including the street, sidewalk or properties other than the premises of the depositor. 
(b)  Each classification of refuse must be kept separate and will be picked up separately. 
(c)  All refuse resulting from building, repairing, remodeling or any kind of construction shall be moved by the contractor, owner of property or person having work done. The city shall not move refuse of this nature. All trees, limbs, bushes, trash, dirt and other refuse resulting from cleaning up or improving property shall be removed by the contractor, tree surgery company, owner of property, developer or person having work done. 
(d)  No person shall be allowed to place for collection limbs or cuttings greater than five feet in length or 50 pounds in weight. Cuttings, trimmings and leaves shall be placed in plastic bags and located as stated in subsection (a) of this section. 
(e)  The city shall schedule two clean up weeks annually, for pickup of limbs, leaves, general rubbish and grass trimmings, once in the spring and once in the fall at the discretion of the city. 
(f)  No person shall be allowed to deposit such trash, cuttings, trimmings, leaves or tree limbs for collection by the city in excess of the load equivalent of one four-yard dump truck per dwelling or business establishment per cleanup week, as provided in this chapter. Charges shall be levied for such pickup exceeding the above amounts, charges to be based upon total cost of such additional service as may be determined by the city sanitation department or designee. 
(g)  No person shall be allowed to deposit such trash, cuttings, trimmings, leaves or tree limbs on any public street, sidewalk or property. 
(h)  The city manager of the city is authorized and directed to develop and publish rules and regulations for the implementation of the services provided by the city under this section, and to supplement and amend same from time to time, so long as such rules and regulations are not inconsistent with the provisions of the Code of the city. Each such rule or regulation shall bear the effective date thereof, and the violation thereof shall be a misdemeanor under this Code. Any such rule or regulation may contain a schedule of fees developed by the city manager, however, any such fee shall not exceed the estimated approximate cost of the provision and administration of such service. Any such rules and regulations shall be presented to the city commission at the meeting next following the development, publishing, implementation, and effective date of such rules and regulations, for review. Upon commission review, any or all of such rules and regulations may be overruled by the commission, and upon such action, such rule or regulation is immediately revoked and repealed ab initio, and no later rule or regulation substantially similar therewith shall be permitted without express approval by the city commission. 
(Code 1987, § 11-113; Ord. No. 98-03-01, 4-14-98; Ord. No. 04-08-04, 9-21-04) 
Sec. 54-32. - Disposal of dead animals. 
The disposal of dead animals shall be in compliance with state and county health rules and regulations and any city ordinance hereinafter passed for the health and well-being of the citizens of the city. 
(Code 1987, § 11-114) 
Sec. 54-33. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 96-06-01, adopted July 15, 1996, amended the Code by repealing § 54-33 in its entirety. Former § 54-33 pertained to classification of residential premises, and derived from the Code of 1987, § 11-108. 
Sec. 54-34. - Solid waste disposal prohibited in city maintained trash barrels. 
(a)  Except for solid waste receptacles (trash barrels) provided by the city in public areas to accommodate disposal by tourism pedestrian traffic, no person or entity shall deposit solid waste except in approved collection receptacles and upon payment therefor, or upon specific expressed permission of the entity controlling the receptacles. 
(b)  No person or entity, who is not a visitor or tourism pedestrian, shall place solid waste in receptacles designed to collect immediately generated solid waste from visitors and tourists. 
(Ord. No. 95-03-01, 4-18-95; Ord. No. 98-03-01, 4-14-98) 
Secs. 54-35—54-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RATES AND CHARGES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference— Service charges authorized, § 6.15. 

Sec. 54-51. - Fee schedule. 
As needed, the city commission shall by resolution set the rates for monthly sanitation solid waste charges. 
Rates shall be classified as follows: 
Residential class A; 
Residential class B receptacle rates are restricted by applicable city contract with service providers; 
Convenience center rates; and 
Commercial receptacle rates are restricted by applicable city contract with service providers. 
(Code 1987, § 11-107; Ord. No. 90-1, § 11-103(3), 3-20-90; Ord. No. 96-06-01, 7-15-96; Ord. No. 98-03-01, 4-14-98) 
Sec. 54-52. - Nondesignated services. 
The city shall not be required to provide any services not stipulated in this chapter. However, should the city, in its discretion, determine to provide any service not provided for under any section of this chapter pertaining to the collection of garbage, trash and refuse, with a charge not specifically set out, a fee equal to the cost of the operation, including collection, transportation, and disposal, plus a ten percent service charge shall be charged. 
(Code 1987, § 11-115; Ord. No. 98-03-01, 4-14-98) 
Sec. 54-53. - Exclusive contractor for removal of solid waste. 
In order to protect the general welfare and safeguard the public health and infrastructure, no person or entity may contract with any person or entity, except that person or entity designated by contract with the city, for solid waste collection within the city. Nothing contained herein shall be construed to prohibit any person or entity from disposing of their own solid waste in a manner consistent with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1987, §§ 11-107, 11-110; Ord. No. 98-03-01, 4-14-98) 
Sec. 54-54. - Nonpayment of fees. 
Any person failing for any reason or refusing to pay the monthly sanitary and health charge for garbage pickup provided for in this chapter, after having been duly billed for same by the city, shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this chapter and all sanitary and health services and water service provided by the city to the premises for which the monthly charges are past due shall be terminated by the city. 
(Code 1987, § 11-111) 
Charter reference— Collection of delinquent fees, § 6.18. 
Chapter 58 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— General powers relative to streets, sidewalks and public places, § 1.13(11)—(13), (17), (32). 
Cross reference— Department of public works, § 2-126 et seq.; traffic and vehicles, ch. 66. 
State Law reference— General authority relative to streets, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, par. III(a)(4). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 58-1—58-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PARADES, DEMONSTRATIONS AND PICKETING 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 58-26. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Assembly means a group of two or more persons who are together for a common cause or purpose, who stand, walk, congregate or assemble upon any of the sidewalks, streets or public property of the city, who evidence their cause by signs, slogans, common dress, solicitation of money or membership, public speech, or the distribution of written materials. The solicitation by one or more persons for money, or membership in any organization or group, or the distribution of written materials for the solicitation of money or membership in any organization, or an advertising or sales promotion upon any of the sidewalks, streets, or public property of the city, is prohibited. 
Demonstration and picketing shall be given their usual meaning, but in any event, any such activity must first be defined as an "assembly" to be included in the context herein. 
Parade means any procession on a public street, excepting funerals and military activities, containing ten or more persons or five or more vehicles. 
(Code 1987, § 31-105) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 58-27. - Penalty. 
Anyone found guilty of violating any provision of this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-7. 
(Code 1987, § 31-109(1)) 
Sec. 58-28. - Appendixes adopted by reference. 
All appendixes referenced in this article are on file in the office of the city clerk and are hereby adopted by reference as if set out at length in this article. 
Sec. 58-29. - Conduct of activities. 
(a)  All activities under a permit issued pursuant to this article shall be conducted under the supervision of the person or persons making the application, and shall be conducted in a peaceful and orderly manner in compliance with the applicable laws and ordinances. 
(b)  In the conduct of such activities, no signs, shields or banners shall be placed or carried by any person upon the sidewalks of the city that extend beyond the width of the person's body, or that extend more than 24 inches above the person's head. Persons carrying any such signs, shields or banners shall be at least ten feet apart; shall not stand or loiter in front of any doorway, driveway or intersection; and shall not interfere with the general flow of traffic, whether pedestrian or vehicular. 
(Code 1987, § 31-104) 
Secs. 58-30—58-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 58-41. - Required; compliance with terms. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to promote, organize or hold, or to assist in promoting, organizing, or holding, or to take part or to participate in any parade, assembly, picketing or other public demonstration in the streets, on the sidewalks or other public areas of the city, unless a permit for it has been secured from the city clerk. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct a parade, assembly or demonstration or picketing at any time other than the time specified in the permit therefor. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct a parade, assembly or demonstration, or picketing along, upon or over any street, sidewalk or public area other than those set out in the permit issued as provided in this division. 
(Code 1987, § 31-107) 
Sec. 58-42. - Application; review and approval procedure. 
Any person desiring to stage a parade, demonstration or assembly, or engage in picketing, on the public streets, sidewalks or public area of the city, shall make application for a permit to the city clerk not later than 4:00 p.m. ten days prior to the day that such proposed activity is intended to be staged or carried out. Such application shall be filed with the city clerk in writing except that any application for activity on any of the state highways of the city must be filed 30 days prior to the planned activity. Such permit shall be granted only after review and approval by the city manager following consultation with the chief of police and the city attorney. The city manager shall be empowered to determine and reasonably restrict the time and duration of the proposed activity, the number of units or automobiles to be involved, the number of persons to participate in such activity, and the streets or locations where such activity shall be allowed, so as not to impair the health, safety, and convenience of the public in general (see Appendix A, on file in the office of the city clerk, application form). 
(Code 1987, § 31-101) 
Sec. 58-43. - Payment for additional expenses. 
After a review of the application for a permit to conduct a parade, assembly, demonstration or picketing activity, and as a condition precedent to the issuance of a permit for such activity, the applicant may be required to pay to the city any and all additional expenses incurred by the city for additional police protection, traffic control, and the expense of cleaning up the area in which the parade, assembly, demonstration or picketing activity is permitted to take place, if such extra expense is reasonably foreseeable. The city manager may require a cash deposit to be paid by the applicant in advance to defray such additional municipal expenses as herein set out. If no additional expenses are incurred by the city as a result of the parade, assembly, demonstration or picketing activity, or if only a portion of the deposit is utilized therefor, the city will refund to the applicant any excess funds held by the city. If the cash deposit is insufficient to defray such additional expenses, the applicant will be liable for the additional expenses as a debt owed to the city, and subject to payment. The applicant, upon accepting the permit from the city for the conduct of a parade, assembly, demonstration or picketing activity, expressly waives questions regarding jurisdiction and venue, and any civil action brought to collect any indebtedness owed for excess municipal expenses may be brought in the appropriate court in the county. 
(Code 1987, § 31-108) 
Sec. 58-44. - Considerations for receiving permit. 
The city manager shall consider at least the following factors before making a decision under this division (see Appendix B, approval form): 
(1)  Traffic densities involved on the streets or sidewalks during the time for which the permit is requested. 
(2)  Police and fire protection required and available at the time and place requested. 
(3)  Street and sidewalk condition in the area requested. 
(4)  Other public or private activities known to occur during the same time and place which would have an impact upon public safety and convenience. 
(5)  Sanitary facilities available in the area requested. 
(6)  Noise impact analysis for the time and area requested. 
(7)  Any other matter which is likely to affect the public order, safety, health or welfare of the citizens, including those people participating in the activity. 
(Code 1987, § 31-102) 
Sec. 58-45. - Number of permits. 
An application and permit under this division shall be required for each such activity; provided, however, only one application and permit shall be required for each proposed parade, demonstration, assembly or picketing site and the picketing (see Appendix C, receipt of permit form). 
(Code 1987, § 31-103) 
Sec. 58-46. - Permit from DOT. 
Parades which are scheduled to pass over or cross any of the state highways which pass through the city must also be given permits by the department of transportation of the state. It shall be the applicant's responsibility to obtain the correct permit from the state department of transportation. No city permit will be issued without a state department of transportation permit having been first obtained. 
(Code 1987, § 31-106) 
Sec. 58-47. - Revocation. 
If any participants, during the course of the permitted activity, breach any law of the United States, the state or any ordinance of the city, and an arrest is made or citation is issued, the permit may be immediately revoked by the chief of police or senior police officer on duty, and the activity shall cease immediately. 
(Code 1987, § 31-109(2)) 
Secs. 58-48—58-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - STREET NAMING AND STRUCTURE NUMBERING SYSTEM[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 94-02-01, adopted March 15, 1994, amended the Code by the addition of provisions which have been codified herein at the discretion of the editor as Art. III, §§ 58-101—58-111. 
Cross reference— Design and construction standards for streets, § 34-651 et seq. 

Sec. 58-101. - Short title. 
This article shall be further referred to as the "Street Naming and Structure Numbering System." 
(Ord. No. 94-02-01, Art. I, 3-15-94) 
Sec. 58-102. - Designation of street and road names and numbers. 
Streets and roads now being maintained by the City of Helen and other public agencies within incorporated Helen shall in the future be named and numbered as now designated on the Official Map and Official Index of the City of Helen as amended by each implementing ordinance. Every other street and road within incorporated Helen shown on the Official Index shall hereafter be referred to as designated on the Official Index for structure numbering purposes. 
(Ord. No. 94-02-01, Art. II, 3-15-94) 
Sec. 58-103. - Designation of structure numbers. 
(a)  Structure numbers for dwelling units, places of business, industrial locations and all other structures and uses requiring same shall be assigned by: 
(1)  The Planning Department of White County and the Helen Public Works Department in conjunction with the United States Postal Service during the implementation stage of the system; and 
(2)  The Planning Department of White County and the Helen Public Works Department following the implementation phase of the system in each area of the incorporated area of the city. 
(b)  The planning department shall keep a record of all numbers assigned under this article. Such records may be maintained in data processing storage systems if so desired. 
(Ord. No. 94-02-01, Art. III, 3-15-94) 
Sec. 58-104. - Posting of designated structure numbers. 
(a)  The owner or occupant or person in charge of any dwelling unit, structure or use to which a number has been assigned, shall be notified in writing by the White County Planning Department in conjunction with the City of Helen Public Works Department of the number assigned to the same at any time after adoption of this article. 
(b)  Within 60 days after receipt of such written notification, the owner, occupant, or person in charge of any dwelling unit, structure, or use to which a number has been assigned, shall cause the same to be posted in either one or two locations depending upon the following conditions: 
(1)  If the mailbox is located on the same side of the street and adjacent to the driveway or curb cut, the number shall be affixed to the mailbox in letters two inches in height, but no larger than six inches in height, and of a color contrasting with the color of the mailbox. This section does not preclude an individual from also numbering the front entrance of the structure if so desired. 
(2)  If the mailbox is not on the same side of the street and adjacent to the driveway or curb cut, the number shall be posted at two locations: 
a.  On the mailbox as prescribed by U.S. Postal Service Regulations; and 
b.  Either on the structure front if visible from the street, or on an above-ground sign attached to a post or other object at the driveway or curb cut. The numbers shall be two inches in height, but no larger than six inches in height, and of a color contrasting with the color of the background. This section does not preclude an individual from also numbering the front entrance of his structure if so desired. 
(c)  In the case that a building is served by two or more driveways or curb cuts, the number shall be assigned and posted to the front entrance or driveway. 
(d)  It shall be the duty of the owner, occupant, or person in charge of the dwelling unit, structure or use, upon affixing the new number, to remove any different number which might be mistaken for or confused with the number assigned to the structure. 
(e)  In such cases where the assigned number cannot be posted as required above or no mailbox exists, the number shall be posted as prescribed by the city public works director after consultation with the owner. The city public works director is hereby directed to develop a written policy on the placement of structure numbers for all buildings not maintaining a mailbox. 
(f)  All structure numbers, for commercial buildings, erected pursuant to this article are to have a Germanic design, as prescribed in a written policy issued by the city planning and design review board. 
(Ord. No. 94-02-01, Art. IV, 3-15-94) 
Sec. 58-105. - Types of numbers. 
Two types of numbers are used under this article: 
(1)  A primary number to be assigned to each street frontage of each parcel of land, whether or not the parcel is occupied. The primary number is required to be posted only if the parcel is occupied by a dwelling unit, structure or active use and the owner, occupant or person in charge is notified under section 58-104(a) of this article. Other primary numbers are reserved for future development of the numbered parcels and will be assigned at the time of development. 
(2)  Secondary numbers may be used when a number of units, structures and uses co-exist on the same parcel of land.
