Examples of parcels requiring secondary numbers include apartment projects, condominium projects, mobile home parks, office parks, planned unit developments, recreational vehicle parks, recreational areas, shopping centers, and other uses where the use of secondary numbers would clarify the location of a unit or be used for public safety purposes. To provide secondary numbers, the White County Planning Department and the city public works director shall work with the owner, manager, or person in charge of the project to determine a logical numbering system under the following guidelines: 
a.  Existing numbered units and uses shall retain the present set of addresses with only the primary number being changed if the primary number is not in sequence with the overall system. 
b.  Buildings on a single parcel with more than one and less than five units may be given either letter (preferred) or number designations as requested by the owner. 
c.  A single building on a single parcel of land and with five or more units may be given numerical designations such as Suite 5, Apartment 5, etc., if so desired. 
d.  Multiple buildings on the same parcel of land may be given secondary numbers consisting of number designations if the buildings are accessed from a main entrance to the project. Generally the number designations should increase in a clockwise direction from the main entrance. 
e.  Recreational vehicle parks, and similar uses shall be given letter designations for lots or sections and number designations for individual lots or sites. 
(Ord. No. 94-02-01, Art. V, 3-15-94) 
Sec. 58-106. - Exempt and excluded structures. 
(a)  The intent of this article is to exclude from this article those structures that do not present a significant danger to human life if destroyed by a fire or other events. 
(b)  The following structures shall be excluded from the provisions: 
(1)  Agricultural buildings not requiring a separate mailing address such as a barn, poultry house, outbuildings, or equipment storage buildings. Buildings used as dwelling units, offices, or the normal work station of an employee shall not be exempt. 
(2)  Storage and accessory buildings for the use of the occupant of another building on the property. Buildings used as dwelling units, offices, or the normal work station of an employee, or requiring a separate mailing address, shall not be exempt. 
(Ord. No. 94-02-01, Art. VI, 3-15-94) 
Sec. 58-107. - New structure and lots. 
(a)  Structure numbers will be assigned to each new lot, tract or building site on the original drawings of a final subdivision plat, recreational vehicle park plan, planned unit development, or other plan requiring the approval of the city public works director. 
(b)  No building, electrical, plumbing or mechanical permit for any new or remodeled or repaired structure will be issued by the public works director of the city, following the implementation of this article in the affected area of the city until the owner, developer, or builder has procured from the city public works director the official structure number or numbers. Final approval for a certificate of occupancy of any principal building erected or repaired, or use requiring said number, shall be withheld until permanent and proper numbers have been displayed in accordance with the standards of this article. 
(Ord. No. 94-02-01, Art. VII, 3-15-94) 
Sec. 58-108. - Utility company compliance. 
(a)  Following the implementation of this article in any area of the city, all utility services regulated by the state public service commission or any utility cooperative service organization, shall withhold service from any building until the owner or other requesting party has furnished the utility with a valid structure number. 
(b)  It shall be the responsibility of the city public works director to notify each affected utility service of each implementation area by issuing maps and lists of official numbers assigned each structure or use. 
(Ord. No. 94-02-01, Art. VIII, 3-15-94) 
Sec. 58-109. - Implementation by city departments. 
Every department and official under the jurisdiction of the city manager shall not render any non-emergency service until the occupant, owner, or requesting individual has provided the department with a valid structure number. Non-emergency service includes any service provided by the city manager except fire, rescue, law enforcement, or emergency medical service. 
(Ord. No. 94-02-01, Art. IX, 3-15-94) 
Sec. 58-110. - Penalties. 
Any firm, person, or corporation who shall do anything prohibited by this article as the same exists or as it may hereafter be amended or who shall fail to do anything required by this article as the same exists or as it may hereafter be amended shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, amenable to the process of the municipal court of the city, and, upon conviction, shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 or by confinement in the county jail or correctional institution not to exceed 60 days, either fine or confinement, or both, in the discretion of the court. Each and every day that such violation exists shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 94-02-01, Art. X, 3-15-94; Ord. No. 11-3-03, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 58-111. - Effective date and repealer. 
(a)  This article shall be implemented upon the date of adoption, and shall be in full force and effect. 
(b)  All ordinances and parts of ordinances in conflict with this article are repealed upon enactment of this article. 
(Ord. No. 94-02-01, Art. XI, 3-15-94) 
Sec. 58-112—58-400. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CONDITIONS FOR USE OF MARKET PLATZ, CITY PARKS, AND BAND SHELL[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 10-03-01, adopted Apr. 6, 2010, repealed former Art. IV, §§ 58-401—58-409, and enacted a new article as set out herein. The former article pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 05-08-01, 8-16-05; Ord. No. 06-07-01, 8-1-06. 

Sec. 58-401. - Short title and purpose. 
This article shall be further referred to as the "Conditions for Use of Market Platz, City Parks, and Band Shell." The City of Helen recognizes that the City Band Shell and Market Platz area benefits the city by providing a place for musical entertainment and special events; contributing to the enjoyment of visitors to the city and to the economy of the area. At the same time, the city is aware of the need to insure the peace and privacy for residents and businesses in the area surrounding the band shell. 
(Ord. No. 10-03-01, 4-6-10) 
Sec. 58-402. - Market Platz defined. 
The Market Platz is that triangular shaped pedestrian area of the downtown city lying on the southerly side of State Highway 75, bounded by State Highway 75, River Street, and a row of privately owned shops, and containing a structures commonly referred to as the "band shell," and fountain. 
(Ord. No. 10-03-01, 4-6-10) 
Sec. 58-403. - Market Platz performance area defined. 
The Market Platz performance area is that area of the Market Platz bounded: easterly by the rear of the band shell; southerly by the northerly rock face, and rock face extended, of a planter; westerly by the easterly rock face, and rock face extended, of a planter located directly behind the benches placed for band shell seating; and northerly by the southerly rock face, and rock face extended through a walkway, of a wall near Main Street. Less and except from those boundaries is the walkway lying immediately northerly of the band shell and the planter lying immediately southerly of the band shell. 
(Ord. No. 10-03-01, 4-6-10) 
Sec. 58-404. - Reservation of band shell; permits required for performance in band shell; use of band shell; reservation of performance periods; conditions; exceptions; limitations. 
(a)  Reservations for events or performances shall be on a first-come, first-serve basis; however, events or performers reserved by the City of Helen, Alpine Helen/White County Convention and Visitors Bureau or the Helen Chamber of Commerce receive priority in reservation of the Market Platz performance area and band shell, until reservations are opened to the public. 
(b)  Reservation of the band shell includes uses of the band shell, but does not include the remainder of the Market Platz area. This area remains open to the public. 
(c)  Permits are required in order to provide performers with the exclusive right to perform, during designated periods, within the Market Platz performance area and to use the band shell itself; 
(d)  Performance times shall be scheduled on a daily basis beginning with the first performance. The period for performances shall be between 10:00 a.m., and 9:30 p.m.; with the last performance of the day concluding no later than 9:30 p.m. 
(e)  Each performance period shall begin on the hour and end upon the half hour or shall begin on the half hour and end on the hour; other than events or performers reserved by the City of Helen, Alpine Helen/White County Convention and Visitors Bureau, or the Helen Chamber of Commerce which may be of longer duration. 
(f)  Performers must be present at least 15 minutes prior to, and begin set up no earlier than 15 minutes prior to, the applicable performance period, and must complete removal within 15 minutes following the applicable performance time, unless the same performer is permitted for consecutive performance times, in which event no removal shall be required between consecutively scheduled performance times. 
(g)  During set up and removal, no audible testing of equipment, voice, amplification, or tuning shall be allowed. 
(h)  For the calendar period beginning Thanksgiving Day and continuing through Christmas Day, performers may reserve, at any time during the 12 months prior to the requested date, a maximum of two performance periods each day. 
(i)  For times other than the calendar period beginning Thanksgiving Day and continuing through Christmas Day, performers may reserve, at any time during the six months prior to the requested date, a maximum of four performance periods each day with a maximum of 12 performance periods in any one month. 
(j)  The permit may not be transferred or assigned. 
(k)  Each performer shall be conclusively presumed to have inspected the entirety of the Market Platz performance area, and found same to be acceptable for their purpose, "as is," without any warranty whatsoever, and without any representation, warranty, or covenant as to fitness for any purpose. 
(l)  No performer shall use any public utility prior to the first daily performance period and following the last daily performance period. 
(m)  Each performer, and any and all persons associated in any manner with the performer, shall be conclusively presumed to have received, acknowledged, executed, and agreed to hold harmless and indemnify the city, their commissioners, agents, employees, officers, directors, and any person or persons acting in concert with them, from and against any and all liability, cost, expense, and damages, direct or indirect, foreseen or unforeseen, related to, or in any manner arising from, the performance by the performer. 
(n)  If a performer or performers desire an amplified performance, the city amplification system must be used. No outside speakers or amplification is permitted. 
(Ord. No. 10-03-01, 4-6-10) 
Sec. 58-405. - By whom permits are to be issued. 
The entity charged with the responsibility of issuing permits for the use of the Market Platz performance area and band shell shall be that entity with whom the city has contracted for the promotion of tourism within the city. 
(Ord. No. 10-03-01, 4-6-10) 
Editor's note— At the time of the passage of Ordinance No. 10-03-01, that entity is the Alpine Helen/White County Convention and Visitors Bureau. 
Sec. 58-406. - Prohibited activities within the Market Platz and city parks. 
The following activities are prohibited within the Market Platz and city parks: 
(1)  Any activity in violation of federal, state, county or city laws, ordinances, rules, and regulations, or of these conditions. Any performers, by use of the Market Platz, Market Platz performance area, or city parks shall be conclusively presumed to have actual knowledge of all such laws, ordinances, rules and regulations, and of these conditions, including, in particular, and without limitation, noise ordinances; and 
(2)  Any performance other than a solely gratuitous performance. However, so long as it is not violative of these conditions, performers may accept voluntary contributions or donations, provided also that no amount of contribution or donation may be specified, urged, suggested or commented on. 
(Ord. No. 10-03-01, 4-6-10) 
Sec. 58-407. - Prohibited activities within the Market Platz. 
The following activities within the Market Platz are prohibited: 
(1)  Open flames; 
(2)  Dispersing of any liquids; 
(3)  Unreasonable obstruction of pedestrian traffic to businesses; 
(4)  Any electronically amplified sound except when originating from the band shell or speakers provided by the city; 
(5)  Use of profanity; and 
(6)  Consumption of alcohol or display of alcoholic beverages. 
(7)  Use of any animal or bird to perform in the Market Platz area which may leave excrement causing unsanitary conditions, littering of the sidewalks or causing damage to the landscaping or other city property; or the use of any animal or bird in a performance which can create a biting or scratching hazard to the public. 
(8)  Use of the city planters at the Market Platz area for any type of display or signage. 
(Ord. No. 10-03-01, 4-6-10; Ord. No. 13-06-02, 7-16-13) 
Sec. 58-408. - Rules and regulations. 
The city manager may adopt and publish such additional rules and regulations for use of the Market Platz and city parks as may be consistent with this article, and such shall have the effect of law. However, no such rules or regulations shall be effective until reviewed for comment by the city commission, and published and made available to the public at city hall. All such rules and regulations shall be published in a single volume, in a reasonable organizational manner, and revised not later than 60 days following any change thereto. The city commission may, by vote, abolish any or all of such rules and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 10-03-01, 4-6-10) 
Editor's note— At the time of the passage of Ordinance No. 10-03-01, a City of Helen Band Shell Usage Policy and Application for use pursuant to section 58-405 was reviewed for comment by the city commission, published and made available to the public at City Hall. 
Sec. 58-409. - Penalties. 
Any firm, person, or corporation who shall do anything prohibited by this article as the same exists or as it may hereafter be amended or who shall fail to do anything required by this article as the same exists or as it may hereafter be amended shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, amenable to the process of the municipal court of the city, and, upon conviction, shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 or by confinement in the county jail or correctional institution not to exceed 60 days, either fine or confinement, or both, in the discretion of the court. Each and every day that such violation exists shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 10-03-01, 4-6-10) 
Sec. 58-410. - Security deposit for use of band shell 
A refundable security deposit of $100.00 shall be paid with the reservation for any event, performance or performances in the band shell. Upon request by applicant, the deposit may be retained by the Alpine Helen/White County Convention and Visitors Bureau as the required deposit for future reservations, or it will be refunded within two weeks of a written request following the event, performance or performances except under the following circumstances. 
(1)  There is damage to the facility or grounds of the band shell. Applicant shall be held liable for all damages that occur during the reservation period. Applicant will be billed for all damages in excess of the damage deposit. 
(2)  The band shell and surrounding area is not left in a clean condition at the conclusion of the performance. 
(Ord. No. 10-03-01, 4-6-10) 
Sec. 58-411. - Revocation of permit. 
The city shall have the authority to revoke any permit upon violation of any conditions in this section or where staging of the event would have an immediate and adverse effect on the welfare and safety of persons or property. The chief of police shall have the authority to close any event immediately upon violation of conditions set forth herein or to preserve the safety of persons or property. 
(Ord. No. 10-03-01, 4-6-10) 
Secs. 58-412—58-500. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PROTECTION OF SIDEWALKS, STREETS, PUBLIC PLACES, PUBLIC PROPERTY, AND PUBLIC RIGHTS-OF-WAY 

Sec. 58-501. - Throwing, depositing, or disposing of garbage, trash, yard trimmings, leaves, or other solid waste upon the sidewalks, streets, public places, public property and public rights-of-way. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, deposit, sweep, blow or discard debris, garbage, litter, trash, yard trimmings, leaves or other solid waste upon the streets, sidewalks, public places, public property and public rights-of-way within the city. 
(Ord. No. 05-12-01, 12-20-05) 
Sec. 58-502. - Transporting garbage, trash, solid waste, or other material in open vehicles; spills from motor vehicles. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or cause to be operated upon any public street in the city any open truck, trailer, wagon or other motor vehicle in and upon which garbage, trash, manure, solid waste material, other debris, or materials are transported, unless the vehicle shall be equipped with a cover or other securing device that will prevent the garbage, trash, waste material, other debris or other material from falling from the truck onto the streets of the city. 
(b)  In the event that spillage does occur in spite of the appropriate use of said devices, the person responsible for the operation of the vehicle shall take immediate action to remove the material from the street or sidewalk. Shoveling, sweeping, or vacuuming the material and removing it from the roadway is an appropriate response. 
(Ord. No. 05-12-01, 12-20-05) 
Sec. 58-503. - Spills from vehicles; concrete, cement, gravel, sand, dirt, and asphalt hauling. 
(a)  Any person engaged in hauling concrete, cement, gravel, sand, dirt, asphalt or any other material on any public streets within the corporate limits of the city shall load or fill vehicles so as not to allow spillage of any material onto the city streets or sidewalks. All vehicles hauling wet concrete, cement or loose material, are required to use suitable covers, spill prevention and capture devices to prevent materials from blowing, spilling, or dripping from the vehicle. 
(b)  In the event that spillage does occur in spite of the appropriate use of said devises, the person responsible for the operation of the vehicle shall remove the material from the street or sidewalk. Shoveling, sweeping, or vacuuming the material and removing it from the roadway is an appropriate response. 
(Ord. No. 05-12-01, 12-20-05) 
Sec. 58-504. - Defacing city sidewalks, streets, public places, public property and public rights-of-way. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to perform the act of nailing, tacking, posting, gluing, painting, stapling, marking or writing upon the surface of any street, sidewalk, public place, public property and public rights-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 05-12-01, 12-20-05) 
Sec. 58-505. - Penalties. 
Anyone found guilty of violating any provision of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, amenable to the process of the municipal court of the city, and, upon conviction, shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 or by confinement in the county jail or correctional institution not to exceed 60 days, either fine or confinement, or both, in the discretion of the court. Each and every day that such violation exists shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 05-12-01, 12-20-05; Ord. No. 11-3-01, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 58-506. - Types of alcohol possession and consumption prohibited above city sidewalks, public places, public property and public rights-of-way. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose and intent of this section is to protect the health, safety and welfare of Helen's citizens and visitors through the prohibition of the possession and consumption of alcoholic beverages in those second story open air locations in which the possession and consumption of such those alcoholic beverages, by virtue of being possessed and consumed on a second story deck, pavilion or other such open air facility, and that are located in direct proximity to city sidewalks, public places, public property, or public rights-of-way creates safety hazards to the citizens and visitors of Helen, and problems regarding trash, spillage, and other issues detrimental to the city's image and overall economic well being. 
(b)  Definitions. 
(1)  Second story decks, pavilions and open air facilities are defined as decks, pavilions or other open air gathering places, which are located on the second story (or higher) above ground level. 
(2)  Adjacent to a city sidewalk is defined as a location in which the closest structural side of a second story deck, pavilion, or other open air structure is within ten linear yards of the city sidewalk at its closest point. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to possess or consume alcoholic beverages contained in either a bottle, can, or any other type of container other than a styrofoam or flexible plastic cup no larger than 18 ounces; upon any second story deck, pavilion, or other open air facility that is adjacent to a city sidewalk, or is directly located over any area in which either the public may be located or which is the public entryway into the first floor of a building. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any business within the City of Helen, Georgia to permit patrons to possess or consume alcoholic beverages other than in a flexible plastic or styrofoam cup no larger than 18 ounces; or to serve patrons alcoholic beverages other than in a plastic cup; for the consumption upon any second story deck, pavilion or other open air facility that is adjacent to a city sidewalk, or directly located over any area in which either the public may be located or which is the public entryway into the first floor of a building. 
(e)  No beverage of any type shall be permitted to be set, placed or held over the railing, floor, or edge of the second story deck, pavilion or other open air facility as these structures overhang or are directly located over any area in which either the public may be located or which is the public entryway into the first floor of a building. 
(Ord. No. 11-03-04, 4-5-2011) 
Chapter 62 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Taxation authority, § 1.13(1), (2). 
Cross reference— Finance, § 2-201 et seq.; malt beverage excise tax, § 6-51; wine excise tax, § 6-101; distilled spirits excise tax, § 6-151; distilled spirits by the drink excise tax, § 6-152; businesses, ch. 14. 
State Law reference— Constitutional grant of home rule powers, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II; statutory grant of home rule powers, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-1 et seq.; revenue and taxation generally, O.C.G.A. § 48-1-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 62-1—62-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - AD VALOREM TAXATION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference— Authority to levy, assess and collect ad valorem taxes, § 1.13(1). 
State Law reference— Municipal ad valorem taxation, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-350 et seq. 

Sec. 62-26. - When due and payable. 
Ad valorem taxes shall become due on December 20 each year and shall be deemed delinquent if not paid within 30 days after the due date. Tax bills showing the assessed valuations, amount of taxes due, tax due dates and information as to delinquency dates and penalties shall be sent to all taxpayers at least 30 days prior to the due date, but failure to send a tax bill shall not invalidate any tax. Delinquent taxes shall bear interest at one percent per month from the due date. 
(Code 1987, § 4-101(4)) 
Charter reference— Collection of delinquent taxes, § 6.18. 
Sec. 62-27. - Failure to pay tax. 
The city shall forthwith issue an execution against any person who has defaulted in the payment of any ad valorem tax to be paid. The execution thus issued shall be a lien on all the property of such person, both real and personal, and shall be placed in the hands of the city officer responsible for collection by levy and sale. 
(Code 1987, § 4-101(5)) 
Sec. 62-28. - Judicial in rem tax foreclosure. 
The city commission, by majority vote, on each delinquent municipal tax case may authorize the city attorney to use judicial in rem tax foreclosure in accordance with O.C.G.A. Section 48-4-76. 
At any time in the calendar year, the city manager may propose a delinquent municipal tax case to the city commission at an official meeting for their consideration of the foreclosure on the property. The city attorney will follow the laws of the state to effect the foreclosure procedure. 
(Ord. No. 96-09-04, 10-15-96) 
Secs. 62-29—62-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - HOTEL-MOTEL EXCISE TAX[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Lodging tax, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50 et seq. 

Sec. 62-51. - Levy. 
There is hereby levied, pursuant to O.C.G.A. 48-13-51(b)(2), an excise tax at the rate of eight percent of the rent paid for the occupancy of any room or rooms, lodging or accommodations, furnished by any person or legal entity licensed by, or required to pay business or occupation taxes to, the city for operating a hotel, motel, inn, lodge, tourist camp, tourist cabin, or any other place in which rooms, lodgings or accommodations are regularly furnished for value. No tax shall be levied as provided in this section upon the fees or charges for any rooms, lodgings or accommodations furnished for a period of more than ten consecutive days or for use as meeting rooms. No tax shall be levied as provided in this section upon the fees or charges for any rooms, lodgings or accommodations furnished for a period of one or more consecutive days for use by state or local government officials or employees when traveling on official business. 
(Code 1987, § 4-108(1); Ord. No. 05-07-03, 8-16-05; Ord. No. 09-05-01, 5-19-09) 
Sec. 62-52. - Collection by operator. 
It shall be the duty of every operator of any establishment covered by section 62-51 located within the city to collect the tax on occupants as imposed in section 62-51. 
(Code 1987, § 4-108(2)) 
Sec. 62-53. - Registration of operator. 
(a)  Every person engaging in, or about to engage in, business in the city as an operator of any establishment covered by section 62-51 shall immediately register the business with the city manager, on a form provided by the city manager for such purpose. The required registration hereunder shall set forth the name under which the operator transacts business or intends to transact business, the location of the place or places of business, and such other information as would facilitate the collection of the tax by the city manager. The registration shall be signed by the owner if a natural person; by a member or partner in case of ownership by an association or partnership; or by an officer in the case of ownership by a corporation. 
(b)  A separate registration shall be required for each place of business of an operator. 
(Code 1987, § 4-108(3)) 
Sec. 62-54. - Certificate of taxing authority. 
Upon the registration of an operator as provided in section 62-53, the city manager shall issue to such operator without charge a certificate of authority to collect the tax on occupants. Each certificate shall state the name and location of the business to which it relates. 
(Code 1987, § 4-108(4)) 
Sec. 62-55. - Due date, filing of return. 
All taxes levied by this article shall be due and payable to the city manager monthly on or before the 20th day of every month next succeeding each respective month in which such taxes are collected. Payment shall be accompanied by a return for the preceding monthly period showing the gross rent, rent from permanent residents, taxable rent, amount of tax collected or otherwise due for the period, and such other information as may be required by the city manager. 
(Code 1987, § 4-108(5)) 
Sec. 62-56. - Collection fee allowed operators. 
Operators collecting the tax levied under this article shall be allowed a percentage of the tax due and accounted for and shall be reimbursed in the form of a deduction for submitting, reporting, and payment of the amount due, if said amount is not delinquent at the time of payment. The rate of the deduction shall be the same rate authorized by O.C.G.A., § 48-8-52. 
(Code 1987, § 4-108(6); Ord. No. 16-08-01 , 9-6-16) 
State Law reference— Commission for collecting tax, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-52. 
Sec. 62-57. - Determination if no return made. 
If any operator fails to file a return as required under the provisions of this article, the city manager shall make an estimate of the amount of gross rentals which are subject to the tax. The estimate shall be made for the period or periods in which the operator failed to file the return and shall be based upon any information which is or may come into the possession of the city manager. Notice, interest, and penalty are as follows: 
(1)  Notice of determination. The city manager or designated representative shall give to the operator written notice of his determination as herein provided. The notice may be served personally or by mail; if by mail such service shall be addressed to the operator at his address as it appears in the records of the city manager. Service by mail is complete when delivered by certified mail with a receipt signed by the addressee. 
(2)  Interest on amount found due. Amounts found due shall bear interest at an annual rate equal to the bank prime loan rate as posted by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System in statistical release H. 15 or any publication that may supersede it, plus three percent, to accrue monthly. Such annual interest rate shall be determined for each calendar year based on the first weekly posting of statistical release H. 15 on or after January 1 of each calendar year. Interest shall begin to accrue from the 20th day of the month following the monthly period, for which the amount or any portion thereof should have been returned, until the date of payment. 
(3)  Specific penalty. The specific penalty shall be five percent of the tax due or $5.00 whichever is greater for each 30 days or fraction thereof of delinquency, not to exceed 25 percent or $25.00 in the aggregate, whichever is greater. 
(Code 1987, § 4-108(7); Ord. No. 16-8-01 , 9-6-16) 
Charter reference— Collection of delinquent taxes, § 6.18. 
State Law reference— Rate of interest on past due taxes, O.C.G.A., § 48-2-40. 
Sec. 62-58. - Required records. 
Each operator collecting a tax under the provisions of this article shall keep for a period of at least three years all records, receipts, invoices, and other pertinent papers setting forth the rental charged for each occupancy, the date or dates of occupancy, and such other information as the city manager may require. 
(Code 1987, § 4-108(8)) 
Sec. 62-59. - Administration and enforcement. 
The city manager shall administer and enforce the provisions of this article for the collection of the tax herein imposed, and in so doing shall have the power to: 
(1)  Examine, or authorize the examination of, books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment, and other facilities of any operator renting guest rooms to persons subject to the tax, in order to verify the accuracy of any return made, or if no return is made by the operator, to ascertain and determine the amount required to be paid. 
(2)  Require the filing of reports by any person or persons having in their possession or custody information relating to rentals of guest rooms which are subject to the tax herein levied. 
(3)  Allow a credit on any amount due and payable from persons who paid the tax herein levied but who were erroneously or illegally subjected thereto. 
(Code 1987, § 4-108(9)) 
Sec. 62-60. - Action for collection of tax. 
At any time within three years after any tax or any portion of the tax required to be collected pursuant to this article becomes due and payable, the city attorney may bring an action in a court of competent jurisdiction in the name of the city to collect such amount due together with interest, court fees, filing fees, attorney's fees and other legal fees incident thereto. 
(Code 1987, § 4-108(10)) 
Sec. 62-61. - Successors or assignees of operator. 
If any operator becomes liable for any amount required to be paid by this article and subsequent thereto sells out or quits the business, the successors or assignees of such operator shall withhold a sufficient amount of the purchase price to cover such amount due. If the purchaser of the business fails to withhold the required amount, he shall become personally liable therefor to the extent of the purchase price. 
(Code 1987, § 4-108(11)) 
Sec. 62-62. - Penalty. 
Any operator or other person who fails to register as required in this article, or who fails to furnish any return required to be made, or who fails or refuses to furnish a supplemental return or other data required by the city manager, or who renders a false or fraudulent return shall be deemed guilty of an offense and upon conviction therefor shall be punished as provided in section 1-7. 
(Code 1987, § 4-108(12))

Chapter 67 - HORSE-DRAWN CARRIAGES FOR HIRE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 14; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 58; traffic and vehicles, ch. 66. 

Sec. 67-1. - Short title and definitions. 
(a)  Short title. This chapter shall be known and recited as "The Horse-Drawn Carriages for Hire Ordinance." 
(b)  Definitions. 
(1)  City. The word "city" shall mean the City of Helen, Georgia. 
(2)  Horse drawn carriage. Any hack or carriage which is operated by being drawn by a horse, mule or other beast of burden, for the transportation for hire of passengers. 
(3)  License. The right and privilege granted by the city for the operation of a business incorporating the use of a single horse drawn carriage within the corporate limits of the city. Also, the document evidencing same. 
(4)  Company. The holder of a license to operate a horse drawn carriage business under the provisions of this chapter whether a person, firm, partnership or corporation. 
(5)  Driver. Any person who drives or operates a horse drawn carriage on the streets of the city for a licensed company. 
(6)  Driver's permit. The written document issued by the city identifying an individual driving or operating a horse drawn carriage for a designated licensed company within the city. 
(7)  Street. The word "street" shall mean and include any street, alley, lane, avenue, court or public place in the city. 
(8)  Inspector (city manager or his designee). The individual employee or organizational unit of the city charged with the responsibility for enforcing this chapter, except for specific responsibilities otherwise provided herein. 
(9)  Stand. A public place alongside the curb of a street or elsewhere which has been designated by the city manager for the use (exclusively or nonexclusively), of horse drawn carriage. 
(10)  Draft animal. A horse, mule or other beast of burden, used for the drawing of horse drawn carriage. 
(11)  Draft animal's permit. The written document issued by the city identifying a draft animal drawing a horse drawn carriage for a designated licensed company within the city. 
(Ord. No. 99-12-02, 12-2-8-99) 
Sec. 67-2. - Licensing of horse-drawn carriage companies; headquarters. 
(a)  License required. 
(1)  No person, firm, corporation, or entity shall operate a business involving the use of a horse-drawn carriage on the streets of the city unless the current year's occupational tax has been paid in accordance with chapter 14 of the City Code, and a license for such business has first been granted by the city pursuant to the provisions contained here in chapter 67. The license shall be effective for only a single carriage, and only for the calendar year stated in the license, unless suspended or revoked sooner as provided by ordinance. 
(2)  Any person, firm, corporation, or legal entity desiring a license required by this section shall submit an application in writing to the city manager on a form to be furnished by the city manager. The application shall be made under oath and shall contain, at a minimum, the following information: 
a.  The legal name of the applicant; 
b.  The trade name, if applicable, under which the applicant is to operate; 
c.  All persons having an beneficial interest in the applicant greater than five percent; 
d.  Mailing and physical address of applicant; 
e.  The name and address of a contact person for all purposes under this chapter; 
f.  The number required to be affixed to the carriage pursuant to this chapter; 
g.  The passenger capacity of the vehicle; and 
h.  A photograph of the carriage for which license is applied. 
(b)  License fee. Before any license is granted under this section, an impact, enforcement, and administrative fee for the licensed activity in the amount of $130.00 shall be paid by the applicant. 
(c)  License to be displayed in horse-drawn carriage. The license issued under the provisions of this section shall be placed on display in the horse-drawn carriage, where the license will be in clear view of the passengers at all times when the horse-drawn carriage is for hire. 
(d)  Alteration of license prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person willfully to alter, deface, obliterate or destroy a horse-drawn carriage license, or cause or allow the same. 
(e)  Multiple licenses allowable. It shall be permissible for any applicant to hold multiple licenses, and they shall be required to obtain multiple licenses to operate separate carriages. 
(f)  License not transferable. Any horse-drawn carriage license issued under this section is not transferable, either from entity to entity, or from carriage to carriage, and is to be used solely by the applicant to whom issued, and solely for the carriage identified upon the license. 
(g)  Duration of permit. Any horse-drawn carriage license shall be valid for that calendar year. License may be renewed, upon application and payment of the required fee. 
(h)  Operating regulations. In addition to the license requirements imposed herein, each license holder shall be responsible for the following operating regulations: 
(1)  Compliance with all laws cited as the "Humane Care for Equines Act" O.C.G.A., Title 4, Section 1, Chapter 13, as well as all other state and federal laws and regulations governing equines and humane treatment of animals. 
(2)  No one animal may be worked more than eight hours per day. 
(3)  No draft animal shall be permitted to pull a horse-drawn carriage when the outside temperature exceeds 90 degrees Fahrenheit. The temperature reading shall be conclusively presumed to be that obtained at the communications desk of the city police department as adjunct to the National Weather Service. 
(4)  At the time of permitting of any draft animal, and at anytime, upon demanded by the city inspector, a valid Equine Infectious Anemia (EIA) certification for the draft animal then in service must be produced. 
(5)  Each license holder shall require, and each driver must maintain, a log of the starting and ending times for each driver and each draft animal. Said log should be kept in a bound book form and continuously available upon the carriage being pulled for inspection by the city inspector. 
(6)  No draft animal shall be permitted to pull a vehicle for hire without properly fitting shoes or boots on each properly trimmed hoof, with said shoes or boots to be made only of rubber or similar other synthetic material. No shoes or boots made of iron, drilltech, borium, studs, spikes or any other types of shoes that can cause damage to pavement, concrete, brick pavers, or similarly hard surface types will be permitted. 
(i)  The inspector shall be empowered to inspect all operating practices of any carriage company to ensure continuous compliance with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 99-12-02, 12-2-8-99; Ord. No. 17-6-01 , 6-20-17) 
Sec. 67-3. - Insurance. 
(a)  Indemnity for benefit of city. Any horse-drawn carriage company operating under this chapter shall hold the city, its officers, agents, servants and employees, harmless against any and all liability, loss damages or expense which may accrue to the city by reason of negligence, default or misconduct of the company in connection with the rights granted to such company hereunder. Nothing in this chapter shall be considered to make the city, its officers, agents, servants or employees liable for damages because of any negligent act or omission or commission by any horse-drawn carriage company, its servants, agents, drivers, or other employees, during the operation by the company of a horse-drawn carriage business or service, either in respect to injury to persons or with respect to damage to property which may be sustained. 
(b)  Insurance for benefit of passengers. Any horse-drawn carriage company holding a license to do business shall give and maintain a policy of indemnity from an insurance company authorized to do business in the state for each vehicle in use as a horse-drawn carriage. The minimum coverage shall be $300,000.00 for bodily injury to any one person, $500,000.00 for injury to more than one person which are sustained in the same accident, and $50,000.00 for property damage resulting from one accident. The indemnity insurance shall inure to the benefit of any person who shall be injured or who shall sustain damage to property caused by the negligence of a horse-drawn carriage company, its servants or agents. 
(c)  Blanket policy. Any company or person operating a horse-drawn carriage in the city shall give a separate policy of indemnity insurance for each separate horse-drawn carriage for hire, except where such company or person actually owns or operates more than one horse-drawn carriage, in which event such company or person may give one policy of indemnity insurance covering all the horse-drawn carriages actually owned or operated. 
(d)  Notice when voided. Before any policy of insurance required by this chapter is voided for any cause, nonpayment of premium or otherwise, notice thereof shall be given, by the licensee in writing, to the city manager at least five days before the same shall take effect. 
(Ord. No. 99-12-02, 12-2-8-99) 
Sec. 67-4. - Horse-drawn carriage driver permit required for identification. 
(a)  Permits required. 
(1)  No person shall operate a horse-drawn carriage for hire upon the streets of the city, and no person who holds a horse-drawn carriage license pursuant to this chapter 67, shall permit a horse-drawn carriage to be driven, at any time for hire, unless the driver of the horse-drawn carriage shall: 
a.  Have a current motor vehicle operator's license issued or approved by the state, and that the license is not under suspension or revocation; and 
b.  Have obtained and shall have then in force a horse-drawn carriage driver's permit issued under the provisions of this section. 
(2)  Any person desiring a permit required by this section shall submit an application in writing to the city manager on a form to be furnished by the city manager. The application shall be made under oath and shall contain, at a minimum, the following information: 
a.  The age of the applicant; 
b.  Date of birth; 
c.  Address; 
d.  The name and license number of the horse-drawn carriage company for whom the applicant shall operate; and 
e.  A photograph of the applicant. 
(b)  Driver's permit fee. Before any permit is granted under this section, an administrative for the driver's permit in the amount of $35.00 shall be paid by the applicant. 
(c)  Permit to be displayed in horse-drawn carriage. The permit issued under the provisions of this section shall be placed on display in the horse-drawn carriage then being operated by the holder of the permit, where the permit will be in clear view of the passengers at all times when the horse-drawn carriage is for hire. 
(d)  Alteration of permits prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person willfully to alter, deface, obliterate or destroy a horse-drawn carriage driver's permit, or cause or allow the same. 
(e)  Multiple permits allowable. It shall be permissible for any person to hold multiple driver permits, and they shall be required to obtain multiple permits to operate separate carriages. 
(f)  Permit not transferable. Any horse-drawn carriage driver's permit issued under this section is not transferable, either from person to person, or from carriage to carriage, and is to be used solely by the person to whom it is issued, and solely for the carriage identified upon the permit. 
(g)  Duration of permit. Any horse-drawn carriage driver's permit shall be valid for that calendar year. Permits may be renewed, upon application and payment of the required fee. 
(Ord. No. 99-12-02, 12-2-8-99) 
Sec. 67-5. - Horse-drawn carriage draft animals permit required for identification. 
(a)  Permits required. 
(1)  No draft animal shall be allowed to draw a horse-drawn carriage for hire upon the streets of the city, and no person who holds a horse-drawn carriage license pursuant to this chapter shall permit any draft animal to draw a horse-drawn carriage at any time for hire, unless the license holder of the horse-drawn carriage shall have obtained and shall have then in force a horse-drawn carriage draft animal permit issued under the provisions of this section. 
(2)  Any person desiring a permit required by this section shall submit an application in writing to the city manager on a form to be furnished by the city manager. The application shall be made under oath and shall contain, at a minimum, the following information: 
a.  The name and description of the draft animal; 
b.  Date of birth of the draft animal; 
c.  Name and address of the owner of the draft animal; 
d.  The name and license number of the horse-carriage company for whom the draw animal shall labor; and 
e.  A photograph of the draft animal. 
(b)  Draft animal's permit fee. Before any permit is granted under this section, and administrative fee for the draft animal permit in the amount of $65.00 shall be paid by the applicant. 
(c)  Permit to be displayed in horse-drawn carriage. The permit issued under the provisions of this section shall be placed on display in the horse-drawn carriage then being drawn by the permitted draft animal, where the permit will be in clear view of the passengers at all times when the horse-drawn carriage is for hire. 
(d)  Alteration of permits prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person willfully to alter, deface, obliterate or destroy a horse-drawn carriage draft animal, or cause or allow the same. 
(e)  Multiple permits allowable. It shall be permissible for any draft animal to be permitted multiple times, and they shall be required to obtained multiple permits to draw separate carriages. 
(f)  Permit not transferable. Any horse-drawn carriage draft animal's permit issued under this section is not transferable, either from draft animal to draft animal, or from carriage to carriage, and is to be used solely by the draft animal for which it is issued, and solely for the carriage identified upon the permit. 
(g)  Duration of permit. Any horse-drawn carriage draft animal's permit shall be valid for that calendar year. Permits may be renewed, upon application and payment of the required fee. 
(Ord. No. 99-12-02, 12-2-8-99) 
Sec. 67-6. - Identification and marking generally. 
Every horse-drawn carriage shall have a sign, clearly visible and readable, painted or affixed upon the rear of each vehicle. The sign shall contain the full name of the horse-drawn carriage company operating the vehicle. Additionally, the sign shall conform with all sign standards for the city and be permitted by the city in the same manner as all other signs. 
(Ord. No. 99-12-02, 12-2-8-99) 
Sec. 67-7. - Numbers generally. 
There shall be painted or affixed on each side and on the rear of each horse-drawn carriage a number of such uniform size and color as is, in the sole discretion of the city, appropriate for identification, and applied to the carriage by the city designee. The number shall be a separate and distinct number from that on any other public vehicle in the city. The number shall be assigned to such horse-drawn carriage by the city manager, or his designee, at the time of application for license, and shall not be altered or changed without consent of the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 99-12-02, 12-2-8-99) 
Sec. 67-8. - Safe mechanical condition of horse-drawn carriage required. 
Every horse-drawn carriage operated on the streets of the city shall be maintained in a safe mechanical condition, with all safety equipment remaining intact and operative at all times when the horse-drawn carriage is in service. 
(Ord. No. 99-12-02, 12-2-8-99) 
Sec. 67-9. - Cleanliness of horse-drawn carriage required. 
Each vehicle operating under this chapter shall be kept neatly painted, and in clean and sanitary condition, free of litter and debris, and at all times suitable for public transportation of passengers. 
(Ord. No. 99-12-02, 12-2-8-99) 
Sec. 67-10. - Vehicle inspections required. 
Each horse-drawn carriage may be inspected by the inspector for compliance with the provisions of the chapter and shall pass the inspection before the vehicle may be used as a horse-drawn carriage in the city. Each horse-drawn carriage involved in an accident shall be inspected by the inspector before it may be returned to service transporting passengers for hire. Inspections of the horse-drawn carriage may be done at any time by the inspector. 
(Ord. No. 99-12-02, 12-2-8-99) 
Sec. 67-11. - Rates of fare; rate card required. 
No license holder, driver, or any other person associated with a horse-drawn carriage shall charge a greater sum for the use of the horse-drawn carriage than that published and advertised as the rates for such vehicle, which shall be displayed in each vehicle. Rates shall be displayed conspicuously at each entrance to the carriage, so as to be in clear view of all passengers. The specific location and size of the rate posting must be approved by the inspector. 
(Ord. No. 99-12-02, 12-2-8-99) 
Sec. 67-12. - No horse-drawn carriage to be left unattended. 
It is unlawful for any driver of any horse-drawn carriage to, or for the license holder thereof to permit, the vehicle to be left unattended at any time. 
(Ord. No. 99-12-02, 12-2-8-99) 
Sec. 67-13. - Soliciting passengers prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to overtly solicit passengers for hire. 
(Ord. No. 99-12-02, 12-2-8-99) 
Sec. 67-14. - Restriction on number of passengers. 
No horse-drawn carriage shall transport more persons at a single time than the seating capacity of his horse-drawn carriage, as identified in the license. 
(Ord. No. 99-12-02, 12-2-8-99) 
Sec. 67-15. - Refusal to carry orderly passengers prohibited. 
No driver shall refuse or neglect to convey any orderly person or persons, upon request, unless previously engaged or unable or forbidden by the provisions of this chapter to do so. 
(Ord. No. 99-12-02, 12-2-8-99) 
Sec. 67-16. - Property left in horse-drawn carriage by passenger. 
Any horse-drawn carriage driver or operator, discovering in any horse-drawn carriage under his control, personal property which was lost or left therein by a passenger of such horse-drawn carriage, shall report the loss, and deliver all the property to the police department within two hours after the discovery of the property. 
(Ord. No. 99-12-02, 12-2-8-99) 
Sec. 67-17. - Safety equipment required. 
(a)  Each horse-drawn carriage shall be equipped with electrically powered lights or lanterns, and reflectors of not less than two inches in diameter or four square inches if square or rectangular. Such lights shall be in use when operating during the hours of darkness and when raining. The lights and reflectors shall be mounted so that they are visible from a distance of 500 feet. At a minimum, lights shall be located on all four side corners of the vehicle, and at a height no less than two feet, nor more than six feet, above the road surface. At a minimum, there shall be a total of eight reflectors which shall be mounted one on the outside of each shaft, two on each side, and two on the rear. A DOT approved slow moving vehicle sign shall be attached upon the rear of the vehicle so as to be clearly visible from a rear approach. 
(b)  Each horse-drawn carriage shall be equipped with a functional and operative friction braking. 
(Ord. No. 99-12-02, 12-2-8-99) 
Sec. 67-18. - Area of operation. 
The city manager shall set a repetitive route or routes for horse-drawn carriage, however, such election shall not prohibit pick up and transport of prearranged passengers for hire who request transport deviating from established routes. The city manager shall also designate the location of stands and the number of carriages which may be located at each stand at any one time. 
(Ord. No. 99-12-02, 12-2-8-99) 
Sec. 67-19. - Sanitation requirements. 
Draft animal manure and urine must immediately, and without any delay whatsoever, be treated with a chemical deodorizing solution, and manure must be removed immediately, and without any delay whatsoever, from the street by the license holder or some person immediately available on behalf of the license holder. Each carriage must be equipped with a suitable scoop shovel and airtight container for the temporary storage of removed manure. Horse diapers, designed, affixed, and maintained to prevent excrement from being deposited on the street surface, must be used at all times upon draft animals. All manure must be disposed of properly. 
(Ord. No. 99-12-02, 12-2-8-99) 
Sec. 67-20. - Traffic violations. 
(a)  Horse-drawn carriages shall be prohibited from stopping in traffic or delaying any on-street traffic for the purposes of loading or unloading passengers or for any other purposes. 
(b)  All vehicles subject to this chapter shall operate the vehicles in accordance with the traffic laws of the city, as well as the state. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any horse-drawn carriage to willfully impede the normal flow of traffic on any city street, alley or thoroughfare, and are required to travel at the extreme right of the road surface when followed by any other vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 99-12-02, 12-2-8-99) 
Sec. 67-21. - Violations; penalty. 
Any person violating the provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable as provided in section 1-7 of this Code. In addition, violation of this chapter shall also be grounds for suspension or revocation of the license issued under this chapter. Every transport for hire in violation of this ordinance shall be deemed a separate violation. 
(Ord. No. 99-12-02, 12-2-8-99) 
Sec. 67-22. - Commission hearing on revocation or suspension of license. 
(a)  When in the opinion of the commission or city manager, grounds for the suspension and/or revocation of a license pursuant to this chapter may exist, the licensee shall be served by the chief of police or other officer with written notice to appear at a show-cause hearing before the commission on a weekday not less than five days and no more than 30 days from the date of such service. The notice shall contain the grounds alleged. The hearing shall constitute a separate and distinct called meeting. 
(b)  The standard of proof to be applied by the commission at the hearing in determining whether or not grounds exist for the suspension and/or revocation of a license is preponderance of the evidence. A preponderance of the evidence is defined as evidence upon the issues involved, which, while not enough to wholly free the mind from a reasonable doubt, is yet sufficient to incline a reasonable and impartial mind to one side of the issue rather than the other. 
(Ord. No. 99-12-02, 12-2-8-99) 
Sec. 67-23. - Effective date. 
This ordinance shall become effective and enforceable on January 1, 2000. 
(Ord. No. 99-12-02, 12-2-8-99) 
Chapter 68 - MOTOR VEHICLES FOR HIRE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 15-08-01 , adopted Sept. 15, 2015, repealed the former Ch. 68, §§ 68-1—68-27, and enacted a new Ch. 68 as set out herein. The former Ch. 68 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 14-08-02 , adopted Oct. 7, 2014. 

Sec. 68-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms, or phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings given in this section. 
Vehicles for hire. Any and all automobiles, including taxicabs and ride share drivers, designed and used for the purpose of transporting less than 10 passengers for consideration or charges which are determined by agreement, contract, mileage, or length of time, not operating from a fixed terminal on a fixed route. 
(Ord. No. 15-08-01 , 9-15-15) 
Sec. 68-2. - Requirements. 
Pursuant to O.C.G.A., § 40-5-39. No person shall operate a motor vehicle for hire within the city limits of Helen, Georgia unless such person: 
(1)  Has a for-hire license endorsement pursuant to this Code section (O.C.G.A., § 40-5-39) and has liability insurance coverage in the amounts required by law for the class of motor vehicle being operated for hire and the requirements for limousine carriers, ride share networks and drivers, and taxi services, as applicable; or 
(2)  Has a private background check certification pursuant to this Code section (O.C.G.A., § 40-5-39) and has liability insurance coverage in the amounts required by law for the class of motor vehicle being operated for hire and the requirements for limousine carriers, ride share networks and drivers, and taxi services, as applicable. 
Any driver of a vehicle for hire, that fails to meet the requirements of O.C.G.A., § 40-5-39 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, pursuant to O.C.G.A., § 40-5-39(g). 
(Ord. No. 15-08-01 , 9-15-15)

ARTICLE II. - WATER SYSTEM[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Technical codes, § 34-801. 
State Law reference— Water system authorized, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, par. III(a)(7). 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 70-26. - Penalty. 
(a)  Any person found to be violating any provision of this article shall be deemed guilty of a municipal offense and upon conviction therefor shall be punished as provided in section 1-7. 
(b)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall become liable to the city for any expense, loss or damage occasioned the city by reason of such violation. 
(Code 1987, § 20-117) 
Sec. 70-27. - Control, supervision. 
The municipal water works shall be under the immediate control and supervision of the city manager or designated official who shall perform all acts that may be necessary for the prudent, efficient, and economical management and protection of the water works, subject to the approval and confirmation of the commission. 
(Code 1987, § 20-101) 
Sec. 70-28. - Inspections. 
The city manager or designated official may at any reasonable time examine the condition of the city owned water pipes and fixtures up to and including the water meter. 
(Code 1987, § 20-102) 
Sec. 70-29. - Application for water service. 
Application for the use of water shall be made to the city clerk by the owner or agent of the property to be benefited, designating the location of the property and stating the purpose for which the water may be required. 
(Code 1987, § 20-103) 
Sec. 70-30. - Connection charge, tap-on fee. 
(a)  Upon the application for a new connection charge that includes the fee for tap and service connection by any consumer within the corporate limits of the city, the applicant shall pay to the city clerk a fee as spelled out below. 
(b)  The city shall own and maintain the water line from the main to the curb box and the property owner shall own and maintain the service line from the curb box to the premises served. 
(c)  All work upon the service line shall be performed by a licensed plumber. 
(d)  Fees. 
(1)  All installations (including backflow preventor): 
¾ inch meter ..... $  600.00 
1 inch meter ..... 1,000.00 
2 inch meter ..... 3,000.00 
Larger than 2 inch ..... 5,000.00 
In addition the applicant shall also pay the city's actual cost of the connection to the city water system, including all direct and indirect cost of materials, labor and equipment, as determined by the city from time to time. All fees for connection to the water system shall be paid as a prerequisite for approval of said connection to the water system. The city may accept a deposit reflecting the estimated cost to the city of connecting the user to water, pending final determination of actual cost after the work has been completed. No water service shall be established until all fees have been paid in full. 
(e)  On a building with multiple units there may be a water meter for each unit or a single meter if authorized by the city manager. 
(f)  All water tap on fees are to be paid when a development or building plan is approved. 
(Code 1987, § 20-104; Ord. No. 88-2, 4-26-88; Ord. No. 99-09-01, 10-19-99; Ord. No. 04-04-01, 5-4-04) 
Sec. 70-31. - Standby sprinkler connection charge. 
Upon an application for a standby sprinkler connection by any consumer or upon the formal adoption by the commission of a required standby sprinkler connection for any consumer class, such connection charge shall be $675.00 per connection. Installation shall be done by tradesmen licensed as pipe fitters by the state, under the inspection of the city. 
(Code 1987, § 20-105) 
Sec. 70-32. - Unauthorized connections and disturbances. 
No person shall uncover, make any connections with or opening into, use, alter, or disturb any public water line, or appurtenance thereof including meters and meter boxes without first obtaining a permit from the city manager. Permits shall only be granted to persons authorized by the plumbing code to do such work. 
(Code 1987, § 20-106) 
Sec. 70-33. - Water meters. 
(a)  Each building or structure using city water shall have a water meter installed by the city. All such meters are the property of the city. 
(b)  The city shall install its meter at or near the property line when feasible, or at the city's option, and the owner's consent, within the property line. When the meter or meter box is placed within the property line, a suitable place, which is unobstructed and accessible at all times to the city's personnel, shall be provided by the owner. 
(c)  In the event a city meter shall be placed within the property line, by the consent for such placement, the owner thereof grants to the city a permanent easement, ten feet either side of the city's water line, and a radius ten feet from the meter itself, for the purpose of maintenance, replacement, repair, inspection, and meter reading. The city shall have no liability to the owner for any damage suffered by the city's reasonable and proper use of the easement, and the city shall be under no obligation to restore the property following reasonable maintenance, replacement, or inspection. 
(d)  Private water meters may be installed within the property line, and inside the water flow from any city water meter, however the city shall have no responsibility therefor, and the owner and consumer shall be fully, and solely, responsible for such meters and any water loss or other damage resulting from any private water meter. 
(e)  No person shall connect to the city's water system without having a back-flow prevention devise properly installed 
(Code 1987, § 20-107; Ord. No. 01-11-01, 11-20-01) 
Sec. 70-34. - Service line regulations. 
No more than one building shall be permitted to use a water service line. Only galvanized or PVC schedule 40 pipe shall be used for the installation of a service line and all service lines shall be installed at a depth at least 40 inches below the surface of the ground. Each service line shall contain a stop and waste cock where the water may be turned off. 
(Code 1987, § 20-108) 
Sec. 70-35. - Water waste prohibition. 
(a)  Consumers shall prevent unnecessary waste of water and keep all water outlets closed when not in actual use. Hydrants, urinals, water closets, bathtubs, faucets and other fixtures must not be left running for any purpose other than the use for which they were intended. When any such waste occurs, the water service may be terminated. 
(b)  Except as provided for in subsection (c) below, only ultra-low flow plumbing fixtures compliant with the following maximum permitted water flow rates shall be installed when erecting a new structure, or altering an existing structure to effect its repair or renovation, or making an addition to an existing structure, or replacing malfunctioning, unserviceable, or obsolete faucets, showerheads, toilets or urinals in an existing structure: 

 
(c)  New construction and the repair or renovation of an existing structure shall be exempt from the requirements of subsection (b) above when: 
(1)  The repair or renovation of the existing structure does not include the replacement of the plumbing or sewage system serving toilets, faucets or showerheads within such existing structure; 
(2)  When the plumbing or sewage system within an existing structure, because of its capacity, design or installation would not function properly if the toilets, faucets or showerheads required by subsection (b) were installed; 
(3)  Such system is a well or gravity flow from a spring and is owned privately by an individual for use in such individual's personal residence; or 
(4)  The plumbing fixtures to be installed are: 
a.  Specifically designed for use by the handicapped; 
b.  Specifically designed to withstand unusual abuse or installation in a penal institution; or 
c.  Toilets for juveniles. 
(d)  The owner, or his agent, of a structure undergoing new construction or repair or renovation who is entitled to an exemption as specified in subsection (c) above shall obtain the exemption by applying to the city manager or designee in writing, on such forms as may be determined by the city manager or designee. A fee of $10.00 shall be charged for the inspection and issuance of such exemption. 
(Ord. No. 91-1, § 20-109, 2-26-91) 
State Law reference— Water conservation requirements for plumbing fixtures, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-3. 
Sec. 70-36. - Restriction on outdoor water[ing] of landscape. 
(a)  Restrictions. Outdoor watering for purposes of planting, growing, managing, or maintaining ground cover, trees, shrubs, or other plants may occur only between the hours of 4:00 p.m. and 10:00 a.m.; provided, however, that this limitation shall not create any limitation upon the following outdoor water uses: 
(A)  Commercial raising, harvesting, or storing of crops; feeding, breeding, or managing livestock or poultry; the commercial production or storing of feed for use in the production of livestock, including, but not limited to, cattle, calves, swine, hogs, goats, sheep, and rabbits, or for use in the production of poultry, including, but not limited to, chickens, hens, ratites, and turkeys; producing plants, trees, fowl, or animals; or the commercial production of aqua cultural, horticultural, dairy, livestock, poultry, eggs, and apiarian products or as otherwise defined in O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3; 
(B)  Capture and reuse of cooling system condensate or storm water in compliance with applicable city ordinances and state guidelines; 
(C)  Reuse of gray water in compliance with O.C.G.A. § 31-3-5.2 and applicable local board of health regulations; 
(D)  Use of reclaimed waste water by a designated user from a system permitted by the Environmental Protection Division of the Georgia Department of Natural Resources to provide reclaimed waste water; 
(E)  Watering personal food gardens; 
(F)  Watering new and replanted plant, seed, or turf in landscapes, golf courses, or sports turf fields during installation and for a period of 30 days immediately following the date of installation; 
(G)  Drip irrigation or irrigation using soaker hoses; 
(H)  Hand watering with a hose with automatic cutoff or handheld container; 
(I)  Use of water withdrawn from private water wells or surface water by an owner or operator of property if such well or surface water is on said property; 
(J)  Watering horticultural crops held for sale, resale, or installation; 
(K)  Watering athletic fields, golf courses, or public turf grass recreational areas; 
(L)  Installation, maintenance, or calibration of irrigation systems; or 
(M)  Hydro seeding. 
(b)  Enforcement. No person shall use or allow the use of water in violation of the restrictions on outdoor water use contained in ordinance. The city manager shall enforce this ordinance and shall have the authority to city manager authorize such departments as may be deemed necessary to support enforcement. Any violation of this section may also be enforced by a citation returnable to the municipal court or by any other legal means as set forth in this Code. 
(c)  Further restrictions. In cases of further water shortage or scarcity, the commission may by resolution place such further restrictions upon the use of water for irrigation or sprinkler purposes as the commission deems necessary to further water conservation and water supply enhancement. 
(Code 1987, § 20-110; Ord. No. 10-12-01, 12-21-10, eff. 1-1-11) 
State Law reference— Outdoor Water Ordinance, O.C.G.A. § 12-5-7. 
Sec. 70-37. - Charges for turning water on. 
A new residential account that is accepted by the city will be assessed a $15.00 administrative fee along with a $200.00 deposit. A new commercial account that is accepted by the city will be assessed a $15.00 administrative fee along with a $500.00 deposit for restaurants and lounges, a $1,000.00 deposit for hotels, motels and water parks, and a $300.00 deposit for all other commercial accounts. 
For properties with new owners which need a temporary connection to ascertain the condition of the premises, an account application a temporary connection will be accepted by the city upon payment of a nonrefundable administrative fee of $50.00. A designated date and time will be provided to the applicant for the temporary connection, and the water will be connected for a 24-hour period. The applicant shall be responsible for water charges incurred during said 24-hour temporary connection period. 
If the water supply to any premises is disconnected due to nonpayment of the account, a reconnect fee will be assessed. The reconnect fee during regular business hours of Monday through Friday 8:30 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. will be $30.00 for the first occurrence within a 12-month period and $50.00 for the second occurrence within a 12-month period. After regular business hours and on weekends an additional $25.00 fee will be assessed to have the service reconnected. 
All water deposits will be held in a non-interest bearing account until such time as the account holder request that the service be disconnected and all amounts due are paid in full. 
(Code 1987, § 20-115; Ord. No. 93-8-2, § 20-115, 9-14-83; Ord. No. 99-06-02, 7-20-99; Ord. No. 07-02-01, 2-20-07; Ord. No. 11-12-01, 1-5-12) 
Sec. 70-38. - Charges for turning water off. 
If a customer requests that the water supply be turned off for any reason, a charge of $10.00 shall be made for turning the water off. 
(Code 1987, § 20-116) 
Sec. 70-39. - Use of city water hydrant. 
(a)  Any person desiring to withdraw water from a city fire hydrant shall make application to the city clerk for a water hydrant permit. At the time of application, the applicant shall be required to pay a deposit of $750.00 in the form of cash or bank certified check, for the use of the city's hydrant flow meter. Upon return of the meter to the city, payment for the water use shall be deducted from the deposit, and the balance shall be returned to the applicant. In the event the water use shall exceed the deposit, the excess shall be immediately due and payable. 
(b)  If the connection to the city's water system is to be used for the filling of a tank or any type container, the tank or container must be inspected by the water department operator for a back-flow prevention device. No person shall connect to the city's water system without having a back-flow prevention devise properly installed. 
(c)  Any person who does not return the hydrant meter to the city's water department within 30 days of the estimated return date stated on the permit shall be subject to forfeit the deposit. 
(d)  The use of the city's water hydrants shall be prohibited for the purpose of filling any water retention pool (e.g. swimming pool). Pools may be filled from approved metered connections to the city's water system. In order to protect the city's water supply, any filling of pools shall be limited to a maximum of 20,000 gallons in a 24-hour period. 

 
In case of a water shortage, the commission may by resolution place any restrictions upon the use of water for the filling or maintenance of water retention pools. 
(Ord. No. 01-11-01, 11-20-01; Ord. No. 07-12-01, 1-2-08) 
Secs. 70-40—70-50. - Reserved.

Charges shall be classified as follows: 
Residential inside the City of Helen. 
Residential outside the City of Helen. 
Commercial inside the City of Helen.

(Ord. No. 90-4, § 20-112, 8-21-90; Ord. No. 93-12-01, 1-11-94; Ord. No. 96-11-02, 12-10-96)
